revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = The International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics Network - ICRANet |image = ICRANet.png |image_size = 175px |type = [[International organization]] |director = [[Remo Ruffini]] |location = [[Pescara]], [[Italy]] |website = http://www.icranet.org |established = 2005}}
'''ICRANet''', the '''International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics Network''', is an [[international organization]] which promotes research activities in relativistic astrophysics and related areas. Its members are four countries and three Universities and Research Centers: the [[Armenia|Republic of Armenia]], the [[Brazil|Federative Republic of Brazil]], [[Italy|Italian Republic]], the [[Vatican City|Vatican City State]], the [[University of Arizona]] (USA), [[Stanford University]] (USA) and [[International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics|ICRA]].
ICRANet headquarters are located in [[Pescara]], Italy.
== History of ICRANet foundation: ICRA and ICRANet ==
=== ICRA and ICRANet ===
In 1985, the International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics<ref>{{cite web|title=ICRA|url=http://www.icra.it/|website=ICRA|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223074040/http://www.icra.it/|archive-date=2008-02-23|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> [[International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics|ICRA]] was founded by [[Remo Ruffini]] ([[Sapienza University of Rome|University of Rome "La Sapienza"]]) together with [[Riccardo Giacconi]] ([[Nobel Prize]] for Physics 2002<ref>{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 2002|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2002/summary/|publisher=[[Nobel Committee]]|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181008225757/https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2002/summary/|archive-date=2018-10-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>), [[Abdus Salam]] (Nobel Prize for Physics 1979<ref>{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1979|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1979/summary/|publisher=[[Nobel Committee]]|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180914132820/https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1979/summary|archive-date=2018-09-14|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>), Paul Boynton ([[University of Washington]]), [[George Coyne]] (former director of the [[Vatican Observatory|Vatican observatory]]), [[Francis Everitt]] ([[Stanford University]]) and [[Fang Lizhi|Fang Li-Zhi]] ([[University of Science and Technology of China]]).
The Statute and the Agreement establishing of ICRANet were signed on March 19, 2003, and they were recognized in the same year by the [[Armenia|Republic of Armenia]] and the [[Vatican City|Vatican City State]]. ICRANet has been created in 2005 by a law of the Italian Government, ratified by the Italian Parliament and signed by the President of the Italian Republic [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]] on February 10, 2005<ref>{{cite web|title=LEGGE 10 febbraio 2005, n. 31|url=http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/atto/vediMenuHTML?atto.dataPubblicazioneGazzetta=2005-03-05&atto.codiceRedazionale=005G0050&tipoSerie=serie_generale&tipoVigenza=originario|publisher=Gazzetta Ufficiale dell Repubblica Italiana|access-date=2015-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126185845/http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/atto/vediMenuHTML?atto.dataPubblicazioneGazzetta=2005-03-05&atto.codiceRedazionale=005G0050&tipoSerie=serie_generale&tipoVigenza=originario|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>. The Republic of Armenia, [[Italy|Italian Republic]], the Vatican City State, ICRA, the [[University of Arizona]] and the [[Stanford University]] are the founding members.
On September 12, 2005, ICRANet Steering Committee was established and had its first meeting: Remo Ruffini and Fang Li-Zhi were appointed respectively Director and Chairman of the Steering Committee. On December 19, 2006 ICRANet Scientific Committee was established and had its first meeting in Washington DC. Riccardo Giacconi was appointed Chairman and John Mester Co-Chairman.
On September 21, 2005 the Director of ICRANet signed, together with the then Ambassador of Brazil in Rome Dante Coelho De Lima the adhesion of the [[Brazil|Federative Republic of Brazil]] to ICRANet. The entrance of Brazil, requested by the then President of Brazil [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Luiz Ignácio Lula Da Silva]] has been unanimously ratified by the Brazilian Parliament. On August 12, 2011, the then President of Brazil [[Dilma Rousseff]] signed the entrance of Brazil in ICRANet.<ref>{{cite web|title=DECRETO Nº 7.552, DE 12 DE AGOSTO DE 2011.|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2011-2014/2011/Decreto/D7552.htm|website=Presidência da República|publisher=Presidência da República|access-date=2015-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126173536/http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2011-2014/2011/Decreto/D7552.htm|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
=== Marcel Grossmann meetings ===
By the beginning of the twentieth century the new branch of mathematics, tensor calculus, was developed in the works of [[Gregorio Ricci-Curbastro|Gregorio Ricci Curbastro]] and [[Tullio Levi-Civita|Tullio Levi Civita]] of the [[University of Padua]] and the [[Sapienza University of Rome|University of Rome "La Sapienza"]]. [[Marcel Grossmann]] of the [[University of Zurich]] who had a deep knowledge of the Italian school of geometry and who was close to Einstein introduced to him these concepts. The collaboration between Einstein and Grossmann was [[History of general relativity|essential]] for the development of General Relativity.
Remo Ruffini and Abdus Salam in 1975 established the Marcel Grossmann meetings (MG) on Recent Developments in Theoretical and Experimental General Relativity, Gravitation, and Relativistic Field Theories,<ref>{{cite web|title=Marcel Grossmann Meetings|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=258|website=icranet.org|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126165119/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=258|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> which take place every three years in different countries, gathering more then 1000 researchers. MG1 and MG2 were held in 1975 and in 1979 in [[Trieste]]; MG3 in 1982 in [[Shanghai]]; MG4 in 1985 in Rome; MG5 in 1988 in [[Perth]]; MG6 in 1991 in [[Kyoto]]; MG7 in 1994 at [[Stanford, California|Stanford]]; MG8 in 1997 in [[Jerusalem]]; MG9 in 2000 in Rome; MG10 in 2003 in [[Rio de Janeiro]]; MG11 in 2006 in [[Berlin]]; MG12 in 2009 in [[Paris]]; MG13 in 2012 in [[Stockholm]]; MG14 in 2015 and MG15 in 2018 both in Rome. Since its foundation, ICRANet has always played a leading role in the organization of those meetings.
=== Celebration of the International Year of Astronomy 2009 ===
ICRANet has been Organizational Associate<ref>{{cite web|title=IYA2009 Organisational Associates|url=https://www.astronomy2009.org/organisation/structure/partners/organisationalassociates/index.html|publisher=International Year of Astronomy|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126103020/http://www.astronomy2009.org/organisation/structure/partners/organisationalassociates/index.html|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> of the [[International Year of Astronomy]] 2009<ref>{{cite web|title=About IYA2009|url=http://www.astronomy2009.org/general/about/index.html|publisher=International Year of Astronomy|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131220641/http://astronomy2009.org/general/about/index.html|archive-date=2016-01-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and supported the global coordination of IYA2009 financially. In this occasion ICRANet organized a series of international meetings<ref>{{cite web|title=International Year of Astronomy 2009 Meetings|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=510&Itemid=837|3=|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126171134/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=510&Itemid=837|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> under the general title "The Sun, the Star, the Universe and General Relativity" including: the 1st Zeldovich meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=ICRANet 1st Zeldovich Meeting|url=http://www.icranet.org/zeldovich/|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126164645/http://www.icranet.org/zeldovich/|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Minsk, Belarus), the Sobral Meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=Sobral Meeting|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=435&Itemid=814|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126170022/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=435&Itemid=814|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Fortaleza, Brazil), the 1st Galileo - Xu Guangqi meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=GX4|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=442&Itemid=686|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208042450/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=442&Itemid=686|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Shanghai, China), the 11th Italian-Korean Symposium on Relativistic Astrophysics<ref>{{cite web|title=IK11|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=471&Itemid=827|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126164459/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=471&Itemid=827|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Seoul, South Korea) and the 5th Australasian Conference - Christchurch Meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=5th Australasian Conference|url=http://www2.phys.canterbury.ac.nz/ACGRG5/|publisher=University of Canterbury, New Zealand|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126181805/http://www2.phys.canterbury.ac.nz/ACGRG5/|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Christchurch, New Zealand).
=== Celebration of the International Year of Light 2015 ===
Under the initiative of the [[United Nations]] and [[UNESCO]], 2015 was declared the and as the [[International Year of Light]], and it represented the centenary of the formulation of the equations of general relativity by [[Albert Einstein]], and the fiftieth anniversary of the birth of relativistic astrophysics.<ref>{{cite web|title=Einstein Centenary|url=http://www.light2015.org/Home/CosmicLight/Einstein-Centenary.html|publisher=International Year of Light|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118021036/http://www.light2015.org/Home/CosmicLight/Einstein-Centenary.html|archive-date=2015-11-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> ICRANet was a "Bronze Associate" sponsor of those celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sponsors|url=http://www.light2015.org/Home/About/Sponsors.html|publisher=International Year of Light|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222183651/http://www.light2015.org/Home/About/Sponsors.html|archive-date=2016-02-22|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
In 2015, ICRANet also organized a series of international meetings<ref>{{cite web|title=IYL 2015 meetings|url=http://icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=926&Itemid=902|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126163608/http://icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=926&Itemid=902|archive-date=2015-11-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> including: the Second ICRANet César Lattes Meeting<ref name="2nd César Lattes Meeting">{{cite web|title=2nd César Lattes Meeting|url=http://www.icranet.org/2cl/|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930125426/http://www.icranet.org/2cl/|archive-date=2015-09-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Niterói – Rio de Janeiro – João Pessoa – Recife – Fortaleza, Brazil), the International Conference on Gravitation and Cosmology<ref>{{cite web|title=International Conference on Gravitation and Cosmology|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126173813/http://www.kitpc.ac.cn/?p=ProgDetail&id=CP20150504&i=main|publisher=Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics China at the Chinese Academy of Sciences (KITPC-CAS)|accessdate=3 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126173813/http://www.kitpc.ac.cn/?p=ProgDetail&id=CP20150504&i=main|archivedate=26 November 2015|df=}}</ref> / the 4th Galileo-Xu Guangqi meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=4th GX Meeting|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=918|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930102731/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=918|archive-date=2015-09-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Beijing, China), Fourteenth Marcel Grossmann Meeting<ref>{{cite web|title=14th Marcel Grossmann Meeting|url=http://www.icra.it/mg/mg14/|publisher=ICRA|accessdate=3 December Relativistic Astrophysics<ref>{{cite web|title=1 Julio Garavito Meeting|url=http://www.icranet.org/1jg/|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106190938/http://icranet.org/1jg/|archive-date=2016-01-06|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (Bucaramanga – Bogotá, Colombia), the 1st Sandoval Vallarta ==Organization and structure==
The organization consists of the Director, the Steering Committee and the Scientific Committee. The members of committees are representatives of the countries and member institutions. ICRANet has a number of permanent Faculty positions. Their activities are supported by administrative staff and secretariat personnel. ICRANet financing is based by Statute on the funds provided by the governments and by voluntary contributions, donations.
Director of ICRANet is [[Remo Ruffini]].
In 2018 the Steering Committee consists of:<ref>{{cite web|title=Steering Committee|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=687|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125043246/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=687|archive-date=2015-11-25|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * Armenia: Ashot Kocharian * Brazil: Gilberto Kassab, Minister of Science, Technology, Innovation and Communications * ICRA: Remo Ruffini * Italy: *# Italian Foreign Ministry, Unità Scientifica e Tecnologica Bilaterale e Multilaterale: Min. Plen. Fabrizio Nicoletti, Cons. Enrico Padula, Immacolata Pannone *# Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ragioneria Generale dello Stato, IGAE, Uff. IX: Dr. Antonio Bartolini, Dr. Salvatore Sebastiano Vizzini *# MIUR: Dr. Vincenzo Di Felice, Dott.ssa Giulietta Iorio *# Pescara Municipality: Avv. Carlo Masci * Stanford University: Francis Everitt * University of Arizona: [[Xiaohui Fan]] * Vatican City State: [[Guy Consolmagno|Guy J. Consolmagno, S.J.]] The current Chairperson (2018) of ICRANet Steering Committee is Francis Everitt.
The first Chairperson of the Scientific Committee was Riccardo Giacconi, Nobel Prize for Physics in 2002, who ended his term in 2013. The actual (2018) Chairperson of the Scientific Committee is Massimo Della Valle.
The Scientific Committee in 2018 consists of:<ref>{{cite web|title=Scientific Committee|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=688|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125041805/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=688|archive-date=2015-11-25|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Prof. Narek Sahakyan (Armenia), Dr. Barres de Almeida Ulisses (Brazil), Dr. Carlo Luciano Bianco (ICRA), Prof. Massimo Della Valle (Italy), Prof. John Mester (Stanford University), Prof. Chris Fryer (University of Arizona) and Dr. Gabriele Gionti (Vatican City State).
The Faculty<ref>{{cite web|title=Faculty|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=332&Itemid=806|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=14 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912063650/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=332&Itemid=806|archive-date=2017-09-12|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> in 2018 consists of Professors Ulisses Barres de Almeida, [[Vladimir Belinski]], Carlo Luciano Bianco, Donato Bini, Pascal Chardonnet, Christian Cherubini, Filippi Simonetta, Robert Jantzen, Roy Patrick Kerr, Hans Ohanian, Giovanni Pisani, Brian Mathew Punsly, Jorge Rueda, Remo Ruffini, Gregory Vereshchagin, and She-Sheng Xue, and is supported by an Adjunct Faculty<ref>{{cite web|title=Adjunct Faculty|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=327&Itemid=785|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=14 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180122052524/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=327&Itemid=785|archive-date=2018-01-22|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> made up of more than 30 internationally renowned scientists participating in ICRANet activities, and between eighty "Lecturers"<ref>{{cite web|title=Lecturers|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=359&Itemid=686|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=14 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831170731/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=359&Itemid=686|archive-date=2011-08-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and "Visiting Professors"<ref>{{cite web|title=Lecturers|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=917|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref>. Among these are the Nobel Laureates [[Riccardo Giacconi]], [[Murray Gell-Mann]], [[Theodor W. Hänsch|Theodor Hänsch]], [[Gerard 't Hooft|Gerard ’t Hooft]] and [[Steven Weinberg]].
== Member states and institutions == Currently ICRANet members are four countries and three Universities and research centers.
Member states: {| class="wikitable" !Country !Date joined |- |{{flag|Armenia}} |2003 |- |{{flag|Federal Republic of Brazil}} |2011 |- |{{flag|Italian Republic}} |2003 |- |{{flag|Vatican City State}} |2003 |}
Member institutions: {| class="wikitable" !Institution !Date joined |- |[[University of Arizona]] (USA) |2003 |- |[[Stanford University]] (USA) |2003 |- |[[International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics|ICRA]] |2003 |}
ICRANet has signed collaboration agreements with over 57 institutions, universities and research centers in different countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Documents|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=16&Itemid=818|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125185344/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=16&Itemid=818|archive-date=2015-11-25|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
== ICRANet seats and centers == The network is composed of several seats and centers. Seat agreements, establishing rights and privileges, including [[extraterritoriality]], have been signed for the seat in Pescara in Italy, for the seat in Rio de Janeiro in Brazil and for the seat in [[Yerevan]] in Armenia. The Seat Agreement for Pescara<ref>{{cite web|title=LEGGE 13 maggio 2010, n. 83|url=http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/atto/vediMenuHTML?atto.dataPubblicazioneGazzetta=2010-06-10&atto.codiceRedazionale=010G0106&tipoSerie=serie_generale&tipoVigenza=originario|publisher=Gazzetta Ufficiale della Repubblica Italiana|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151209003223/http://www.gazzettaufficiale.it/atto/vediMenuHTML?atto.dataPubblicazioneGazzetta=2010-06-10&atto.codiceRedazionale=010G0106&tipoSerie=serie_generale&tipoVigenza=originario|archive-date=2015-12-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> has been ratified on May 13, 2010. The Seat agreement for Yerevan has been unanimously approved<ref name=ArmAppr>{{cite web|title=ՀԱՅԱՍՏԱՆԻ ՀԱՆՐԱՊԵՏՈՒԹՅԱՆ ԱԶԳԱՅԻՆ ԺՈՂՈՎԻ ՀԻՆԳԵՐՈՐԴ ԳՈՒՄԱՐՄԱՆ ՈՒԹԵՐՈՐԴ ՆՍՏԱՇՐՋԱՆԻ 2015 ԹՎԱԿԱՆԻ ՆՈՅԵՄԲԵՐԻ 10-13-Ի ԱՐՏԱՀԵՐԹ ՆԻՍՏԻ ԱՐՁԱՆԱԳՐՈՒԹՅՈՒՆ|url=http://parliament.am/register.php?AgendaID=400&day=13&month=11&year=2015&lang=#13.11.2015|publisher=National Assembly of the Republic of Armenia|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208070155/http://parliament.am/register.php?AgendaID=400&day=13&month=11&year=2015&lang=#13.11.2015#13.11.2015|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> by the Parliament of Armenia on November 13, 2015.
High speed [[optical fiber]] connection with different locations are made possible by the connection to the pan-European data network for the research and education community ([[GÉANT]]) through the [[GARR]] network.
Currently ICRANet centers<ref>{{cite web|title=ICRANet centers|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=451&Itemid=820|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226122346/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=451&Itemid=820|archive-date=2015-12-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> are operative at: * ICRANet Headquarters in Pescara, Italy * The Department of Physics of University "[[La Sapienza]]" (Rome, Italy); * Villa Ratti (Nice, France); * The Presidium of the [[Armenian National Academy of Sciences]] (Yerevan, Armenia); * [[CBPF]] – Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Físicas (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil); * Isfahan University of Technology (Isfahan, Iran); * National Academy of Science of Belarus (Minsk, Belarus).
===ICRANet Centers in Pescara, Rome and Nice===
ICRANet headquarters are located in [[Pescara]], Italy. This center coordinates ICRANet activities and yearly meetings of the Scientific and the Steering committees are usually held there. International meetings such as the Italian-Korean Symposia on Relativistic Astrophysics<ref>{{cite web|title=IK Symposia|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=94&Itemid=635|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226104000/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=94&Itemid=635|archive-date=2015-12-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> are regularly held in this center. Scientific activities in Pescara center include the fundamental research on the early cosmology by the Russian school guided by [[Vladimir Belinski]].
Activities of the ICRANet Seat at Villa Ratti in Nice include the coordination of the IRAP PhD program, as well as scientific activities connected with the ultra high energy observations by the University of Savoy and the [[Very Large Telescope|VLT]] observations performed by the Côte d’Azur Observatory, which involve the thesis works of IRAP PhD students. The University of Savoy is the closest French lab to the [[CERN]].
{| style="border: 1px solid darkgray; margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" ! style="width: 250px;" | [[File:ICRANet Pescara.jpg|265px]] ! style="width: 250px;" | [[File:Sapienza entrance (20040201351).jpg|250px]] ! style="width: 250px;" | [[File:Villa Ratti.jpg|180px]] |- style="text-align: center;" |''ICRANet Headquarters in Pescara (Italy).'' |''The University of Rome "[[La Sapienza]]" where the Physics Department hosts ICRANet center in Rome (Italy).'' |''ICRANet seat in Nice (France).'' |}
===ICRANet Center in Armenia===
[[File:Icranet-nas_ra.jpg|thumb|The Presidium of the National Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Armenia (NAS RA), where ICRANet seat in Yerevan (Armenia) is located.]]
Since January 2014, the ICRANet Center in Yerevan<ref>{{cite web|title=ՀայIcraNET-Yerevan Center|url=https://armenpress.am/arm/news/727306/hay-italakan-haraberutyunnery-kzarganan-naev-astxagitutyan.html|language=en|publisher=[[Armenpress]]|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208080559/http://armenpress.am/arm/news/727306/hay-italakan-haraberutyunnery-kzarganan-naev-astxagitutyan.html|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> has been established the Presidium of the [[Armenian National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Armenia (NAS RA)]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Հայ-իտալական հարաբերությունները կզարգանան նաև աստղագիտության ոլորտում |url=https://www.sci.am/m/orgsview.php?id=9&langid=2#top|language=am|publisher=[[Armenpress]]|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>, at Marshall Baghramian Avenue, 24a. Scientific activities in this center are coordinated by the Director, Dr. Narek Sahakyan. In 2014, the Government of the Republic of Armenia approved the Agreement to establish the ICRANet international center in Armenia. The Seat Agreement has been signed in Rome on February 14, 2015, by the director of ICRANet, Remo Ruffini and the Ambassador of Armenia in Italy, Mr. Sargis Ghazaryan. On November 13, 2015, the Parliament of the Republic of Armenia unanimously approved the Seat Agreement<ref name=ArmAppr/>. Since January 2016 ICRANet Armenia center is registered at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as an international organization<ref>{{cite web |title=International Organizations - MFA.AM |url=https://www.mfa.am/en/international-organizations |website=www.mfa.am |publisher=MFA |access-date=2018-11-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116220204/https://www.mfa.am/en/international-organizations |archive-date=2018-11-16 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>. The main areas of scientific research in ICRANet-Armenia are in the fields of relativistic astrophysics, astroparticle physics, X-ray astrophysics, high and very high energy gamma-ray astrophysics, high energy neutrino astrophysics. The center is a full member of the MAGIC international collaboration since 2017. Also, the center is actively involved in development of the Open Universe Initiative. In Armenia, the ICRANet center collaborates with other scientific institutions from the Academy and Universities, and provides to organize joint international meetings and workshops, summer schools for PhD students and mobility programs for scientists in the field of Astrophysics. ICRANet center in Armenia coordinates ICRANet activities in the area of Central-Asian and Middle-Eastern countries.
A summer school and an international scientific conference dedicated to the issues of Relativistic Astrophysics "1st Scientific ICRANet Meeting in Armenia: Black Holes: the largest energy sources in the Universe" were held in Armenia from June 28 to July 4, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=1st Meeting in Armenia|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/seatAgreementArmenia_eng.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.am/arm/news/218620.html|title=Ռելյատիվիստական աստղաֆիզիկայի միջազգային գիտաժողով՝ Հայաստանում (ֆոտո)|language=am|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208074918/http://news.am/arm/news/218620.html|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===ICRANet Center in Brazil===
[[File:CBPF (9135367394).jpg|thumb|Entrance of CBPF, where ICRANet seat in Rio de Janeiro is located.]]
The Seat of ICRANet in Rio de Janeiro has been activated, at first in the premises granted by [[Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Físicas|CBPF]]; with the possible expansion to the [[Cassino da Urca]]. A school of Cosmology and Astrophysics is being developed jointly with Brazilian institutions. The 2nd ICRANet César Lattes Meeting devoted to relativistic astrophysics was held in Rio de Janeiro in 2015.<ref name="2nd César Lattes Meeting"/>
Currently (2018) ICRANet has signed scientific collaboration agreements with 175 Brazilian universities, institutions and research centers.<ref>{{cite web|title=ICRANet Brazil Agreements|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/ICRANet_Brazil_Agreements_total.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208052850/http://www.icranet.org/documents/ICRANet_Brazil_Agreements_total.pdf|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
There are two specific programs initiated by ICRANet, which are underway (2018): * the possibility of restructuring the mountain side of the [[Urca|Cassino da Urca]] as the Seat of ICRANet for Brazil and Latin America (with a project by the Italian Architect Carlo Serafini), * building of the [[Brazilian Science Data Center]] (BSDC), a novel astrophysics data base, built following the concept of the ASI Science Data Center (ASDC) by the Italian Space Agency, which will consist on a unique research infrastructure at the interface between experimental and theoretical astrophysicists.
===ICRANet Center in Minsk===
[[File:Icranet-nasb.jpg|thumb|The National Academy of Science of Belarus (NASB), where ICRANet seat center in Minsk is located.]]
The ICRANet-Minsk center has been established at the National Academy of Science of Belarus (NASB), with whom ICRANet has signed a cooperation agreement on 2013<ref>{{cite web|title=Agreement ICRANet Belarus|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-Belarus_eng.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105212831/http://www.icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-Belarus_eng.pdf|archive-date=2016-01-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Agreement ICRANet Belarus|url=http://icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-Belarus_rus.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105203205/http://www.icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-Belarus_rus.pdf|archive-date=2016-01-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>. On April 2016 has been signed the Protocol for the realization of the official Belarusian seat in Minsk of the International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics Network<ref>{{cite web|title=Annex ICRANet NASB Belarus|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/annex_icranet-nasb_eng.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Annex ICRANet NASB|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/annex_icranet-nasb_ru.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>. The "First ICRANet-Minsk workshop on high energy astrophysics" has been held at the ICRANet-Minsk center from 26 to 28 of April 2017<ref>{{cite web|title=First ICRANet-Minsk Workshop|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1092|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>.
===ICRANet Center in Isfahan===
The ICRANet Center in Isfahan has been established at the Isfahan University of Technology. The Protocol of cooperation<ref>{{cite web|title=Agreem ent ICRANet IUT|url=http://www.icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-IUT.pdf|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109184939/http://icranet.org/documents/agreementICRANet-IUT.pdf|archive-date=2017-01-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>, signed in 2016 by Remo Ruffini, Director of ICRANet, and Mahnoud Modarres-Hashemi, Rector of the Isfahan University of Technology, includes the promotion and development of scientific and technological research in the fields of cosmology, gravitation and relativistic astrophysics. It also includes the organization of joint international conferences and workshops, institutional exchanges for students, researchers and faculty members.
===ICRANet Centers in USA===
The present Chairman of the ICRANet Steering Committee Francis Everitt is responsible for the ICRANet Center at the [[Stanford University|Leland Stanford Junior University]]. His special activity has been the conception, development, launch and data acquisition, all the way to the elaboration of the final data analysis, of the [[NASA]] [[Gravity Probe B]] mission, one of the most complex physics experiment in space ever performed.
The first Chairman of the ICRANet Steering Committee [[Fang Lizhi|Fang Li-Zhi]] developed collaboration with the Physics Department of the [[University of Arizona]] in Tucson. The collaboration with its Astronomy Department is promoted by [[William David Arnett|David Arnett]].
== ICRANet and IRAP PhD program ==
[[File:Grafico_IRAP_PhD_students.png|thumb|Geographical distribution of IRAP PhD students]]
Since 2005 ICRANet co-organizes an International Ph.D. program in Relativistic Astrophysics — [[IRAP PhD Program|International Relativistic Astrophysics Ph.D. Program]], IRAP-PhD, the first joint PhD astrophysics program with: ASI - Italian Space Agency (Italy); Bremen University (Germany); Carl von Ossietzky University of Oldenburg (Germany); CAPES - Brazilian Federal Agency for Support and Evaluation of Graduate Education (Brazil); CBPF - Brazilian Centre for Physics Research (Brazil); CNR - National Research Council (Italy); FAPERJ -Foundation "Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro" (Brazil); ICRA - International Center for Relativistic Astrophysics (Italy); ICTP - Abdus Salam International Centre for Theoretical Physics (Italy); IHES - Institut Hautes Etudes Scientifiques (France); Indian centre for space physics (India); INFN - National Institute for Nuclear Physics (Italy); NAS RA - Armenian National Academy of Sciences (Armenia); Nice University Sophia Antipolis (France); Observatory of the Côte d'Azur (France); Rome University - “Sapienza” (Italy); Savoy University (France); TWAS - Academy of sciences for the developing world; UAM - Metropolitan Autonomous University (Mexico); UNIFE - University of Ferrara (Italy).<ref>{{cite web |title=Consortium |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=587 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2018-11-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181115195254/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=587 |archive-date=2018-11-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Among the associated centers, there are both institutes devoted to theory and others devoted to experiments and observations. In that way, PhD students can have a wider education on theoretical relativistic astrophysics and put it in practice. The official language of the IRAP PhD is English and students have also the opportunity to learn the national language of their hosting country, attending several academic courses in the partner Universities.
By 2018, 122 students were enrolled in the IRAP PhD program<ref>{{cite web |title=PhD Students |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=595 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2018-11-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181115195309/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=595 |archive-date=2018-11-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>: 1 from Albania, 4 from Argentina, 8 from Armenia, 1 from Austria, 2 from Belarus, 16 from Brazil, 5 from China, 9 from Colombia, 3 from Croatia, 5 from France, 5 from Germany 7 from India, 2 from Iran, 38 from Italy 2 from Kazakhstan, 1 from Lebanon, 1 from Mexico, 1 from Pakistan, 4 from Russia, 1 from Serbia, 1 from Sweden, 1 from Switzerland, 1 from Saudi Arabia, 2 from Taiwan and 1 from Turkey.
The IRAP-PhD program was the only European PhD program in Astrophysics awarded the Erasmus Mundus label and funded by the European Commission in 2010-2017.
== Scientific research at ICRANet == ICRANet main goals are training, education and research in the field of relativistic astrophysics, cosmology, theoretical physics and mathematical physics.
Its main activities are devoted to promote the [[Science diplomacy|international scientific co-operation]] and to carry on scientific research.
According to the 2017 ICRANet Scientific Report<ref>{{cite web |title=Annual reports |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=429&Itemid=810 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2015-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208065101/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=429&Itemid=810 |archive-date=2015-12-08 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>, the main areas of scientific research in ICRANet are: * [[Gamma ray|Gamma-rays]] and [[Neutrino]]s from Cosmic Accelerators; * Exact solutions of Einstein and Einstein-Maxwell equations; * [[Gamma-ray burst|Gamma-Ray Bursts]]; * [[Special relativity|Relativistic effects]] in Physics and Astrophysics; * [[Big data]] analysis; * [[Cosmology]] and [[Observable universe|Large Scale Structures]]; * Theoretical [[Astroparticle physics|Astroparticle Physics]]; * Generalization of the [[Kerr–Newman metric|Kerr-Newman solution]]; * [[Black hole|Black Holes]] and [[Quasar]]s; * The electron-positron pairs in physics and astrophysics; * From [[Atomic nucleus|nuclei]] to [[compact star]]s; * [[Supernova]]e; * [[Spacetime symmetries|Symmetries in General Relativity]]; * Self Gravitating Systems, Galactic Structures and Galactic Dynamics; * Interdisciplinary Complex Systems. Between 2006 and 2018, ICRANet has released over 1800 scientific publications in refereed journals such as [[Physical Review]], the [[The Astrophysical Journal|Astrophysical Journal]], [[Astronomy and Astrophysics]] etc., in its various fields of research.
'''New scientific concepts and terms introduced by ICRANet scientists:'''
[[Black hole]] (Ruffini, Wheeler 1971)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Introducing the black hole|url = http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/article/24/1/10.1063/1.3022513|journal = Physics Today|date = 2008-12-29|issn = 0031-9228|pages = 30–41|volume = 24|issue = 1|doi = 10.1063/1.3022513|first = Remo|last = Ruffini|first2 = John A.|last2 = Wheeler|bibcode = 1971PhT....24a..30R|access-date = 2015-12-03|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208142135/http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/article/24/1/10.1063/1.3022513|archive-date = 2015-12-08|dead-url = no|df = }}</ref>
[[Ergosphere]] (Rees, Ruffini, Wheeler, 1974)<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |author1=Rees M.J. |author2=Ruffini R. |author3=Wheeler J.A. |title = Black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmology: an introduction to current research |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=y6SxAAAAIAAJ |publisher = Gordon and Breach |year = 1974 |series = Topics in astrophysics and space physics |isbn = 9780677045801 }}</ref>
Pursue and plunge (Rees, Ruffini, Wheeler, 1974)<ref name=":0" />
Black hole mass formula (Christodoulou, Ruffini, 1971)<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Reversible Transformations of a Charged Black Hole|url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevD.4.3552|journal = Physical Review D|date = 1971-12-15|pages = 3552–3555|volume = 4|issue = 12|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.4.3552|first = Demetrios|last = Christodoulou|first2 = Remo|last2 = Ruffini|bibcode = 1971PhRvD...4.3552C }}</ref>
Reversible and irreversible transformations of black holes (Christodoulou, Ruffini, 1971)<ref name=":1" />
Dyadosphere (Damour, Ruffini, 1975; Preparata, Ruffini, Xue, 1998)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Quantum Electrodynamical Effects in Kerr-Newmann Geometries|url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.35.463|journal = Physical Review Letters|date = 1975-08-18|pages = 463–466|volume = 35|issue = 7|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.35.463|first = Thibaut|last = Damour|first2 = Remo|last2 = Ruffini|bibcode = 1975PhRvL..35..463D }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = The dyadosphere of black holes and gamma-ray bursts|journal = Astronomy and Astrophysics|date = 1998|pages = L87-L90|volume = 338 |bibcode = 1998A&A...338L..87P |arxiv = astro-ph/9810182 |author1=Preparata G. |author2=Ruffini R. |author3=Xue S.-S. }}</ref>
Dyadotorus (Cherubini et al., 2009)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = ${e}^{-}-<nowiki/>{e}^{+}$ pair creation by vacuum polarization around electromagnetic black holes|url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevD.79.124002|journal = Physical Review D|date = 2009-06-03|pages = 124002|volume = 79|issue = 12|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.79.124002|first = C.|last = Cherubini|first2 = A.|last2 = Geralico|first3 = J. A.|last3 = Rueda H.|first4 = R.|last4 = Ruffini|arxiv = 0905.3274 |bibcode = 2009PhRvD..79l4002C }}</ref>
Induced Gravitational Collapse (Rueda, Ruffini, 2012)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = ON THE INDUCED GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE OF A NEUTRON STAR TO A BLACK HOLE BY A TYPE Ib/c SUPERNOVA|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1088/2041-8205/758/1/L7|journal = The Astrophysical Journal|date = 2012-10-10|volume = 758|issue = 1|doi = 10.1088/2041-8205/758/1/l7|first = Jorge A.|last = Rueda|first2 = Remo|last2 = Ruffini|arxiv = 1206.1684 |bibcode = 2012ApJ...758L...7R }}</ref>
Binary-driven Hypernova (Ruffini et al., 2014)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = On binary-driven hypernovae and their nested late X-ray emission|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201423812|journal = Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume = 565|doi = 10.1051/0004-6361/201423812|first = R.|last = Ruffini|first2 = M.|last2 = Muccino|first3 = C. L.|last3 = Bianco|first4 = M.|last4 = Enderli|first5 = L.|last5 = Izzo|first6 = M.|last6 = Kovacevic|first7 = A. V.|last7 = Penacchioni|first8 = G. B.|last8 = Pisani|first9 = J. A.|last9 = Rueda|arxiv = 1404.3946 |bibcode = 2014A&A...565L..10R }}</ref>
Cosmic matrix (Ruffini et al., 2015)<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Black holes, supernovae and gamma ray bursts|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1134/S1063772915070082|journal = Astronomy Reports|date = 2015-07-09|issn = 1063-7729|pages = 591–625|volume = 59|issue = 7|doi = 10.1134/S1063772915070082|first = Remo|last = Ruffini|bibcode = 2015ARep...59..591R |arxiv = 1310.1836}}</ref>
== Other activities ==
=== International meetings ===
;The Galileo-Xu Guangqi meetings (2009-)
The Galileo-Xu Guangqi meetings<ref>{{cite web |title=Galileo - Xu Guangqi Meetings |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=400&Itemid=802 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2015-12-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208064543/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=400&Itemid=802 |archive-date=2015-12-08 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> have been created in the name of Galileo and Xu Guangqi, the collaborator of Matteo Ricci (Ri Ma Dou), generally recognized for bringing to China the works of Euclid and Galileo and for his strong commitment to the process of modernization and scientific development of China. The 1st Galileo - Xu Guangqi Meeting was held in Shanghai, China, in 2009. The 2nd Galileo - Xu Guangqi meeting took place in Hanbury Botanic Gardens (Ventimiglia, Italy) and Villa Ratti (Nice, France) in 2010. The 3rd and 4th Galileo - Xu Guangqi meetings were both held in Beijing, China, respectively in 2011 and 2015.
;Italian-Korean Symposia (1987-)
The Italian-Korean Symposia on Relativistic Astrophysics<ref>{{cite web |title=Italian-Korean Meetings |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=94&Itemid=635 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2018-11-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180902075021/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=94&Itemid=635 |archive-date=2018-09-02 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> is a series of biannual meetings, alternatively organized in Italy and in Korea since 1987. The symposia discussions cover topics in astrophysics and cosmology, such as gamma-ray bursts and compact stars, high energy cosmic rays, dark energy and dark matter, general relativity, black holes, and new physics related to cosmology.
;Stueckelberg Workshops on Relativistic Field Theories (2006-2008)
These workshops represent a one-week dialogues on Relativistic Field Theories in Curved Space, which is inspired to the work of E. C. G. Stueckelberg.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stueckelberg Workshops|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=221&Itemid=736|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208050846/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=221&Itemid=736|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Invited lectures were delivered by Professors Abhay Ashtekar, Thomas Thiemann, [[Gerard 't Hooft]] and [[Hagen Kleinert]].
;The Zeldovich Meetings (2009-)
The Zeldovich Meetings<ref>{{cite web |title=Zeldovich Meetings |url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=405&Itemid=876 |website=www.icranet.org |publisher=ICRANet |access-date=2015-12-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081756/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=405&Itemid=876 |archive-date=2015-12-08 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> are a series of international conferences held in Minsk, in honor of Ya. B. Zeldovich, one of the founders of the Soviet Atomic Bomb and the founder of the Russian School on Relativistic Astropysics, which celebrate and discuss his wide research interests, ranging from chemical physics, elementary particle and nuclear physics to astrophysics and cosmology. The 1st Zeldovich Meeting was held at the Belarusian State University in Minsk, from 20 to 23 April 2009; the 2nd Zeldovich Meeting was held at the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus from 10 to 14 March 2014, to celebrate Ya. B. Zeldovich 100th Anniversary; the 3rd Zeldovich Meeting has been held at the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus from 23 to 27 April 2018.
;Other meetings
ICRANet has also organized: * six Italian-Sino Workshops<ref>{{cite web|title=Italian-Sino Workshops|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=195&Itemid=643|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106080415/http://icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=195&Itemid=643|archive-date=2016-01-06|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> on Cosmology and Relativistic Astrophysics, held in Pescara every year from 2004 to 2009, except for the 5th Italian-Sino Workshop held in Teipei-Hualian, Taiwan, in 2008; * two ICRANet Cesar Latter meetings<ref>{{cite web|title=César Lattes Meetings|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=261&Itemid=735|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208051448/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=261&Itemid=735|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (in 2007 and 2015) and the [http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=730&Itemid=872 1st URCA meeting on Relativistic Astrophysics] in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
=== PhD schools ===
In the framework of the IRAP PhD program, ICRANet has organized several PhD schools: 11 of them have been held in Nice (France), 3 in [[Les Houches]], 1 in Ferrara (Italy), 1 in Pescara (Italy) and 1 in Beijing (China).<ref>{{cite web|title=PhD Schools|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=593|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081516/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=593|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
=== ICRANet visiting program === ICRANet has developed a program<ref>{{cite web|title=Visiting Scientists|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=87&Itemid=649|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226172822/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=87&Itemid=649|archive-date=2015-12-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> of short and long term visits for scientific collaboration.
Prominent personalities have carried out their activities at ICRA and ICRANet, among them are: Prof. Riccardo Giacconi, Nobel Prize for Physics in 2002, Gerardus 't Hooft, Dutch physicist and Nobel Prize for Physics in 1999; Steven Weinberg, Nobel Prize in 1979; Murray Gell -Mann Nobel Prize in 1969; Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar Nobel Prize in 1930; Haensch Theodor, Nobel Prize in 2001; Valeriy Ginzburg., Francis Everitt, Chairman of the Scientific Committee of ICRANet, [[Isaak Markovich Khalatnikov|Isaak Khalatnikov]], Russian physicist and former director of the [[Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics]] from 1965 to 1992; [[Roy Kerr]], New Zealand mathematician and discoverer of the "[[Kerr metric|Kerr Metric]]"; [[Thibault Damour]]; [[Demetrios Christodoulou]]; [[Hagen Kleinert]]; [[Neta Bahcall|Neta]] and [[John N. Bahcall|John]] Bachall; [[Tsvi Piran]]; [[Charles W. Misner|Charles Misner]]; [[Robert Williams (astronomer)|Robert Williams]]; [[José Gabriel Funes]]; [[Fang Lizhi|Fang Li-Zhi]]; [[Rashid Sunyaev]].
=== Weekly seminars === ICRANet co-organizes with ICRA Joint Astrophysics Seminar<ref>{{cite web|title=Seminar|url=http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=89&Itemid=781|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208050123/http://www.icranet.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=89&Itemid=781|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> at the Department of Physics of University "La Sapienza" in Rome. All institutions collaborating with ICRANet, as well as ICRANet centers, participate at those seminars.
=== Brazilian Science Data Center === The main objective of the Brazilian Science Data Center<ref>{{cite web|title=BSDC|url=http://bsdc.icranet.org/|publisher=ICRANet|accessdate=3 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208073146/http://bsdc.icranet.org/|archive-date=2015-12-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> (BSDC) is to provide data of all international space missions existing on the wavelength of X- and gamma rays, and later on the whole electromagnetic spectrum, for all the galactic and extragalactic sources of the Universe. A special attention will be paid to the achievement and the complete respect of the levels defined by the [[International Virtual Observatory Alliance]] (IVOA). In addition to these specific objectives, BSDC will promote technical seminars, annual workshops and it will assure a plan of scientific divulgation and popularization of science with the aim of the understanding of the Universe.
The BSDC is currently being implemented at CBPF, and at the [[Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul]] (UFRGS), and will be expanded to all other ICRANet centers in Brazil as well as to the other Latin-American ICRANet Centers in [[Argentina]], [[Colombia]] and [[Mexico]]: a unique coordinated continental research network planned for Latin America.
==References== <references />
==External links== * http://www.icranet.org/ * [http://www.icranet.org/documents/brochure_icranet_eng.pdf ICRANet information brochure 2015]

[[Southwest Research Institute]] | launch_mass = {{convert|494|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | dry_mass = | payload_mass = {{convert|210|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hT_wCAAAQBAJ |title=The IMAGE Mission |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]] |editor-first=J. L. |editor-last=Burch |date=2000 |isbn=978-94-010-5837-7 |doi=10.1007/978-94-011-4233-5}}{{rp|17}} | dimensions = Bus: {{convert|2.25|xx|1.52|m|ft|1|abbr=on}}
{{nowrap|Deployed: {{convert|1652|xx|71|ft|m|order=flip|abbr=on}} }} | power = 286 watts ([[GaAs]] solar arrays, Super [[NiCd]] batteries) | launch_date = {{start-date|25 March 2000, 20:34:43.929}} [[UTC]]{{cite conference |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20010084999.pdf |title=On-Orbit Performance of Autonomous Star Trackers |conference=Flight Mechanics Symposium. 19-21 June 2001. Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Maryland. |first1=V. |last1=Airapetian |first2=J. |last2=Sedlak |first3=J. |last3=Hashmall |date=2001 |id=NASA/CP-2001-209986}} | launch_rocket = [[Delta II]] 7326-9.5 #277{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/delta/d277/000325delta.html |title=The Delta 2 rocket |work=Spaceflight Now |date=25 March 2000 |accessdate=28 January 2018}} | launch_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 2|SLC-2W]] | launch_contractor = [[Boeing Launch Services]] | disposal_type = Contact lost | last_contact = {{end-date|18 December 2005, 07:39}} UTC | recovery_date = 20 January 2018 | recovery_by = Scott Tilley{{cite news |url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/219836/20180128/lost-nasa-satellite-found-after-a-decade-by-amateur-astronomer.htm |title=Lost NASA Satellite Found After A Decade By Amateur Astronomer |work=Tech Times |first=Athena |last=Chan |date=28 January 2018 |accessdate=28 January 2018}} | decay_date = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Polar orbit|Polar]] | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|29880|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.75308 | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|1000|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|46004|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 90.01° | orbit_RAAN = 192.74° | orbit_arg_periapsis = 319.86° | orbit_period = 856 minutes | orbit_epoch = 25 March 2000, 16:30:34 UTC{{cite web |url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=2000-017A |title=IMAGE - Spacecraft Orbit |work=[[NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive]] |accessdate=28 January 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://pluto.space.swri.edu/IMAGE/final_orbit.html |title=IMAGE Final Orbit Data |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |accessdate=28 January 2018}} | apsis = gee | instruments_list = {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments | acronym1 = RPI | name1 = Radio Plasma Imager | acronym2 = LENA | name2 = Low-Energy Neutral Atom Imager | acronym3 = MENA | name3 = Medium-Energy Neutral Atom Imager | acronym4 = HENA | name4 = High-Energy Neutral Atom Imager | acronym5 = FUV | name5 = Far Ultraviolet Imager | acronym6 = EUV | name6 = Extreme Ultraviolet Imager }} | programme = [[Explorers program]] | previous_mission = [[Far Ultraviolet Spectroscopic Explorer|FUSE]] | next_mission = [[High Energy Transient Explorer|HETE-2]] }} '''IMAGE''' ('''Imager for Magnetopause-to-Aurora Global Exploration''') is a [[NASA]] [[Medium Explorers program|Medium Explorers]] mission that studied the global response of the [[Earth]]'s [[magnetosphere]] to changes in the [[solar wind]]. It was believed lost but as of August 2018 might be recoverable. It was launched 25 March 2000 by a [[Delta II]] rocket from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg AFB]] on a two-year mission. Almost six years later, it unexpectedly ceased operations in December 2005 during its extended mission and was declared lost.{{cite web |url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=2000-017A |title=IMAGE - Spacecraft Details |work=[[NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive]] |access-date=25 January 2018}} The spacecraft was part of NASA's [[Sun-Earth Connections Program]], and during its run had over 400 research articles published in peer-reviewed journals using its data.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2006/jan/HQ_06030_IMAGE_quits.html |title=NASA Magnetic Field Mission Ends |publisher=NASA |first1=Erica |last1=Hupp |first2=Nancy |last2=Neal |first3=Bill |last3=Steigerwald |date=20 January 2006 |id=06-030}} It had special cameras that provided various breakthroughs in understanding the dynamics of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] around the Earth. The Principal Investigator was Jim Burch of the [[Southwest Research Institute]]. In January 2018, an amateur satellite tracker found it to be transmitting some signals back to Earth.{{cite web |url=https://skyriddles.wordpress.com/2018/01/21/nasas-long-dead-image-satellite-is-alive/ |title=NASA’s Long Dead ‘IMAGE’ Satellite is Alive! |work=Riddles in the Sky |first=Scott |last=Tilley |date=21 January 2018 |access-date=1 February 2018}} NASA made attempts to communicate with the spacecraft and determine its payload status, but has had to track down and adapt old hardware and software to the current systems.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2018/nasa-image-confirmed |title=Latest Data From IMAGE Indicates Spacecraft’s Power Functional |publisher=NASA |first1=Rob |last1=Garner |first2=Miles |last2=Hatfield |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=4 February 2018}} On 25 February, contact with IMAGE was again lost, but if reestablished, NASA may decide to fund a restarted mission.{{cite news |url=https://www.airspacemag.com/space/24_am2018-soundings-180968357 |title=NASA’s On-Again, Off-Again Satellite |work=[[Air & Space]] |first=Glenn |last=Fleishman |date=April 2018 |accessdate=22 March 2018}} ==Overview== IMAGE was the first spacecraft dedicated to imaging the Earth's [[magnetosphere]]. IMAGE was a spacecraft developed by the [[Explorers program|Medium-Class Explorers]] (MIDEX) program, and it was the first spacecraft dedicated to observing the magnetosphere of the Earth, producing comprehensive global [[Digital imaging|images]] of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] in the inner magnetosphere. The IMAGE craft was placed in a 1,000×46,000 km [[orbit]] around the Earth, with an [[inclination]] of 90° (passing over the [[geographical pole|pole]]s) and a 14.2 hour period. By acquiring images every 2 minutes in wavelengths invisible to the human eye, it allowed detailed study of the interaction of the [[solar wind]] with the magnetosphere and the magnetosphere's response during a [[magnetic storm]]. From its distant orbit, the spacecraft produced a wealth of images of the previously invisible region of space in the inner magnetosphere, exceeded all its scientific goals. A senior review in 2005, just previous to its loss, described the mission as "extremely productive",{{cite conference |url=https://image.gsfc.nasa.gov/publication/document/sr_rev_2005/2005_image_senior_review.pdf |title=Imager for Magnetopause-to-Aurora Global Exploration (IMAGE) |conference=Senior Review 2005. 5 October 2005. San Antonio, Texas. |first1=James L. |last1=Burch |first2=Thomas E. |last2=Moore |first3=James L. |last3=Green |first4=Stephen A. |last4=Fuselier |first5=Harald U. |last5=Frey |first6=Jerry |last6=Goldstein |date=2005}} having confirmed several theoretical predictions (e.g., [[plasmasphere]] plumes, pre-midnight ring-current injection, and continuous antiparallel reconnection), discovered numerous new and unanticipated phenomena (e.g., plasmasphere shoulders, subauroral proton arcs, and a secondary interstellar neutral atom stream), and answered a set of outstanding questions regarding the source region of kilometric continuum radiation, the role of solar wind pressure pulses in ionospheric outflow, and the relationship between proton and electron auroras during substorms.{{cite web |url=http://pluto.space.swri.edu/IMAGE/highlights.html |title=IMAGE Mission Highlights |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |accessdate=4 February 2018}} When the spacecraft went silent in December 2005, it had already been approved a mission extension until 2010. Costs for IMAGE are estimated at {{US$|132 million}}, including the spacecraft, instruments, launch vehicle, and ground operations. ==Payload== Its science payload consists of three suites of [[Measuring instrument|instruments]]: * [[Energetic neutral atom]] imagers (LENA, MENA, HENA) — These instruments use hydrogen, helium, and oxygen atoms in the exosphere to form images and determine the properties of their low-, medium- and high-energy parent ions. HENA, the High Energy Neutral Atom imager is a modified version of the MIMI/INCA (Magnetospheric Imaging Instrument/Ion and Neutral Camera) sensor flown on the ''[[Cassini–Huygens]]'' mission. * [[Ultraviolet astronomy|Ultraviolet imagers]] (FUV and EUV) — The Extreme Ultraviolet (EUV) imager detects light from helium atoms in Earth's [[plasmasphere]]. The Far Ultraviolet (FUV) imager employs three detectors to image the [[aurora]]s in different wavelengths and measure the distribution of different ions. * [[Astrophysical plasma|Radio Plasma]] Imager (RPI) — This instrument uses pulses of radio waves to image the entire volume of the Earth's magnetic field. With its 502 meters-long antenna, it sends out a burst of radio waves, which reflect off of clouds of charged particles between the plasmasphere's outer boundary all the way out to the boundary where the [[Earth's magnetic field]] is impacted by the [[solar wind]]. RPI also measures naturally occurring [[waves in plasmas|plasma waves]] at the spacecraft's location. The Central Instrument Data Processor (CIDP) as well as the Command & Data Handling Subsystem (main on-board computer) were built around the mission-proven [[IBM RAD6000]] [[avionics]] processors. ==Loss== On 18 December 2005, the satellite failed to make an expected contact at 16:20 UTC. An earlier contact had ended successfully at 07:40 the same day with no sign of trouble.{{cite web |url=https://image.gsfc.nasa.gov/publication/document/IMAGE_FRB_Presentation_4-21-06.pdf |title=IMAGE Failure Review Board Final Presentation |publisher=NASA |first=Mike |last=Prior |date=21 April 2006}}{{Rp|14}} Over the following days and weeks, commands were sent "blind" to reset the transmitter, change antennas, and otherwise attempt to re-establish contact with the spacecraft, but no signal (not even an unmodulated [[carrier wave]]) was received. Recovery efforts included using different [[NASA Deep Space Network|DSN]] antennas, using non-NASA ground stations in case there was some systematic DSN error, transmitting no commands for several days to trigger a 72-hour [[watchdog timer]], increasing transmit power in case the antenna was badly misaligned, and optical and radar observations of the satellite to check for debris, change in spin rate or change in orbit indicative of a collision or other damage.{{r|FRBpresent|p=16–17}} The spacecraft was also commanded to slightly increase its spin rate and asymmetrically turn on its heaters. If observed, these would indicate that it could receive commands but not transmit. Neither change was seen and analysis later indicated that the temperature change would have been undetectable.{{cite web |url=https://image.gsfc.nasa.gov/publication/document/IMAGE_FRB_Final_Report.pdf |title=IMAGE Failure Review Board Final Report: Executive Summary |publisher=NASA |date=19 September 2006}}{{Rp|9–10}} An attempt to observe the craft's temperature to determine if it was completely dead or consuming the power expected in [[Safe mode (spacecraft)|safe mode]] was inconclusive.{{r|FRBreport|p=10–11}} A careful failure analysis revealed that, among plausible causes for an abrupt bidirectional loss of communication, the [[Solid-state electronics|Solid State]] [[Electric power conversion|Power Converter]] (SSPC) for the transponder had, among its features, an "instant trip" shutdown in response to a high-current ({{val|100|ul=A}}) [[short circuit]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o_yvbP5JMa0C&pg=PA57 |title=Software and System Safety: Accidents, Incidents, and Lessons Learned |publisher=[[AuthorHouse]] |last=Hardy |first=Terry L. |page=57 |date=16 April 2012 |isbn=978-1-4685-7470-8}} Critically, such a shutdown was ''not'' reported in the power supply's telemetry output and this lack was not documented. The non-reporting was by design, as in non-spacecraft applications it would be dangerous to automatically restore power in such an event, while in a spacecraft failure to receive means loss of mission so there is nothing more to lose by trying. Because it was undocumented the spacecraft's hardware and software had no provision for attempting to reset the SSPC if it reported good status.{{r|FRBreport|p=13}} This would result in the observed symptoms: no radio communication with an apparently undamaged spacecraft.{{r|FRBreport|p=1,12–13,22,29–31}} Although such a short circuit would be almost impossible without fatal damage to the spacecraft, the shutdown could be falsely triggered by a radiation-induced [[single event upset]].{{r|FRBreport|p=1,30–31}} It could be simply fixed by power-cycling the supply, but the spacecraft design left no way to send such a command, nor was one built in. The same problem with the same model of power supply had affected the [[EO-1]] and [[WMAP]] satellites (launched after IMAGE),{{r|FRBreport|p=1,13}} but they were able to recover. In January 2006, NASA declared the mission over, declaring that "Preliminary analysis indicated the craft's power supply subsystems failed, rendering it lifeless." Despite this, they continued to try and establish contact. In early 2006, NASA convened a board of experts to figure out what went wrong. After several months they created a report in which they theorized that IMAGE had tripped a power breaker and might fix itself.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2018/01/31/nasa-lost-contact-with-a-satellite-12-years-ago-an-amateur-just-found-its-signal/ |title=NASA lost contact with a satellite 12 years ago. An amateur just found its signal. |work=[[The Washington Post]] |last1=Selk |first1=Avi |accessdate=1 February 2018 |date=31 January 2018}} It was hoped that an [[eclipse]] when the spacecraft passed through the Earth's shadow in October 2007 would result in a sufficiently deep supply voltage sag that it would trigger a total bus reset, which would cause a power cycle of the suspect supply.{{r|FRBreport|p=14–18}} However, attempts to contact the craft after this eclipse were not successful.{{r|alive}} ==Recovery efforts== On 20 January 2018, IMAGE was found by Canadian radio amateur [[Satellite watching|and satellite tracker]] Scott Tilley to be broadcasting, and he reported it to NASA. He had been scanning the [[S-band]] (microwaves) in the hopes of finding the [[Zuma (satellite)|Zuma]] satellite.{{r|alive}}{{cite news |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/01/amateur-astronomer-discovers-revived-nasa-satellite |title=Amateur astronomer discovers a revived NASA satellite |work=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |last1=Voosen |first1=Paul |date=26 January 2018 |accessdate=28 January 2018}} On 24 January 2018, Richard Burley of NASA reported that they were trying to establish communication with the satellite using the [[NASA Deep Space Network]].{{cite mailing list |url=http://www.satobs.org/seesat/Jan-2018/0192.html |title=Re: NASA IMAGE - Returns from the Dead |mailing-list=SeeSat-L |last=Burley |first=Richard J. |via=Scott Tilley |date=24 January 2018 |language=en}} Two days later, Burley reported that engineers at [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] successfully acquired the signal,{{cite mailing list |url=http://www.satobs.org/seesat/Jan-2018/0203.html |title=Fwd: 20180126 Break-Break-Break IMAGE Status |mailing-list=SeeSat-L |last=Burley |first=Richard J. |via=Scott Tilley |date=26 January 2018 |language=en}} and confirmed on 30 January 2018 that IMAGE is the source.{{r|NASA IMAGE Updates}} It is not known when the satellite started broadcasting, but re-examination of old data recorded by Tilley and fellow satellite tracker Cees Bassa showed transmissions from the same satellite in October 2016 and May 2017.{{cite web |url=https://skyriddles.wordpress.com/2018/01/30/when-did-image-return-from-the-dead/ |title=When did IMAGE return from the dead? |work=Riddles in the Sky |first=Cees |last=Bassa |date=30 January 2018 |access-date=9 February 2018}} Bassa hypothesized that while the 2007 eclipse did not manage to reset the satellite, another one did the trick, probably sometime between 2014 and 2016.{{r|12years}} On 8 February 2018, NASA published a detailed account of the IMAGE satellite's recovery.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2018/a-detailed-timeline-of-the-image-mission-recovery |title=A Detailed Timeline of The IMAGE Mission Recovery |last=Blumberg |first=Sara |date=8 February 2018 |work=NASA |access-date=10 February 2018 |language=en}} The satellite was transmitting data beyond simple telemetry, indicating that some of its six onboard instruments were still active.{{cite news |url=https://gizmodo.com/over-a-decade-later-nasas-long-dead-image-satellite-ma-1822479068 |title=Over a Decade Later, NASA's Long-Dead IMAGE Satellite May Have Come Back to Life |work=Gizmodo |first=Tom |last=McKay |date=27 January 2018}} NASA engineers are attempting to determine the satellite's status,{{r|NASA IMAGE Updates}} but since the software and hardware type used in the IMAGE Mission Operations Center have been discarded and no longer exist, they are in the process of adapting old software and databases to their modern systems and track down replacement hardware.{{r|NASA IMAGE Updates}}{{cite news |url=https://www.space.com/39534-amateur-astronomer-finds-lost-nasa-satellite.html |title=Signal Detected by Amateur Astronomer Came from Long-Lost Satellite, NASA Confirms |work=Space.com |first=Calla |last=Cofield |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=4 February 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://newatlas.com/nasa-image-satellite-recovery/53174/ |title=NASA to attempt recovery of lost IMAGE satellite |work=New Atlas |first=David |last=Szondy |date=30 January 2018}} On 25 February 2018, NASA again lost contact with the satellite, but not in the same manner it did in 2005. Richard Burley, former IMAGE mission director, stated that he believes there is an issue with IMAGE's spin axis in relation to its medium-gain antenna placement. If NASA can regain control of the spacecraft, and the status of data and ground systems can be assessed, it will decide if it can fund a mission restart. On 4 March 2018, the Applied Physics Laboratory at Johns Hopkins University reported detecting the signal from the satellite, but it was too faint to lock onto.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2018/nasa-image-confirmed |title=Latest Updates from NASA on IMAGE Recovery |publisher=NASA |first=Miles |last=Hatfield |accessdate=12 October 2018}} On 9 May 2018, Scott Tilley again detected a strong signal from IMAGE. Hours later NASA and APL engineers had locked onto the signal and were receiving telemetry. Commands were transmitted to IMAGE, but for unknown reasons the spacecraft only acknowledged receipt of a fraction of those commands. On 28 August 2018 NASA announced that the IMAGE team had stopped receiving any signals from the satellite, as previously happened in spring, and would continue to try sending commands.{{cite news |url=https://www.popularmechanics.com/space/satellites/a22877021/nasa-already-lost-the-satellite-it-just-found-in-january/ |title=NASA Already Lost the Satellite It Just Found in January |work=Popular Mechanics |last1=Thompson |first1=Avery |date=30 August 2018 |accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==Gallery== Aurora australis 20050911.jpg|False-colour image of ultraviolet [[aurora|aurora australis]] Earth plasmasphere in EUV.jpg|Picture of the ultraviolet glow from relatively cold plasma surrounding Earth Aurora as seen by IMAGE.PNG|An [[aurora]] as seen by the Far-[[Ultraviolet]] (FUV) imager UV Proton Aurora IMAGE composite light.jpg|False-colour image of ultraviolet auroral lights from particles excited by collisions with protons, so called proton aurorae IMAGE (Explorer 78).jpg|IMAGE in preparation ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[[Galaxy 15]] *[[List of plasma physics articles]] *[[Magnetospheric Multiscale Mission]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|IMAGE (spacecraft)}} * [https://image.gsfc.nasa.gov/ IMAGE website] by NASA{{\}}Goddard * [http://pluto.space.swri.edu/IMAGE/ IMAGE website] by the Southwest Research Institute * {{YouTube |2254bCb5CRg |NASA Connect - IMAGE Magnetosphere Satellite}} * {{YouTube |KUDwgOLqUdo |NASA IMAGE Satellite Views of Oxygen in the Earth's Magnetosphere}} {{Explorers program}} {{Magnetospherics}} {{Orbital launches in 2000}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Image}} [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:Explorers program (NASA)]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2000]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Delta II rockets]]

{{Technical|date=October 2010}} Angular size of patch in atmosphere over which electromagnetic waves in the same plane stay parallel. The patch size inversely affects the [[Fried_parameter|Fried Parameter]] and the resolution of optical telescopes. Adaptive [[optical telescope|optical telescopes]] uses a bright light source to identify the properties of the patch in the line of sight to the object of interest to correct for seeing effects. ==See also== [[Astronomical seeing]]
[[optical resolution]] ==References== Birney S, Gonzalez G, Oesper D "observational astronomy" second edition, Cambridge university press, 2006 [[Category:Astronomical imaging]] [[Category:Observational astronomy]] [[Category:Speckle imaging]] {{astronomy-stub}}

revision.text:
In [[crystal growth]], a '''Knudsen cell''' is an [[effusion]] [[evaporator]] source for relatively low partial pressure elementary sources (e.g. Ga, Al, Hg, As). Because it is easy to control the temperature of the evaporating material in Knudsen cells, they are commonly used in [[molecular-beam epitaxy]].
==Development== The Knudsen effusion cell was developed by [[Martin Knudsen]] (1871-1949). A typical Knudsen cell contains a [[crucible]] (made of [[pyrolytic]] [[boron nitride]], [[quartz]], [[tungsten]] or [[graphite]]), heating filaments (often made of metal [[tantalum]]), [[water cooling]] system, [[heat shield]]s, and an [[:wikt:orifice|orifice]] shutter.
==Vapor pressure measurement== The Knudsen cell is used to measure the [[vapor pressure]]s of a solid with very low vapor pressure. Such a solid forms a vapor at low pressure by [[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublimation]]. The vapor slowly effuses through the pinhole, and the loss of mass is proportional to the vapor pressure and can be used to determine this pressure.<ref name=Atk>[[Peter Atkins]] and Julio de Paula, ''Physical Chemistry'' (8th ed., W.H.Freeman 2006) p.756 {{ISBN|0-7167-8759-8}}</ref> The [[heat of sublimation]] can also be determined by measuring the vapor pressure as a function of temperature, using the [[Clausius–Clapeyron relation]].<ref>Drago, R.S. ''Physical Methods in Chemistry'' (W.B.Saunders 1977) p.563 {{ISBN|0-7216-3184-3}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{science-stub}} [[Category:Crystallography]] [[Category:Semiconductor growth]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{notability|date=October 2012}} {{primary sources|date=October 2012}} The '''U.S. LHC Accelerator Research Program''' (LARP) coordinates [[research and development]] in the United States related to the [[Large Hadron Collider]] at [[CERN]].<ref>http://www.uslarp.org/</ref> Among other things, the program has contributed important instrumentation for initial LHC operation<ref>http://accelconf.web.cern.ch/Accelconf/p07/PAPERS/THXC01.PDF</ref><ref>http://spms.kek.jp/pls/ipac2010/JACoW.view_abstract?abs_id=3518</ref><ref>http://spms.kek.jp/pls/ipac2010/JACoW.view_abstract?abs_id=2884</ref><ref>http://accelconf.web.cern.ch/Accelconf/p07/PAPERS/FRPMN068.PDF</ref> and is leading the way for the development of [[superconducting]] magnets based on [[Niobium-tin]], which are proposed for future LHC upgrades.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eucard.web.cern.ch/eucard/news/newsletters/issue04/article4.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116174029/http://eucard.web.cern.ch/EuCARD/news/newsletters/issue04/article4.html |archivedate=2010-11-16 |df= }}</ref>
LARP was first proposed in 2003 as a collaboration between the [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]], the [[Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory]], and the [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]].<ref>[http://www.uslarp.org/LARP_Proposal.pdf R. Kephart ''et al'', "The U.S. LHC Accelerator Research Program: A Proposal"]</ref> The [[SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory]] joined the program shortly thereafter.<ref>[http://www.slidefinder.net/L/LHC_Accelerator_Research/SLAC/1152290|T. Markiewicz, "LHC Accelerator Research at SLAC"]</ref>
LARP is funded through the [[US Department of Energy]]. The total funding in Fiscal Year 2010 was $12.39M, distributed among the four labs involved.<ref>[http://www.cfo.doe.gov/budget/10budget/Content/Volumes/Volume4.pdf DOE FY10 Science Budget, p. 245]</ref>
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.uslarp.org/ LARP website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lhc Accelerator Research Program}} [[Category:Large Hadron Collider]] [[Category:Particle accelerators]] [[Category:Research projects]]

{{external links|date=August 2015}}
'''[[RNA-Seq]]''' <ref name=Wang2009>{{cite journal | journal=Nature Reviews Genetics |volume=10| year=2009 | author=Wang, Z., Gerstein, M., & Snyder, M. | pmid=19015660| title=RNA-Seq: a revolutionary tool for transcriptomics|doi=10.1038/nrg2484| issue=1| pages=57–63 | pmc=2949280}}</ref> <ref name=Kimberley2015>{{cite journal|journal= Cold Spring Harb Protoc|volume=2015| year=2015|author1=Kimberly R. Kukurba |author2=Stephen B. Montgomery |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=25870306| title = RNA Sequencing and Analysis |url=http://cshprotocols.cshlp.org/content/early/2015/04/11/pdb.top084970.abstract |doi=10.1101/pdb.top084970| issue=11| pages=951–69 | pmc=4863231}}</ref><ref name=Ana2016>{{cite journal|journal= Genome Biology |volume=17| year=2016|author1=Ana Conesa |author2=Pedro Madrigal |author3=Sonia Tarazona |author4=David Gomez-Cabrero |author5=Alejandra Cervera |author6=Andrew McPherson |author7=Michał Wojciech Szcześniak |author8=Daniel J. Gaffney |author9=Laura L. Elo |author10=Xuegong Zhang |author11=Ali Mortazavi | pmid=26813401|pmc=4728800| title= A survey of best practices for RNA-seq data analysis|url= |doi=10.1186/s13059-016-0881-8| issue=13| pages=13}}</ref> is a technique<ref name=CA2012>{{cite journal|journal= Canadian Bioinformatics Workshops |volume=| year=2012| pmid=| title = RNA Sequencing and analysis|url= http://bioinformatics.ca//files/public/BiCG_2012_Module7.pdf|doi= | issue=| pages=}}</ref> that allows [[transcriptome]] studies (see also [[Transcriptomics technologies]]) based on [[next-generation sequencing]] technologies. This technique is largely dependent on [[bioinformatics]] tools developed to support the different steps of the process. Here are listed some of the principal tools commonly employed and links to some important web resources.
<!--the corresponding high-quality-assembled reference genome available or not <ref name=Geng2011>{{cite journal | journal= Science China Life Sciences | volume=54 | issue=12 | pages=1121–1128 | date=December 2011 |vauthors=Geng C, Charles W, TieLiu S | title=Overview of available methods for diverse RNA-Seq data analyses | pmid=22227904| pmid=22227904 | doi=10.1007/s11427-011-4255-x}}</ref>-->
==Design== Design is a fundamental step of a particular RNA-Seq experiment. Some important questions like sequencing depth/coverage or how many biological or technical replicates must be carefully considered.
