Design review.<ref name=Alicia2017>{{cite journal|journal= Briefings in Bioinformatics |volume=19| year=2017| author= Alicia Poplawski, Harald Binder | pmid=28100468| title=Feasibility of sample size calculation for RNA-seq studies |doi= 10.1093/bib/bbw144| issue=4|pages=713–720}}</ref> *'''PROPER''' ''[https://rdrr.io/bioc/PROPER/ PROPER]'': PROspective Power Evaluation for RNAseq. *'''RNAtor''' ''[https://github.com/binaypanda/RNAtor RNAtor]'' Android Application to calculate optimal parameters for popular tools and kits available for DNA sequencing projects. *'''Scotty''' ''[http://scotty.genetics.utah.edu/ Scotty]'': a web tool for designing RNA-Seq experiments to measure differential gene expression. *'''ssizeRNA''' ''[https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ssizeRNA/index.html ssizeRNA]'': Sample Size Calculation for RNA-Seq Experimental Design.
==Quality control, trimming, error correction and pre-processing of data== Quality assessment of raw data <ref name=Sheng2016>{{cite journal|journal= Brief Funct Genomics |volume=16| year=2016|vauthors=Sheng Q, Vickers K, Zhao S, Wang J, Samuels DC, Koues O, Shyr Y, Guo Y | title= Multi-perspective quality control of Illumina RNA sequencing data analysis |pmid= 27687708|pmc=5860075|doi= 10.1093/bfgp/elw035| issue=4| pages=1–11}}</ref> is the first step of the bioinformatics pipeline of RNA-Seq. Often, is necessary to filter data, removing low quality sequences or bases (trimming), adapters, contaminations, overrepresented sequences or correcting errors to assure a coherent final result. ''[https://sequencing.qcfail.com/ Articles about common next-generation sequencing problems]''.
===Quality control=== *'''AfterQC''' ''[https://github.com/OpenGene/AfterQC AfterQC]'' - Automatic Filtering, Trimming, Error Removing and Quality Control for fastq data. *'''dupRadar''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/dupRadar.html dupRadar]''.<ref name=Sayols2015>{{cite journal|journal= |volume=| year=2015|vauthors=Sayols S, Klein H |lastauthoramp=yes |pmid=| title = dupRadar: Assessment of duplication rates in RNA-Seq datasets. R package version 1.1.0. |url= http://bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/dupRadar.html|doi=| issue=| pages=}}</ref> An R package which provides functions for plotting and analyzing the duplication rates dependent on the expression levels. *'''FastQC''' ''[http://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/fastqc/ FastQC]'' is a quality control tool for high-throughput sequence data ([[Babraham Institute]]) and is developed in [[Java (programming language)|Java]]. Import of data is possible from [[FASTQ format|FastQ]] files, BAM or SAM format. This tool provides an overview to inform about problematic areas, summary graphs and tables to rapid assessment of data. Results are presented in [[HTML]] permanent reports. FastQC can be run as a stand-alone application or it can be integrated into a larger pipeline solution. *'''fastqp''' ''[https://github.com/mdshw5/fastqp fastqp]''. Simple FASTQ quality assessment using Python. *'''Kraken''' ''[http://www.ebi.ac.uk/research/enright/software/kraken kraken]'':<ref name=Matthew2013>{{cite journal|journal= Methods |volume=63| year=2013 |author1=Matthew P.A. Davis |author2=Stijn van Dongen |author3=Cei Abreu-Goodger |author4=Nenad Bartonicek |author5=Anton J. Enright | pmid=23816787| title= Kraken: A set of tools for quality control and analysis of high-throughput sequence data|doi= 10.1016/j.ymeth.2013.06.027| issue=1| pages=41–49 | pmc=3991327}}</ref> A set of tools for quality control and analysis of high-throughput sequence data. *'''HTSeq''' ''[http://www-huber.embl.de/users/anders/HTSeq/doc/qa.html#qa HTSeq]''.<ref name=So2015>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=31| year=2015 |author1=S Anders |author2=T P Pyl |author3=W Huber | pmid=25260700| title= HTSeq — A Python framework to work with high-throughput sequencing data.|url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/31/2/166|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btu638| issue=2| pages=166–169 | pmc=4287950}}</ref> The Python script htseq-qa takes a file with sequencing reads (either raw or aligned reads) and produces a PDF file with useful plots to assess the technical quality of a run. *'''mRIN''' ''[http://zhanglab.c2b2.columbia.edu/index.php/MRIN mRIN]''<ref name=Feng2015>{{cite journal|journal= Nature Communications |volume=6| year=2015| author = Feng, H., Zhang, X., Zhang, C. | pmid=26234653| title = mRIN for direct assessment of genome-wide and gene-specific mRNA integrity from large-scale RNA sequencing data |url= http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150803/ncomms8816/full/ncomms8816.html|doi=10.1038/ncomms8816| issue=7816| pages= 7816| pmc=4523900|bibcode=2015NatCo...6E7816F}}</ref> - Assessing mRNA integrity directly from RNA-Seq data. *'''MultiQC''' [http://multiqc.info/ ''MultiQC'']<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ewels|first=Philip|last2=Magnusson|first2=Måns|last3=Lundin|first3=Sverker|last4=Käller|first4=Max|date=2016-06-16|title=MultiQC: summarize analysis results for multiple tools and samples in a single report|url=http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2016/06/23/bioinformatics.btw354|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=32|issue=19|language=en|pages=3047–8|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btw354|issn=1367-4803|pmid=27312411|pmc=5039924}}</ref> - Aggregate and visualise results from numerous tools ''(FastQC, HTSeq, RSeQC, Tophat, STAR, others..)'' across all samples into a single report. *'''NGSQC''' ''[http://brainarray.mbni.med.umich.edu/brainarray/ngsqc/ NGSQC]'': cross-platform quality analysis pipeline for deep sequencing data. *'''NGS QC Toolkit''' ''[http://www.nipgr.res.in/ngsqctoolkit.html NGS QC Toolkit]'' A toolkit for the quality control (QC) of next generation sequencing (NGS) data. The toolkit comprises user-friendly stand alone tools for quality control of the sequence data generated using Illumina and Roche 454 platforms with detailed results in the form of tables and graphs, and filtering of high-quality sequence data. It also includes few other tools, which are helpful in NGS data quality control and analysis. *'''PRINSEQ''' ''[http://prinseq.sourceforge.net/manual.html PRINSEQ]'' is a tool that generates summary statistics of sequence and quality data and that is used to filter, reformat and trim next-generation sequence data. It is particular designed for 454/Roche data, but can also be used for other types of sequence. *'''QC-Chain''' ''[http://www.computationalbioenergy.org/qc-chain.html QC-Chain]'' is a package of quality control tools for next generation sequencing (NGS) data, consisting of both raw reads quality evaluation and de novo contamination screening, which could identify all possible contamination sequences. *'''QC3''' ''[https://github.com/slzhao/QC3 QC3]'' a quality control tool designed for DNA sequencing data for raw data, alignment, and variant calling. *'''qrqc''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/2.8/bioc/html/qrqc.html qrqc]''. Quickly scans reads and gathers statistics on base and quality frequencies, read length, and frequent sequences. Produces graphical output of statistics for use in quality control pipelines, and an optional HTML quality report. S4 SequenceSummary objects allow specific tests and functionality to be written around the data collected. *'''RNA-SeQC''' ''[http://www.broadinstitute.org/cancer/cga/rna-seqc RNA-SeQC]''<ref name=Deluca2012>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=28| year=2012 |vauthors=Deluca DS, Levin JZ, Sivachenko A, Fennell T, Nazaire MD, Williams C, Reich M, Winckler W, Getz G | pmid=22539670| title= RNA-SeQC: RNA-seq metrics for quality control and process optimization |url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/11/1530.long|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts196| issue=11| pages=1530–1532 | pmc=3356847}}</ref> is a tool with application in experiment design, process optimization and quality control before computational analysis. Essentially, provides three types of quality control: read counts (such as duplicate reads, mapped reads and mapped unique reads, rRNA reads, transcript-annotated reads, strand specificity), coverage (like mean coverage, mean coefficient of variation, 5’/3’ coverage, gaps in coverage, GC bias) and expression correlation (the tool provides RPKM-based estimation of expression levels). RNA-SeQC is implemented in Java and is not required installation, however can be run using the ''[http://genepattern.org GenePattern]'' web interface. The input could be one or more BAM files. HTML reports are generated as output. *'''RSeQC''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/rseqc/ RSeQC]''<ref name=Wang2012>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=28| year=2012 | author= Wang, L., Wang, S., & Li, W. | pmid=22743226| title= RSeQC: Quality Control of RNA-seq experiments.|url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/16/2184.long|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts356| issue=16| pages=2184–2185}}</ref> analyzes diverse aspects of RNA-Seq experiments: sequence quality, sequencing depth, strand specificity, GC bias, read distribution over the genome structure and coverage uniformity. The input can be SAM, BAM, FASTA, BED files or Chromosome size file (two-column, plain text file). Visualization can be performed by genome browsers like UCSC, IGB and IGV. However, R scripts can also be used to visualization. *'''SAMStat''' ''[http://samstat.sourceforge.net/ SAMStat]'' <ref name=Lassman2010>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=27| year=2010 |vauthors=Lassmann T, Hayashizaki Y, Daub CO | title= SAMStat: monitoring biases in next generation sequencing data.|pmid= 21088025|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btq614 | issue=1| pages=130–131 | pmc=3008642}}</ref> identifies problems and reports several statistics at different phases of the process. This tool evaluates unmapped, poorly and accurately mapped sequences independently to infer possible causes of poor mapping. *'''SolexaQA''' ''[http://solexaqa.sourceforge.net/ SolexaQA]'' calculates sequence quality statistics and creates visual representations of data quality for second-generation sequencing data. Originally developed for the Illumina system (historically known as “Solexa”), SolexaQA now also supports Ion Torrent and 454 data. *'''Trim galore!''' ''[http://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_galore/ Trim_galore]'' is a wrapper script to automate quality and adapter trimming as well as quality control, with some added functionality to remove biased methylation positions for RRBS sequence files (for directional, non-directional (or paired-end) sequencing).
===Improving the quality=== Improvement of the RNA-Seq quality, correcting the bias is a complex subject.<ref name=Nicholas2014>{{cite journal|journal= Genome Biology |volume=15| year=2014 |author1=Nicholas F Lahens |author2=Ibrahim Halil Kavakli |author3=Ray Zhang |author4=Katharina Hayer |author5=Michael B Black |author6=Hannah Dueck |author7=Angel Pizarro |author8=Junhyong Kim |author9=Rafael Irizarry |author10=Russell S Thomas |author11=Gregory R Grant |author12=John B Hogenesch | pmid=24981968| title= IVT-seq reveals extreme bias in RNA sequencing|url= http://genomebiology.com/2014/15/6/R86|doi=10.1186/gb-2014-15-6-r86| issue=6| pages=R86 | pmc=4197826}}</ref><ref name=Li2014>{{cite journal|journal= Nature Biotechnology |volume=32| year=2014 |vauthors=Li S, Łabaj PP, Zumbo P, Sykacek P, Shi W, Shi L, Phan J, Wu PY, Wang M, Wang C, Thierry-Mieg D, Thierry-Mieg J, Kreil DP, Mason CE | pmid=25150837| title =Detecting and correcting systematic variation in large-scale RNA sequencing data|doi=10.1038/nbt.3000| issue=9| pages=888–895 | pmc=4160374}}</ref> Each RNA-Seq protocol introduces specific type of bias, each step of the process (such as the sequencing technology used) is susceptible to generate some sort of noise or type of error. Furthermore, even the species under investigation and the biological context of the samples are able to influence the results and introduce some kind of bias. Many sources of bias were already reported – GC content and PCR enrichment,<ref name=Benjamini2012>{{cite journal|journal= Nucleic Acids Res |volume=40| year=2014 |vauthors=Benjamini Y, Speed TP | pmid=22323520| title= Summarizing and correcting the GC content bias in high-throughput sequencing .|doi= 10.1093/nar/gks001 | issue=10| pages=e72 | pmc=3378858}}</ref><ref name=Aird11>{{cite journal|journal= Genome Biol |volume=12| year=2011 |vauthors=Aird D, Ross MG, Chen WS, Danielsson M, Fennell T, Russ C, Jaffe DB, Nusbaum C, Gnirke A | pmid=21338519| title =Analyzing and minimizing PCR amplification bias in Illumina sequencing libraries.|url=http://genomebiology.com/2011/12/2/R18|doi=10.1186/gb-2011-12-2-r18| issue=2| pages=888–895 | pmc=3188800}}</ref> rRNA depletion,<ref name=Adiconis2013>{{cite journal|journal= Nat Methods |volume=10| year=2013 |vauthors=Adiconis X, Borges-Rivera D, Satija R, DeLuca DS, Busby MA, Berlin AM, Sivachenko A, Thompson DA, Wysoker A, Fennell T, Gnirke A, Pochet N, Regev A, Levin JZ | pmid=23685885| title= Comparative analysis of RNA sequencing methods for degraded or low-input samples.|doi= 10.1038/nmeth.2483 | issue=7| pages=623–629 | pmc=3821180}}</ref> errors produced during sequencing,<ref name=Nakamura2011>{{cite journal|journal= Nucleic Acids Res |volume=39| year=2011 |vauthors=Nakamura K, Oshima T, Morimoto T, Ikeda S, Yoshikawa H, Shiwa Y, Ishikawa S, Linak MC, Hirai A, Takahashi H, Altaf-Ul-Amin M, Ogasawara N, Kanaya S | pmid=21576222| title = Sequence-specific error profile of Illumina sequencers. |doi= 10.1093/nar/gkr344| issue=13| pages=e90 | pmc=3141275}}</ref> priming of reverse transcription caused by random hexamers.<ref name=Hansen2010>{{cite journal|journal= Nucleic Acids Res |volume=38| year=2010 |vauthors=Hansen KD, Brenner SE, Dudoit S | pmid=20395217| title = Biases in Illumina transcriptome sequencing caused by random hexamer priming|url= http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2010/04/14/nar.gkq224 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkq224 | issue=12| pages=e131 | pmc=2896536}}</ref>
Different tools were developed to attempt to solve each of the detected errors.
====Trimming and adapters removal==== *'''BBDuk''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/ BBDuk]''. Ultrafast, multithreaded tool to trim adapters and filter or mask contaminants based on kmer-matching, allowing a hamming- or edit-distance, as well as degenerate bases. Also performs optimal quality-trimming and filtering, format conversion, contaminant concentration reporting, gc-filtering, length-filtering, entropy-filtering, chastity-filtering, and generates text histograms for most operations. Interconverts between fastq, fasta, sam, scarf, interleaved and 2-file paired, gzipped, bzipped, ASCII-33 and ASCII-64. Keeps pairs together. Open-source, written in pure Java; supports all platforms with no recompilation and no other dependencies. *'''clean_reads''' ''[http://bioinf.comav.upv.es/clean_reads/ clean_reads]'' cleans NGS (Sanger, 454, Illumina and solid) reads. It can trim bad quality regions, adaptors, vectors, and regular expressions. It also filters out the reads that do not meet a minimum quality criteria based on the sequence length and the mean quality. *'''condetri'''<ref name=condetri>{{cite journal|last1=Smeds|first1=Linnéa|last2=Künstner|first2=Axel|last3=Donlin|first3=Maureen J.|title=ConDeTri - A Content Dependent Read Trimmer for Illumina Data|journal=PLoS ONE|date=19 October 2011|volume=6|issue=10|pages=e26314|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0026314|pmid=22039460|pmc=3198461|bibcode=2011PLoSO...626314S}}</ref> ''[https://code.google.com/p/condetri/ condetri]'' is a method for content dependent read trimming for Illumina data using quality scores of each base individually. It is independent from sequencing coverage and user interaction. The main focus of the implementation is on usability and to incorporate read trimming in next-generation sequencing data processing and analysis pipelines. It can process single-end and paired-end sequencing data of arbitrary length. *'''cutadapt''' <ref name=cutadapt>{{cite journal|last1=Martin|first1=Marcel|title=Cutadapt removes adapter sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads|journal=EMBnet.journal|date=2 May 2011|volume=17|issue=1|pages=10|doi=10.14806/ej.17.1.200}}</ref> ''[https://cutadapt.readthedocs.org/en/stable/ cutadapt]'' removes adapter sequences from next-generation sequencing data (Illumina, SOLiD and 454). It is used especially when the read length of the sequencing machine is longer than the sequenced molecule, like the microRNA case. *'''Deconseq''' ''[http://deconseq.sourceforge.net/ Deconseq]''. Detect and remove contaminations from sequence data. *'''Erne-Filter''' <ref name="erne-bs5">{{Cite book|last1=Spandow|first1=O|last2=Hellström|first2=S|last3=Schmidt|first3=SH|last4=De Paoli|first4=Emanuale|last5=Policriti|first5=Alberto|title=ERNE-BS5: Aligning BS-treated Sequences by Multiple Hits on a 5-letters Alphabet|journal=Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology and Biomedicine|date=2012|volume=12|pages=12–19|doi=10.1145/2382936.2382938|isbn=9781450316705}}</ref> ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/erne/ Erne]'' is a short string alignment package whose goal is to provide an all-inclusive set of tools to handle short (NGS-like) reads. ERNE comprises ERNE-FILTER (read trimming and continamination filtering), ERNE-MAP (core alignment tool/algorithm), ERNE-BS5 (bisulfite treated reads aligner), and ERNE-PMAP/ERNE-PBS5 (distributed versions of the aligners). *'''FastqMcf''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/ea-utils/wiki/FastqMcf FastqMcf]''. Fastq-mcf attempts to: Detect & remove sequencing adapters and primers; Detect limited skewing at the ends of reads and clip; Detect poor quality at the ends of reads and clip; Detect Ns, and remove from ends; Remove reads with CASAVA 'Y' flag (purity filtering); Discard sequences that are too short after all of the above; Keep multiple mate-reads in sync while doing all of the above. *'''FASTX''' ''[http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit/ FASTX]'' Toolkit is a set of command line tools to manipulate reads in files [[FASTA]] or [[FASTQ format|FASTQ]] format. These commands make possible preprocess the files before mapping with tools like [[BowTie (aligner)|Bowtie]]. Some of the tasks allowed are: conversion from FASTQ to FASTA format, information about statistics of quality, removing sequencing adapters, filtering and cutting sequences based on quality or conversion [[DNA]]/[[RNA]]. *'''Flexbar''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/flexbar/ Flexbar]'' performs removal of adapter sequences, trimming and filtering features. *'''FreClu''' ''[http://mlab.cb.k.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~quwei/DeNovoShortReadClustering/ FreClu]'' improves overall alignment accuracy performing sequencing-error correction by trimming short reads, based on a clustering methodology. *'''htSeqTools''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.9/bioc/html/htSeqTools.html htSeqTools]'' is a Bioconductor package able to perform quality control, processing of data and visualization. htSeqTools makes possible visualize sample correlations, to remove over-amplification artifacts, to assess enrichment efficiency, to correct strand bias and visualize hits. *'''NxTrim''' ''[https://github.com/sequencing/NxTrim NxTrim]''. Adapter trimming and virtual library creation routine for Illumina Nextera Mate Pair libraries. *'''PRINSEQ'''<ref name=prinseq>{{cite journal|last1=Schmieder|first1=R.|last2=Edwards|first2=R.|title=Quality control and preprocessing of metagenomic datasets|journal=Bioinformatics|date=28 January 2011|volume=27|issue=6|pages=863–864|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btr026|pmid=21278185|pmc=3051327}}</ref> ''[http://edwards.sdsu.edu/cgi-bin/prinseq/prinseq.cgi PRINSEQ]'' generates statistics of your sequence data for sequence length, GC content, quality scores, n-plicates, complexity, tag sequences, poly-A/T tails, odds ratios. Filter the data, reformat and trim sequences. *'''Sabre''' ''[https://github.com/najoshi/sabre sabre]''. A barcode demultiplexing and trimming tool for FastQ files. *'''Scythe''' ''[https://github.com/vsbuffalo/scythe scythe]''. A 3'-end adapter contaminant trimmer. *'''SEECER''' ''[http://sb.cs.cmu.edu/ seecer]'' SEECER is a sequencing error correction algorithm for RNA-seq data sets. It takes the raw read sequences produced by a next generation sequencing platform like machines from Illumina or Roche. SEECER removes mismatch and indel errors from the raw reads and significantly improves downstream analysis of the data. Especially if the RNA-Seq data is used to produce a de novo transcriptome assembly, running SEECER can have tremendous impact on the quality of the assembly. *'''Sickle''' ''[https://github.com/najoshi/sickle Sickle]''. A windowed adaptive trimming tool for FASTQ files using quality. *'''SnoWhite'''<ref name=snow2013>{{cite journal|journal= G3 |volume=3| year=2013 |vauthors=Dlugosch KM, Lai Z, Bonin A, Hierro J, Rieseberg LH | pmid=23390612| title= Allele identification for transcriptome-based population genomics in the invasive plant Centaurea solstitialis.|doi= 10.1534/g3.112.003871 | issue=2| pages=359–367 | pmc=3564996}}</ref> ''[http://dlugoschlab.arizona.edu/software.html SnoWhite]''. Snowhite is a pipeline designed to flexibly and aggressively clean sequence reads (gDNA or cDNA) prior to assembly. It takes in and returns fastq or fasta formatted sequence files. *'''ShortRead''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.11/bioc/html/ShortRead.html ShortRead]'' is a package provided in the [[R (programming language)]] / [[BioConductor]] environments and allows input, manipulation, quality assessment and output of next-generation sequencing data. This tool makes possible manipulation of data, such as filter solutions to remove reads based on predefined criteria. ShortRead could be complemented with several Bioconductor packages to further analysis and visualization solutions ([[BioStrings]], [[BSgenome]], [[IRanges]], and so on). *'''SortMeRNA''' ''[http://bioinfo.lifl.fr/sortmerna/sortmerna.php SortMeRNA]'' is a program tool for filtering, mapping and OTU-picking NGS reads in metatranscriptomic and metagenomic data. The core algorithm is based on approximate seeds and allows for fast and sensitive analyses of nucleotide sequences. The main application of SortMeRNA is filtering ribosomal RNA from metatranscriptomic data. *'''TagCleaner''' ''[http://tagcleaner.sourceforge.net/ TagCleaner]''. The TagCleaner tool can be used to automatically detect and efficiently remove tag sequences (e.g. WTA tags) from genomic and metagenomic datasets. It is easily configurable and provides a user-friendly interface. *'''Trimmomatic''' <ref name=trimmomatic>{{cite journal|last1=Bolger|first1=A. M.|last2=Lohse|first2=M.|last3=Usadel|first3=B.|title=Trimmomatic: a flexible trimmer for Illumina sequence data|journal=Bioinformatics|date=1 April 2014|volume=30|issue=15|pages=2114–2120|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btu170|pmid=24695404|pmc=4103590}}</ref> ''[http://www.usadellab.org/cms/index.php?page=trimmomatic Trimmomatic]'' performs trimming for Illumina platforms and works with FASTQ reads (single or pair-ended). Some of the tasks executed are: cut adapters, cut bases in optional positions based on quality thresholds, cut reads to a specific length, converts quality scores to Phred-33/64.
====Detection of chimeric reads==== Recent sequencing technologies normally require DNA samples to be amplified via polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Amplification often generates chimeric elements (specially from ribosomal origin) - sequences formed from two or more original sequences joined together. * '''UCHIME''' ''[http://drive5.com/uchime UCHIME]''. UCHIME is an algorithm for detecting chimeric sequences. * '''ChimeraSlayer''' ''[http://microbiomeutil.sourceforge.net/ ChimeraSlayer] is a chimeric sequence detection utility, compatible with near-full length Sanger sequences and shorter 454-FLX sequences (~500 bp).
====Error correction==== High-throughput sequencing errors characterization and their eventual correction.<ref name=David2015>{{cite journal|journal= Briefings in Bioinformatics|volume=17| year=2015 |author1=David Laehnemann, Arndt Borkhardt |author2=Alice Carolyn McHardy |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=26026159| title= Denoising DNA deep sequencing data—high-throughput sequencing errors and their correction|doi=10.1093/bib/bbv029| issue=1| pages=1–26 | pmc=4719071}}</ref> *'''Acacia''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/acaciaerrorcorr/ Acacia]''. Error-corrector for pyrosequenced amplicon reads. *'''AllPathsLG''' error correction. *'''AmpliconNoise''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/ampliconnoise/ AmpliconNoise]''.<ref name=Quince2011>{{cite journal | journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=12| year=2011|vauthors=Quince C, Lanzen A, Davenport RJ, Turnbaugh PJ | pmid=21276213| title= Removing noise from pyrosequenced amplicons |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-12-38| issue=38| pages= 38| pmc=3045300}}</ref> AmpliconNoise is a collection of programs for the removal of noise from 454 sequenced PCR amplicons. It involves two steps the removal of noise from the sequencing itself and the removal of PCR point errors. This project also includes the Perseus algorithm for chimera removal. *'''BayesHammer''' ''[http://cab.spbu.ru/software/spades/ BayesHammer]. Bayesian clustering for error correction. We introduce several novel algorithms based on Hamming graphs and Bayesian subclustering in our new error correction tool BAYES HAMMER. While BAYES HAMMER was designed for single-cell sequencing, we demonstrate that it also improves on existing error correction tools for multi-cell sequencing data while working much faster on real-life datasets. We benchmark BAYES HAMMER on both k-mer counts and actual assembly results with the SPADES genome assembler. *'''Bless''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/p/bless-ec/wiki/Home/ Bless].<ref name=Heo2014>{{cite journal | journal= Bioinformatics | year=2014|vauthors=Heo Y, Wu XL, Chen D, Ma J, Hwu WM | pmid=24451628| title= BLESS: bloom filter-based error correction solution for high-throughput sequencing reads |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btu030 | volume=30| issue=10| pages=1354–1362}}</ref> A bloom filter-based error correction solution for high-throughput sequencing reads. *'''Blue''' ''[http://www.bioinformatics.csiro.au/blue/ Blue]''.<ref name=Paul2014>{{cite journal | journal= Bioinformatics |volume=30| year=2014|author1=Paul Greenfield |author2=Konsta Duesing |author3=Alexie Papanicolaou |author4=Denis C. Bauer | pmid=24919879| title=Blue: correcting sequencing errors using consensus and context. |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btu368| issue=19| pages=2723–32}}</ref> Blue is a fast, accurate short-read error-correction tool based on k-mer consensus and context. *'''bfc''' ''[https://github.com/lh3/bfc bfc]''. A free, fast and easy-to-use sequencing error corrector designed for Illumina short reads. It uses a non-greedy algorithm but still maintains a speed comparable to implementations based on greedy methods. *'''Denoiser''' ''[http://nebc.nerc.ac.uk/bioinformatics/docs/denoiser.html Denoiser]''. Denoiser is designed to address issues of noise in pyrosequencing data. Denoiser is a heuristic variant of PyroNoise. Developers of denoiser report a good agreement with PyroNoise on several test datasets. *'''Echo''' ''[http://uc-echo.sourceforge.net/ Echo]''. A reference-free short-read error correction algorithm. *'''Lighter'''. A fast and memory-efficient sequencing error correction without counting. *'''LSC''' ''[http://www.healthcare.uiowa.edu/labs/au/LSC/ LSC]''. LSC uses short Illumina reads to corrected errors in long reads. *'''Karect''' ''[https://aminallam.github.io/karect/ Karect]''. Karect: accurate correction of substitution, insertion and deletion errors for next-generation sequencing data. *'''NoDe''' ''[http://science.sckcen.be/en/Institutes/EHS/MCB/MIC/Bioinformatics/NoDe NoDe]''. NoDe: a fast error-correction algorithm for pyrosequencing amplicon reads. *'''PyroTagger''' ''[https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/jgi_pyrotagger Pyrotagger]''. PyroTagger: A fast, accurate pipeline for analysis of rRNA amplicon pyrosequence data. *'''Quake''' ''[http://www.cbcb.umd.edu/software/quake/ Quake]'' is a tool to correct substitution sequencing errors in experiments with deep coverage for Illumina sequencing reads. *'''QuorUM''' ''[http://www.genome.umd.edu/ QuorUM]'': An Error Corrector for Illumina Reads. *'''Rcorrector'''. Error correction for Illumina RNA-seq reads. *'''Reptile''' ''[http://aluru-sun.ece.iastate.edu/doku.php?id=reptile Reptile]'' is a software developed in C++ for correcting sequencing errors in short reads from next-gen sequencing platforms. *'''Seecer''' ''[http://sb.cs.cmu.edu/seecer/ Seecer]''. SEquencing Error CorrEction for Rna reads. *'''SGA'''. *'''SOAP denovo'''. *'''UNOISE'''.
====Bias correction==== *'''Alpine''' ''[https://github.com/mikelove/alpine Alpine]''.<ref name=Love2015>{{cite biorxiv | year=2015|author1=Michael I Love |author2=John B Hogenesch |author3=Rafael A Irizarry | title= Modeling of RNA-seq fragment sequence bias reduces systematic errors in transcript abundance estimation|biorxiv=025767}}</ref> Modeling and correcting fragment sequence bias for RNA-seq. *'''cqn''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/cqn.html cqn]'' <ref name=Hansen2012>{{cite journal|journal= Biostatistics |volume=13| year=2012 |vauthors=Hansen KD, Irizarry RA, Wu Z | pmid=22285995| title= Removing technical variability in RNA-seq data using conditional quantile normalization.|doi= 10.1093/biostatistics/kxr054| issue=2| pages=204–16 | pmc=3297825}}</ref> is a normalization tool for RNA-Seq data, implementing the conditional quantile normalization method. *'''EDASeq''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/EDASeq.html EDASeq]'' <ref name=Risso2011>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=12| year=2011|vauthors=Risso D, Schwartz K, Sherlock G, Dudoit S | pmid=22177264|pmc=3315510| title = GC-Content Normalization for RNA-Seq Data.|url= http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/12/480|doi= 10.1186/1471-2105-12-480| issue=1| pages=480}}</ref> is a Bioconductor package to perform GC-Content Normalization for RNA-Seq Data. *'''GeneScissors''' ''[http://csbio.unc.edu/genescissors/ GeneScissors]''. A comprehensive approach to detecting and correcting spurious transcriptome inference due to RNAseq reads misalignment. *'''Peer''' ''[https://github.com/PMBio/peer/wiki Peer]'' <ref name=Oliver2012>{{cite journal|journal= Nat Protoc |volume=7| year=2012 |author1=Oliver Stegle |author2=Leopold Parts |author3=Matias Piipari |author4=John Winn |author5=Richard Durbin |last-author-amp=yes | pmid=22343431| title= Using probabilistic estimation of expression residuals (PEER) to obtain increased power and interpretability of gene expression analyses.|doi= 10.1038/nprot.2011.457| issue=6| pages=500–507| pmc=3398141}}</ref> is a collection of Bayesian approaches to infer hidden determinants and their effects from gene expression profiles using factor analysis methods. Applications of PEER have: a) detected batch effects and experimental confounders, b) increased the number of expression QTL findings by threefold, c) allowed inference of intermediate cellular traits, such as transcription factor or pathway activations. *'''RUV''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/RUVSeq.html RUVseq]'' <ref name=Risso2014>{{cite journal|journal= Nat. Biotechnol. |volume=32| year=2014 |vauthors=Risso D, Ngai J, Speed TP, Dudoit S | pmid=25150836| title= Normalization of RNA-seq data using factor analysis of control genes or samples |doi= 10.1038/nbt.2931| issue=9| pages=896–902 | pmc=4404308}}</ref> is a R package that implements the remove unwanted variation (RUV) methods of Risso et al. (2014) for the normalization of RNA-Seq read counts between samples. *'''sva''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.11/bioc/html/sva.html sva]'' Surrogate Variable Analysis. *'''svaseq''' ''[https://github.com/jtleek/svaseq svaseq]'' removing batch effects and other unwanted noise from sequencing data. *'''SysCall''' ''[http://bio.math.berkeley.edu/SysCall/ SysCall]'' <ref name=Meacham2011>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=12| year=2011 | author= Meacham, F., Boffelli, D., Dhahbi, J., Martin, D. I., Singer, M., & [[Lior Pachter|Pachter, L.]] | pmid=22099972|pmc=3295828| title= Identification and correction of systematic error in high-throughput sequence data |url= http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/12/451/|doi=10.1186/1471-2105-12-451| issue=1| pages=451}}</ref> is a classifier tool to identification and correction of systematic error in high-throughput sequence data.
====Other tasks/pre-processing data==== Further tasks performed before alignment, namely paired-read mergers. * '''AuPairWise''' ''[https://github.com/sarbal/AuPairWise AuPairWise]'' A Method to Estimate RNA-Seq Replicability through Co-expression. * '''BamHash''' ''[https://github.com/DecodeGenetics/BamHash BamHash]''is a checksum based method to ensure that the read pairs in FASTQ files match exactly the read pairs stored in BAM files, regardless of the ordering of reads. BamHash can be used to verify the integrity of the files stored and discover any discrepancies. Thus, BamHash can be used to determine if it is safe to delete the FASTQ files storing raw sequencing reads after alignment, without the loss of data. * '''BBMerge''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/ BBMerge]''Merges paired reads based on overlap to create longer reads, and an insert-size histogram. Fast, multithreaded, and yields extremely few false positives. Open-source, written in pure Java; supports all platforms with no recompilation and no other dependencies. Distributed with BBMap. *'''Biopieces''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/biopieces/ Biopieces]'' are a collection of bioinformatics tools that can be pieced together in a very easy and flexible manner to perform both simple and complex tasks. The Biopieces work on a data stream in such a way that the data stream can be passed through several different Biopieces, each performing one specific task: modifying or adding records to the data stream, creating plots, or uploading data to databases and web services. *'''COPE''' ''[ftp://ftp.genomics.org.cn/pub/cope COPE]''.<ref name=Liu2012>{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=28| year=2012 |vauthors=Liu B, Yuan J, Yiu SM, Li Z, Xie Y, Chen Y, Shi Y, Zhang H, Li Y, Lam TW, Luo R | pmid=23044551| title= COPE: an accurate k-mer-based pair-end reads connection tool to facilitate genome assembly.|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts563| issue=22| pages=2870–4}}</ref> COPE: an accurate k-mer-based pair-end reads connection tool to facilitate genome assembly. *'''DeconRNASeq''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.12/bioc/html/DeconRNASeq.html DeconRNASeq]'' is an R package for deconvolution of heterogeneous tissues based on mRNA-Seq data. *'''FastQ Screen''' ''[http://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/fastq_screen/ FastQ Screen]'' screens [[FASTQ format]] sequences to a set of databases to confirm that the sequences contain what is expected (such as species content, adapters, vectors, etc.). *'''FLASH''' ''[http://www.cbcb.umd.edu/software/flash FLASH]'' is a read pre-processing tool. FLASH combines paired-end reads which overlap and converts them to single long reads. *'''IDCheck''' ''[http://eqtl.rc.fas.harvard.edu/idcheck/ IDCheck]''. *'''PANDASeq'''. ''[https://github.com/neufeld/pandaseq PANDASeq]'' is a program to align Illumina reads, optionally with PCR primers embedded in the sequence, and reconstruct an overlapping sequence. *'''PEAR''' ''[http://www.exelixis-lab.org/pear Pear]''.<ref name=Zhang2012>{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=30| year=2013 |author1=J. Zhang |author2=K. Kobert |author3=T. Flouri |author4=A. Stamatakis | pmid=24142950| title= PEAR: A fast and accurate Illumina Paired-End read mergeR|url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2013/10/18/bioinformatics.btt593.short |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btt593| issue=5| pages=614–620 | pmc=3933873}}</ref> PEAR: A fast and accurate Illumina Paired-End reAd mergeR. *'''qRNASeq script''' ''[http://www.biooscientific.com/Next-Gen-Sequencing/Illumina-Library-Prep-Kits/NEXTflex-Rapid-Directional-qRNA-Seq-Kit/resources#LiveTabsContent68055366 qRNASeq script]''. The qRNAseq tool can be used to accurately eliminate PCR duplicates from RNA-Seq data if Molecular Indexes™ or other stochastic labels have been used during library prep. *'''SHERA''' ''[http://almlab.mit.edu/shera.html Shera]'' <ref name=Sebastien2010>{{cite journal|journal=PLoS ONE |volume=5| year=2010|author1=Sébastien Rodrigue |author2=Arne C. Materna |author3=Sonia C. Timberlake |author4=Matthew C. Blackburn |author5=Rex R. Malmstrom |author6=Eric J. Alm |author7=Sallie W. Chisholm | pmid=20676378| title = Unlocking Short Read Sequencing for Metagenomics|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0011840| issue=7| pages=e11840 | pmc=2911387|bibcode=2010PLoSO...511840R}}</ref> a SHortread Error-Reducing Aligner. *'''XORRO''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/xorro-overlap/ Xorro]'': Rapid Paired-End Read Overlapper.
==Alignment tools== After quality control, the first step of RNA-Seq analysis involves alignment ''[http://training.bioinformatics.ucdavis.edu/docs/2012/05/RNA/_downloads/Alignment.pdf (RNA-Seq alignment) ]'' of the sequenced reads to a reference genome (if available) or to a transcriptome database. See also <ref name=Nuno2012>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=28| year=2012 |author1=Nuno A. Fonseca |author2=Johan Rung |author3=Alvis Brazma |author4=John C. Marioni | pmid=23060614| title = Tools for mapping high-throughput sequencing data|url=http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/24/3169.full|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts605| issue=24| pages=3169–3177}}</ref> and ''[[List of sequence alignment software]]''.
===Short (unspliced) aligners=== Short aligners are able to align continuous reads (not containing gaps result of splicing) to a genome of reference. Basically, there are two types: 1) based on the [[Burrows-Wheeler transform]] method such as Bowtie and BWA, and 2) based on Seed-extend methods, [[Needleman-Wunsch]] or [[Smith-Waterman]] algorithms. The first group (Bowtie and BWA) is many times faster, however some tools of the second group tend to be more sensitive, generating more correctly aligned reads. See a comparative study of short aligners - ''[http://lh3lh3.users.sourceforge.net/alnROC.shtml comparative study]''. <!--For an online comparative study of short aligners performances see ''[http://massgenomics.org/short-read-aligners MassGenomics/aligners]''.--> *''' [[BFAST]]''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/apps/mediawiki/bfast/index.php?title=Main_Page BFAST]'' aligns short reads to reference sequences and presents particular sensitivity towards errors, SNPs, insertions and deletions. BFAST works with the [[Smith-Waterman]] algorithm. See also ''[http://seqanswers.com/wiki/BFAST seqanwers/BFAST]''. *'''[[BowTie (aligner)|Bowtie]]''' ''[http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml Bowtie]'' is a fast short aligner using an algorithm based on the [[Burrows-Wheeler transform]] and the [[FM-index]]. Bowtie tolerates a small number of mismatches. *'''Burrows-Wheeler Aligner (BWA)''' ''[http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/ BWA]''. BWA is a software package for mapping low-divergent sequences against a large reference genome, such as the human genome. It consists of three algorithms: BWA-backtrack, BWA-SW and BWA-MEM. The first algorithm is designed for Illumina sequence reads up to 100bp, while the rest two for longer sequences ranged from 70bp to 1Mbp. BWA-MEM and BWA-SW share similar features such as long-read support and split alignment, but BWA-MEM, which is the latest, is generally recommended for high-quality queries as it is faster and more accurate. BWA-MEM also has better performance than BWA-backtrack for 70-100bp Illumina reads. *'''Short Oligonucleotide Analysis Package (SOAP)''' ''[http://soap.genomics.org.cn/ SOAP]''. *'''GNUMAP''' ''[http://dna.cs.byu.edu/gnumap/ GNUMAP]'' performs alignment using a probabilistic [[Needleman-Wunsch]] algorithm. This tool is able to handle alignment in repetitive regions of a genome without losing information. The output of the program was developed to make possible easy visualization using available software. *'''Maq''' ''[http://maq.sourceforge.net/maq-man.shtml Maq]'' first aligns reads to reference sequences and after performs a consensus stage. On the first stage performs only ungapped alignment and tolerates up to 3 mismatches. *'''Mosaik''' ''[http://bioinformatics.bc.edu/marthlab/Mosaik Mosaik]''. Mosaik is able to align reads containing short gaps using [[Smith-Waterman algorithm]], ideal to overcome SNPs, insertions and deletions. *'''NovoAlign (commercial)''' ''[http://www.novocraft.com/main/index.php NovoAlign]'' is a short aligner to the Illumina platform based on [[Needleman-Wunsch]] algorithm. It is able to deal with bisulphite data. Output in SAM format. *'''PerM''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/perm/ PerM]'' is a software package which was designed to perform highly efficient genome scale alignments for hundreds of millions of short reads produced by the ABI SOLiD and Illumina sequencing platforms. PerM is capable of providing full sensitivity for alignments within 4 mismatches for 50bp SOLID reads and 9 mismatches for 100bp Illumina reads. *'''RazerS''' ''[http://www.seqan.de/projects/razers RazerS]''. *'''SEAL''' ''[http://biodoop-seal.sourceforge.net/ SEAL]'' uses a [[MapReduce]] model to produce distributed computing on clusters of computers. Seal uses BWA to perform alignment and [[Picard MarkDuplicates]] to detection and duplicate read removal. *'''segemehl''' ''[http://www.bioinf.uni-leipzig.de/Software/segemehl/ segemehl]''. *'''SeqMap''' ''[http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jianghui/seqmap/ SeqMap]''. *'''SHRiMP''' ''[http://compbio.cs.toronto.edu/shrimp/ SHRiMP]'' employs two techniques to align short reads. Firstly, the [[q-gram]] filtering technique based on multiple seeds identifies candidate regions. Secondly, these regions are investigated in detail using [[Smith-Waterman]] algorithm. *'''SMALT''' ''[http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/software/smalt/ Smalt]''. *'''Stampy''' ''[http://www.well.ox.ac.uk/project-stampy Stampy]'' combines the sensitivity of hash tables and the speed of BWA. Stampy is prepared to alignment of reads containing sequence variation like insertions and deletions. It is able to deal with reads up to 4500 bases and presents the output in SAM format. *'''ZOOM (commercial)''' ''[http://www.bioinfor.com/zoom/general/overview.html ZOOM]'' is a short aligner of the Illumina/Solexa 1G platform. ZOOM uses extended spaced seeds methodology building hash tables for the reads, and tolerates mismatches and insertions and deletions. *'''WHAM''' ''[http://research.cs.wisc.edu/wham/ Wham]''. WHAM is a high-throughput sequence alignment tool developed at University of Wisconsin-Madison. It aligns short DNA sequences (reads) to the whole human genome at a rate of over 1500 million 60bit/s reads per hour, which is one to two orders of magnitudes faster than the leading state-of-the-art techniques.
===Spliced aligners=== Many reads span exon-exon junctions and can not be aligned directly by Short aligners, thus specific aligners were necessary - Spliced aligners. Some Spliced aligners employ Short aligners to align firstly unspliced/continuous reads (exon-first approach), and after follow a different strategy to align the rest containing spliced regions - normally the reads are split into smaller segments and mapped independently. See also.<ref name=Alamancos2014>{{Cite book|journal= Methods Mol. Biol. |volume=1126| year=2014 |vauthors=Alamancos GP, Agirre E, Eyras E | pmid=24549677| title = Methods to study splicing from high-throughput RNA sequencing data |doi=10.1007/978-1-62703-980-2_26| issue=| pages=357–97|arxiv=1304.5952|series=Methods in Molecular Biology|isbn=978-1-62703-979-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baruzzo|first=Giacomo|last2=Hayer|first2=Katharina E.|last3=Kim|first3=Eun Ji|last4=Di Camillo|first4=Barbara|last5=FitzGerald|first5=Garret A.|last6=Grant|first6=Gregory R.|date=February 2017|title=Simulation-based comprehensive benchmarking of RNA-seq aligners|url=http://www.nature.com/nmeth/journal/v14/n2/full/nmeth.4106.html|journal=Nature Methods|language=en|volume=14|issue=2|pages=135–139|doi=10.1038/nmeth.4106|pmid=27941783|pmc=5792058|issn=1548-7091}}</ref>
====Aligners based on known splice junctions (annotation-guided aligners)==== In this case the detection of splice junctions is based on data available in databases about known junctions. This type of tools cannot identify new splice junctions. Some of this data comes from other expression methods like [[expressed sequence tags]] (EST).
*'''Erange''' ''[http://woldlab.caltech.edu/rnaseq/ Erange]'' is a tool to alignment and data quantification to mammalian transcriptomes. *'''IsoformEx''' ''[http://bioinformatics.wistar.upenn.edu/isoformex IsoformEx]''. *'''MapAL''' ''[http://www.bioinf.boku.ac.at/pub/MapAl/ MapAL]''. * '''OSA''' ''[http://omicsoft.com/osa/ OSA]''. *'''RNA-MATE''' ''[http://grimmond.imb.uq.edu.au/RNA-MATE/ RNA-MATE]'' is a computational pipeline for alignment of data from [[Applied Biosystems]] SOLID system. Provides the possibility of quality control and trimming of reads. The genome alignments are performed using '''mapreads''' and the splice junctions are identified based on a library of known exon-junction sequences. This tool allows visualization of alignments and tag counting. *'''RUM''' ''[https://github.com/PGFI/rum/wiki RUM]'' performs alignment based on a pipeline, being able to manipulate reads with splice junctions, using Bowtie and Blat. The flowchart starts doing alignment against a genome and a transcriptome database executed by Bowtie. The next step is to perform alignment of unmapped sequences to the genome of reference using BLAT. In the final step all alignments are merged to get the final alignment. The input files can be in FASTA or FASTQ format. The output is presented in RUM and SAM format. *'''RNASEQR''' ''[http://hood.systemsbiology.net/rnaseqr.php RNASEQR]''. *'''SAMMate''' ''[http://sammate.sourceforge.net/ SAMMate]''. *'''SpliceSeq''' ''[http://bioinformatics.mdanderson.org/main/SpliceSeq:Overview SpliceSeq]''. *'''X-Mate''' ''[http://grimmond.imb.uq.edu.au/X-MATE/ X-Mate]''.
====De novo splice aligners==== De novo Splice aligners allow the detection of new Splice junctions without need to previous annotated information (some of these tools present annotation as a suplementar option). See also [http://openwetware.org/wiki/Wikiomics:RNA-Seq De novo Splice Aligners].
* '''ABMapper''' ''[http://hkbic.cuhk.edu.hk/software/abmapper ABMapper]''. *'''BBMap''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/ BBMap]'' Uses short kmers to align reads directly to the genome (spanning introns to find novel isoforms) or transcriptome. Highly tolerant of substitution errors and indels, and very fast. Supports output of all SAM tags needed by Cufflinks. No limit to genome size or number of splices per read. Supports Illumina, 454, Sanger, Ion Torrent, PacBio, and Oxford Nanopore reads, paired or single-ended. Does not use any splice-site-finding heuristics optimized for a single taxonomic branch, but rather finds optimally-scoring multi-affine-transform global alignments, and thus is ideal for studying new organisms with no annotation and unknown splice motifs. Open-source, written in pure Java; supports all platforms with no recompilation and no other dependencies. *'''ContextMap''' ''[http://www.bio.ifi.lmu.de/softwareservices/contextmap ContextMap]'' was developed to overcome some limitations of other mapping approaches, such as resolution of ambiguities. The central idea of this tool is to consider reads in gene expression context, improving this way alignment accuracy. ContextMap can be used as a stand-alone program and supported by mappers producing a SAM file in the output (e.g.: TopHat or MapSplice). In stand-alone mode aligns reads to a genome, to a transcriptome database or both. *'''CRAC''' ''[http://crac.gforge.inria.fr/ CRAC]'' propose a novel way of analyzing reads that integrates genomic locations and local coverage, and detect candidate mutations, indels, splice or fusion junctions in each single read. Importantly, CRAC improves its predictive performance when supplied with e.g. 200 nt reads and should fit future needs of read analyses. * '''GSNAP''' ''[http://research-pub.gene.com/gmap/ GSNAP]''. * '''GMAP''' ''[http://research-pub.gene.com/gmap/ GMAP]'' A Genomic Mapping and Alignment Program for mRNA and EST Sequences. *'''HISAT''' ''[http://www.ccb.jhu.edu/software/hisat/index.shtml HISAT]''. HISAT is a fast and sensitive spliced alignment program for mapping RNA-seq reads. In addition to one global FM index that represents a whole genome, HISAT uses a large set of small FM indexes that collectively cover the whole genome (each index represents a genomic region of ~64,000 bp and ~48,000 indexes are needed to cover the human genome). These small indexes (called local indexes) combined with several alignment strategies enable effective alignment of RNA-seq reads, in particular, reads spanning multiple exons. The memory footprint of HISAT is relatively low (~4.3GB for the human genome). We have developed HISAT based on the Bowtie2 implementation to handle most of the operations on the FM index. *'''HMMSplicer''' ''[http://derisilab.ucsf.edu/index.php?software=105 HMMSplicer]'' can identify canonical and non-canonical splice junctions in short-reads. Firstly, unspliced reads are removed with Bowtie. After that, the remaining reads are one at a time divided in half, then each part is seeded against a genome and the exon borders are determined based on the [[Hidden Markov Model]] . A quality score is assigned to each junction, useful to detect false positive rates. *'''MapSplice''' ''[http://www.netlab.uky.edu/p/bioinfo/MapSplice MapSplice]''. *'''PALMapper''' ''[http://www.raetschlab.org/suppl/palmapper PALMapper]''. *'''Pass''' ''[http://pass.cribi.unipd.it/cgi-bin/pass.pl Pass]'' <ref name=Campagna2013>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=29| year=2013|vauthors=Campagna D, Telatin A, Forcato C, Vitulo N, Valle G | pmid=23162053| title =PASS-bis: a bisulfite aligner suitable for whole methylome analysis of Illumina and SOLiD reads.|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts675| issue=2| pages=268–70}}</ref> aligns gapped, ungapped reads and also [[bisulfite sequencing]] data. It includes the possibility to filter data before alignment (remotion of adapters). Pass uses [[Needleman-Wunsch]] and [[Smith-Waterman]] algorithms, and performs alignment in 3 stages: scanning positions of seed sequences in the genome, testing the contiguous regions and finally refining the alignment. *'''PASSion''' ''[https://trac.nbic.nl/passion/ PASSion]''. * '''PASTA''' ''[http://genome.ufl.edu/rivalab/pasta/ PASTA]''. *'''QPALMA''' ''[http://www.raetschlab.org/suppl/qpalma QPALMA]'' predicts splice junctions supported on [[machine learning]] algorithms. In this case the training set is a set of spliced reads with quality information and already known alignments. *'''RAZER''' ''[https://github.com/jaegyoonahn/RASER RAZER]'':<ref name=Jaegyoon2015>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=31| year=2015|author1=Jaegyoon Ahn |author2=Xinshu Xiao |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=26323713| title = RASER: reads aligner for SNPs and editing sites of RNA|url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/09/04/bioinformatics.btv505.full|doi= 10.1093/bioinformatics/btv505| issue=24| pages=3906–13 | pmc=4692970}}</ref> reads aligner for SNPs and editing sites of RNA. *'''SeqSaw''' ''[http://bioinfo.au.tsinghua.edu.cn/software/seqsaw/ SeqSaw]''. *'''SoapSplice''' ''[http://soap.genomics.org.cn/soapsplice.html SoapSplice]'' - A tool for genome-wide ab initio detection of splice junction sites from RNA-Seq, a method using new generation sequencing technologies to sequence the messenger RNA. *'''SpliceMap''' ''[http://www.stanford.edu/group/wonglab/SpliceMap/ SpliceMap]''. *'''SplitSeek''' ''[http://www.uppmax.uu.se/software/splitseek SplitSeek]''. *'''SuperSplat''' ''[http://supersplat.cgrb.oregonstate.edu/ SuperSplat]'' was developed to find all type of splice junctions. The algorithm splits each read in all possible two-chunk combinations in an iterative way, and alignment is tried to each chunck. Output in "Supersplat" format. * '''Subread''' ''[http://subread.sourceforge.net/ Subread]''<ref name=liao2013>{{cite journal | journal=Nucleic Acids Research | volume=41 | year=2013 | author=Yang Liao, Gordon K Smyth and Wei Shi | title= The Subread aligner: fast, accurate and scalable read mapping by seed-and-vote | pmid= 23558742 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkt214 | issue=10 | pages=e108 | pmc=3664803}}</ref> is a superfast, accurate and scalable read aligner. It uses the seed-and-vote mapping paradigm to determine the mapping location of the read by using its largest mappable region. It automatically decides whether the read should be globally mapped or locally mapped. For RNA-seq data, Subread should be used for the purpose of expression analysis. Subread is very powerful in mapping gDNA-seq reads as well. * '''Subjunc''' ''[http://subread.sourceforge.net/ Subjunc]''<ref name="liao2013"/> is a specialized version of Subread. It uses all mappable regions in an RNA-seq read to discover exons and exon-exon junctions. It uses the donor/receptor signals to find the exact splicing locations. Subjunc yields full alignments for every RNA-seq read including exon-spanning reads, in addition to the discovered exon-exon junctions. Subjunc should be used for the purpose of junction detection and genomic variation detection in RNA-seq data.
=====De novo splice aligners that also use annotation optionally===== *'''MapNext''' ''[http://evolution.sysu.edu.cn/english/software/mapnext.htm MapNext]''. * '''OLego''' ''[http://zhanglab.c2b2.columbia.edu/index.php/OLego OLego]''. * '''STAR''' ''[https://github.com/alexdobin/STAR STAR]'' is an ultrafast tool that employs "sequential maximum mappable seed search in uncompressed suffix arrays followed by seed clustering and stitching procedure", detects canonical, non-canonical splices junctions and chimeric-fusion sequences. It is already adapted to align long reads ([[third-generation sequencing]] technologies) and can reach speeds of 45 million paired reads per hour per processor.<ref name="dobin2013">{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=29|year=2013|author=Alexander Dobin, Carrie A. Davis, Felix Schlesinger, Jorg Drenkow, Chris Zaleski, Sonali Jha, Philippe Batut, Mark Chaisson, Thomas R. Gingeras|pmid=23104886|title=STAR: ultrafast universal RNA-seq aligner|url=http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/29/1/15.full|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts635|issue=1|pages=15–21|pmc=3530905}}</ref> *'''[[TopHat (bioinformatics)|TopHat]]''' ''[http://tophat.cbcb.umd.edu TopHat]''<ref name=trapnell2009>{{cite journal | journal=Bioinformatics | volume=25 | issue=9 | pages=1105–1111 | year=2009 | author=Cole Trapnell, [[Lior Pachter]] and Steven Salzberg | pmid=19289445 | title= TopHat: discovering splice junctions with RNA-Seq | pmc=2672628 | url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/25/9/1105?etoc | doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btp120 }}</ref> is prepared to find de novo junctions. TopHat aligns reads in two steps. Firstly, unspliced reads are aligned with Bowtie. After, the aligned reads are assembled with Maq resulting islands of sequences. Secondly, the splice junctions are determined based on the initially unmapped reads and the possible canonical donor and acceptor sites within the island sequences.
=====Other spliced aligners===== *'''G.Mo.R-Se''' ''[http://www.genoscope.cns.fr/externe/gmorse/ G.Mo.R-Se]'' is a method that uses RNA-Seq reads to build ''de novo'' gene models.
===Evaluation of alignment tools=== *'''AlignerBoost''' ''[https://github.com/Grice-Lab/AlignerBoost AlignerBoost]'' is a generalized software toolkit for boosting Next-Gen sequencing mapping precision using a Bayesian-based mapping quality framework. *'''CADBURE''' ''[http://cadbure.sourceforge.net/ CADBURE]'':Bioinformatics tool for evaluating aligner performance on your RNA-Seq dataset. *'''QualiMap''' ''[http://qualimap.bioinfo.cipf.es/ QualiMap]'': Evaluating next generation sequencing alignment data. *'''RNAseqEVAL''' ''[https://github.com/kkrizanovic/RNAseqEval RNAseqEval]'' A collection of tools for evaluating RNA seq mapping. *'''Teaser''' ''[https://github.com/Cibiv/Teaser Teaser]'': Individualized benchmarking and optimization of read mapping results for NGS data.
==Normalization, quantitative analysis and differential expression== ===General tools=== These tools perform normalization and calculate the abundance of each gene expressed in a sample.<ref name=Lior2011>{{Cite journal|journal= |volume=| year=2011 | author= Lior Pachter| pmid=| title = Models for transcript quantification from RNA-Seq |arxiv= 1104.3889|doi=| issue=| pages=}}</ref> RPKM, FPKM and TPMs<ref name=Haijing2017>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=18(Suppl 4)| year=2017| author= Haijing Jin, Ying-Wooi Wan and Zhandong Liu| pmid=28361706|pmc=5374695| title= Comprehensive evaluation of RNA-seq quantification methods for linearity |doi=10.1186/s12859-017-1526-y| issue=117| pages=117}}</ref> are some of the units employed to quantification of expression ([http://www.rna-seqblog.com/rpkm-fpkm-and-tpm-clearly-explained/ RPKM-FPKM-TPMs video]). Some software are also designed to study the variability of genetic expression between samples (differential expression). Quantitative and differential studies are largely determined by the quality of reads alignment and accuracy of isoforms reconstruction. Several studies are available comparing differential expression methods.<ref name=Vanessa2012>{{cite journal | journal= American Journal of Botany |volume=99| year=2012|author1=VANESSA M. KVAM |author2=PENG LIU |author3=YAQING SI |last-author-amp=yes | pmid=22268221| title = A COMPARISON OF STATISTICAL METHODS FOR DETECTING DIFFERENTIALLY EXPRESSED GENES FROM RNA-SEQ DATA | url=http://www.amjbot.org/content/99/2/248.long |doi=10.3732/ajb.1100340 | issue=2| pages=248–256}}</ref><ref name=Marie2012>{{cite journal | journal=Brief Bioinform |volume=14| year=2012| author= Marie-Agne's Dillies, Andrea Rau, Julie Aubert, Christelle Hennequet-Antier, and on behalf of The French StatOmique Consortium | pmid=22988256| title= A comprehensive evaluation of normalization methods for Illumina high-throughput RNA sequencing data analysis|url= http://bib.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/09/15/bib.bbs046.long |doi=10.1093/bib/bbs046|issue=6|pages=1–13}}</ref><ref name=Ciaran2017>{{cite journal|journal= Briefing in Bioinformatics |volume=19| year=2017| author=Evans, C., Hardin, J. and Stoebel, D.| pmid=28334202|pmc=6171491| title= Selecting between-sample RNA-Seq normalization methods from the perspective of their assumptions |doi=10.1093/bib/bbx008| issue=5| pages=776–792}}</ref> *'''ABSSeq''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/html/ABSSeq.html ABSSeq]'' -a new RNA-Seq analysis method based on modelling absolute expression differences. * '''ALDEx2''' ''[https://github.com/ggloor/ALDEx2 ALDEx2]'' is a tool for comparative analysis of high-throughput sequencing data. ALDEx2 uses compositional data analysis and can be applied to RNAseq, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, metagenomic sequencing, and selective growth experiments. * '''Alexa-Seq''' ''[http://www.alexaplatform.org/alexa_seq/downloads.htm Alexa-Seq]'' is a pipeline that makes possible to perform gene expression analysis, transcript specific expression analysis, exon junction expression and quantitative alternative analysis. Allows wide alternative expression visualization, statistics and graphs. *'''ARH-seq''' – identification of differential splicing in RNA-seq data. *'''ASC''' ''[http://www.stat.brown.edu/ZWU/research.aspx ASC]''.<ref name=Zhijin2010>{{cite journal|journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=11| year=2010| author =Zhijin Wu, corresponding author1 Bethany D Jenkins, Tatiana A Rynearson, Sonya T Dyhrman, Mak A Saito, Melissa Mercier, and LeAnn P Whitney| pmid=21080965| title= Empirical bayes analysis of sequencing-based transcriptional profiling without replicates. |doi= 10.1186/1471-2105-11-564| issue=| pages=564| pmc=3098101}}</ref> *'''Ballgown''' ''[https://github.com/alyssafrazee/ballgown Ballgown]''. *'''BaySeq''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/baySeq.html BaySeq]'' is a Bioconductor package to identify differential expression using next-generation sequencing data, via empirical [[Bayesian methods]]. There is an option of using the "snow" package for parallelisation of computer data processing, recommended when dealing with large data sets. *'''GMNB''' ''[https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.02527 GMNB]''<ref name=":gmnb">Hajiramezanali, E. & Dadaneh, S. Z. & Figueiredo, P. d. & Sze, S. & Zhou, Z. & Qian, X. Differential Expression Analysis of Dynamical Sequencing Count Data with a Gamma Markov Chain. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1803.02527.pdf</ref> is a Bayesian method to temporal gene differential expression analysis across different phenotypes or treatment conditions that naturally handles the heterogeneity of sequencing depth in different samples, removing the need for ad-hoc normalization. *'''BBSeq''' ''[http://www.bios.unc.edu/research/genomic_software/BBSeq/ BBSeq]''. *'''BitSeq''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/bitseq/ BitSeq]''. (Bayesian Inference of Transcripts from Sequencing Data) is an application for inferring expression levels of individual transcripts from sequencing (RNA-Seq) data and estimating differential expression (DE) between conditions. *'''CEDER''' ''[http://www-rcf.usc.edu/~fsun/Programs/CEDER/CEDERmain.html CEDER]''. Accurate detection of differentially expressed genes by combining significance of exons using RNA-Seq. *'''CPTRA''' ''[http://people.tamu.edu/~syuan/cptra/cptra.html CPTRA]''. The CPTRA package is for analyzing transcriptome sequencing data from different sequencing platforms. It combines advantages of 454, Illumina GAII, or other platforms and can perform sequence tag alignment and annotation, expression quantification tasks. *'''casper''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/casper.html casper]'' is a Bioconductor package to quantify expression at the isoform level. It combines using informative data summaries, flexible estimation of experimental biases and statistical precision considerations which (reportedly) provide substantial reductions in estimation error. *'''Cufflinks/Cuffdiff''' ''[http://cufflinks.cbcb.umd.edu Cufflinks]'' is appropriate to measure global ''de novo'' transcript isoform expression. It performs assembly of transcripts, estimation of abundances and determines differential expression (Cuffdiff) and regulation in RNA-Seq samples.<ref name=trapnell2010>{{cite journal | journal = Nature Biotechnology | volume =28 | issue = 5 | pages = 511–515 | year = 2010 | author = Cole Trapnell, Brian A Williams, Geo Pertea, Ali Mortazavi, Gordon Kwan, Marijke J van Baren, Steven L Salzberg, Barbara J Wold and [[Lior Pachter]] | title = Transcript assembly and abundance estimation from RNA-Seq reveals thousands of new transcripts and switching among isoforms | pmid = 20436464 | url = http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v28/n5/abs/nbt.1621.html | doi=10.1038/nbt.1621 | pmc = 3146043 }}</ref> *'''DESeq''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/DESeq.html DESeq]'' is a Bioconductor package to perform differential gene expression analysis based on negative binomial distribution. *'''DEGSeq''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.6/bioc/html/DEGseq.html DEGSeq]''. *'''Derfinder''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/derfinder.html Derfinder]'' Annotation-agnostic differential expression analysis of RNA-seq data at base-pair resolution via the DER Finder approach. *'''DEXSeq''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/DEXSeq.html DEXSeq]'' is Bioconductor package that finds differential differential exon usage based on RNA-Seq exon counts between samples. DEXSeq employs negative binomial distribution, provides options to visualization and exploration of the results. *'''DEXUS''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.13/bioc/html/dexus.html dexus]'' is a Bioconductor package that identifies differentially expressed genes in RNA-Seq data under all possible study designs such as studies without replicates, without sample groups, and with unknown conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Klambauer | first1 = G. | last2 = Unterthiner | first2 = T. | last3 = Hochreiter | first3 = S. | doi = 10.1093/nar/gkt834 | title = DEXUS: Identifying differential expression in RNA-Seq studies with unknown conditions | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | year = 2013 | pmid = 24049071 | pmc =3834838 | volume=41 | issue=21 | pages=e198 }}</ref> In contrast to other methods, DEXUS does not need replicates to detect differentially expressed transcripts, since the replicates (or conditions) are estimated by the EM method for each transcript. * '''DGEclust''' [http://dvav.me/dgeclust/ dgeclust] is a Python package for clustering expression data from RNA-seq, CAGE and other NGS assays using a [[Hierarchical Dirichlet process|Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Mixture Model]]. The estimated cluster configurations can be post-processed in order to identify differentially expressed genes and for generating gene- and sample-wise dendrograms and heatmaps.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vavoulis|first=Dimitrios V.|last2=Francescatto|first2=Margherita|last3=Heutink|first3=Peter|last4=Gough|first4=Julian|date=2015-02-20|title=DGEclust: differential expression analysis of clustered count data|journal=Genome Biology|volume=16|pages=39|doi=10.1186/s13059-015-0604-6|pmid=25853652|pmc=4365804|issn=1465-6906}}</ref> * '''DiffSplice''' ''[http://www.netlab.uky.edu/p/bioinfo/DiffSplice DiffSplice]'' is a method for differential expression detection and visualization, not dependent on gene annotations. This method is supported on identification of alternative splicing modules (ASMs) that diverge in the different isoforms. A non-parametric test is applied to each ASM to identify significant differential transcription with a measured false discovery rate. *'''EBSeq''' ''[http://www.biostat.wisc.edu/~kendzior/EBSEQ/ EBSeq]'' is a Bioconductor package for identifying genes and isoforms differentially expressed (DE) across two or more biological conditions in an RNA-seq experiment. It also can be used to identify DE contigs after performing de novo transcriptome assembly. While performing DE analysis on isoforms or contigs, different isoform/contig groups have varying estimation uncertainties. EBSeq models the varying uncertainties using an empirical Bayes model with different priors. *'''EdgeR''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/edgeR.html EdgeR]'' is a R package for analysis of differential expression of data from DNA sequencing methods, like RNA-Seq, SAGE or ChIP-Seq data. edgeR employs statistical methods supported on negative binomial distribution as a model for count variability. *'''EdgeRun''' ''[https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/edgeRun/ edgeRun]'': an R package for sensitive, functionally relevant differential expression discovery using an unconditional exact test. *'''EQP''' ''[https://github.com/Novartis/EQP-cluster EQP]'' - The exon quantification pipeline (EQP): a comprehensive approach to the quantification of gene, exon and junction expression from RNA-seq data. *'''ESAT''' ''[http://garberlab.umassmed.edu/software/esat/index.html ESAT]'' The End Sequence Analysis Toolkit (ESAT) is specially designing to be applied for quantification of annotation of specialized RNA-Seq gene libraries that target the 5' or 3' ends of transcripts. *'''eXpress''' ''[http://bio.math.berkeley.edu/eXpress/index.html eXpress]'' performance includes transcript-level RNA-Seq quantification, allele-specific and haplotype analysis and can estimate transcript abundances of the multiple isoforms present in a gene. Although could be coupled directly with aligners (like Bowtie), eXpress can also be used with de novo assemblers and thus is not needed a reference genome to perform alignment. It runs on Linux, Mac and Windows. *'''ERANGE''' ''[http://woldlab.caltech.edu/rnaseq ERANGE]'' performs alignment, normalization and quantification of expressed genes. *'''featureCounts''' ''[http://bioinf.wehi.edu.au/featureCounts/ featureCounts]'' an efficient general-purpose read quantifier. It is part of the ''[http://subread.sourceforge.net SourceForge Subread package]'' and ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/Rsubread.html Bioconductor Rsubread package]''. *'''FDM''' ''[http://csbio-linux001.cs.unc.edu/nextgen/software/FDM/ FDM]''. *'''FineSplice''' ''[https://sourceforge.net/projects/finesplice/ FineSplice]'' - Enhanced splice junction detection and estimation from RNA-Seq data. *'''GFOLD''' ''[http://compbio.tongji.edu.cn/~fengjx/GFOLD/gfold.html GFOLD]:<ref name=Feng2012>{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics |volume=28| year=2012|vauthors=Feng J, Meyer CA, Wang Q, Liu JS, Liu XS, Zhang Y | pmid=22923299| title = GFOLD: a generalized fold change for ranking differentially expressed genes from RNA-seq data|url= http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/08/23/bioinformatics.bts515 |doi= 10.1093/bioinformatics/bts515 | issue=21| pages=2782–2788}}</ref> Generalized fold change for ranking differentially expressed genes from RNA-seq data. *'''globalSeq''' ''[https://doi.org/doi:10.18129/B9.bioc.globalSeq globalSeq]''.<ref name=Rauschenberger2016>{{cite journal|journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=17| year=2016|vauthors=Rauschenberger A, Jonker MA, van de Wiel MA, Menezes RX | pmid=26951498| title = Testing for association between RNA-Seq and high-dimensional data| doi=10.1186/s12859-016-0961-5| issue=118| pages=118| pmc=4782413}}</ref> Global test for counts: testing for association between RNA-Seq and high-dimensional data. *'''GPSeq''' ''[http://www-rcf.usc.edu/%7Eliangche/software.html GPSeq ]'' This is a software tool to analyze RNA-seq data to estimate gene and exon expression, identify differentially expressed genes, and differentially spliced exons. *'''IsoDOT''' – Differential RNA-isoform Expression. *'''Limma''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/limma.html Limma]''. Limma powers differential expression analyses for RNA-sequencing and microarray studies. *'''LPEseq''' ''[http://bibs.snu.ac.kr/software/LPEseq/ LPEseq]'' – accurately test differential expression with a limited number of replicates. *'''Kallisto''' ''[https://pachterlab.github.io/kallisto/about.html Kallisto]''. "Kallisto is a program for quantifying abundances of transcripts from RNA-Seq data, or more generally of target sequences using high-throughput sequencing reads. It is based on the novel idea of pseudoalignment for rapidly determining the compatibility of reads with targets, without the need for alignment. On benchmarks with standard RNA-Seq data, kallisto can quantify 30 million human reads in less than 3 minutes on a Mac desktop computer using only the read sequences and a transcriptome index that itself takes less than 10 minutes to build." *'''MATS''' ''[http://rnaseq-mats.sourceforge.net/ MATS]''. Multivariate Analysis of Transcript Splicing (MATS). *'''MetaDiff''' ''[https://github.com/jiach/MetaDiff MetaDiff]''. Differential isoform expression analysis using random-effects meta-regression. *'''metaseqR''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/metaseqR.html metaseqR]'' is a Bioconductor package that detects differentially expressed genes from RNA-Seq data by combining six statistical algorithms using weights estimated from their performance with simulated data estimated from real data, either public or user-based. In this way, metaseqR optimizes the tradeoff between precision and sensitivity.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 25452340 | year = 2015 | author1 = Moulos | first1 = P | title = Systematic integration of RNA-Seq statistical algorithms for accurate detection of differential gene expression patterns | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 43 | issue = 4 | pages = e25 | last2 = Hatzis | first2 = P | doi = 10.1093/nar/gku1273 | pmc=4344485 }}</ref> In addition, metaseqR creates a detailed and interactive report with a variety of diagnostic and exploration plots and auto-generated text. *'''MMSEQ''' ''[http://bgx.org.uk/software/mmseq.html MMSEQ]'' is a pipeline for estimating isoform expression and allelic imbalance in diploid organisms based on RNA-Seq. The pipeline employs tools like Bowtie, TopHat, ArrayExpressHTS and SAMtools. Also, edgeR or DESeq to perform differential expression. * '''MultiDE''' ''[http://homepage.fudan.edu.cn/zhangh/softwares/multiDE multiDE]'' * '''Myrna''' ''[http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/myrna/index.shtml Myrna]'' is a pipeline tool that runs in a cloud environment (''[http://aws.amazon.com/elasticmapreduce/ Elastic MapReduce]'') or in a unique computer for estimating differential gene expression in RNA-Seq datasets. Bowtie is employed for short read alignment and R algorithms for interval calculations, normalization, and statistical processing. * '''NEUMA''' ''[http://neuma.kobic.re.kr/ NEUMA]'' is a tool to estimate RNA abundances using length normalization, based on uniquely aligned reads and mRNA isoform models. NEUMA uses known transcriptome data available in databases like [[RefSeq]]. * '''NOISeq''' ''[http://bioinfo.cipf.es/noiseq/doku.php?id=start NOISeq]''. NOISeq is a non-parametric approach for the identification of differentially expressed genes from count data or previously normalized count data. NOISeq empirically models the noise distribution of count changes by contrasting fold-change differences (M) and absolute expression differences (D) for all the features in samples within the same condition. * '''NPEBseq''' ''[http://bioinformatics.wistar.upenn.edu/NPEBseq NPEBseq]'' is a nonparametric empirical bayesian- based method for differential expression analysis. * '''NSMAP''' ''[http://sites.google.com/site/nsmapforrnaseq/ NSMAP]'' allows inference of isoforms as well estimation of expression levels, without annotated information. The exons are aligned and splice junctions are identified using TopHat. All the possible isoforms are computed by combination of the detected exons. * '''NURD''' ''[http://bioinfo.au.tsinghua.edu.cn/software/NURD/ NURD]'' an implementation of a new method to estimate isoform expression from non-uniform RNA-seq data. * '''PANDORA''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/metaseqR.html PANDORA]''. An R package for the analysis and result reporting of RNA-Seq data by combining multiple statistical algorithms. * '''PennSeq''' ''[https://sourceforge.net/projects/pennseq/ PennSeq]'' PennSeq: accurate isoform-specific gene expression quantification in RNA-Seq by modeling non-uniform read distribution. *'''Quark''' ''[https://github.com/COMBINE-lab/quark Quark] - Quark enables semi-reference-based compression of RNA-seq data. *'''QuasR''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/QuasR.html QuasR] - Quantify and Annotate Short Reads in R. *'''RapMap''' ''[https://github.com/COMBINE-lab/RapMap RapMap]''. A Rapid, Sensitive and Accurate Tool for Mapping RNA-seq Reads to Transcriptomes. * '''RNAeXpress''' ''[http://rnaexpress.org/ RNAeXpress]'' Can be run with Java GUI or command line on Mac, Windows and Linux. Can be configured to perform read counting, feature detection or GTF comparison on mapped rnaseq data. * '''Rcount''' ''[https://github.com/MWSchmid/Rcount Rcount]''. Rcount: simple and flexible RNA-Seq read counting. * '''rDiff''' ''[http://bioweb.me/rdiff/ rDiff]'' is a tool that can detect differential RNA processing (e.g. alternative splicing, polyadenylation or ribosome occupancy). * '''RNASeqPower''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/RNASeqPower.html RNASeqPower]''. Calculating samples Size estimates for RNA Seq studies. R package version . * '''RNA-Skim''' ''[http://www.csbio.unc.edu/rs/ RNA-Skim]''. RNA-Skim: a rapid method for RNA-Seq quantification at transcript-level. * '''rSeq''' ''[http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jianghui/rseq/ rSeq]''. rSeq is a set of tools for RNA-Seq data analysis. It consists of programs that deal with many aspects of RNA-Seq data analysis, such as read quality assessment, reference sequence generation, sequence mapping, gene and isoform expressions (RPKMs) estimation, etc. * '''RSEM''' ''[http://deweylab.biostat.wisc.edu/rsem/ RSEM]''. * '''rQuant''' ''[http://www.raetschlab.org/suppl/rquant rQuant]'' is a web service ([[Galaxy (computational biology)]] installation) that determines abundances of transcripts per gene locus, based on [[quadratic programming]]. rQuant is able to evaluate biases introduced by experimental conditions. A combination of tools is employed: PALMapper (reads alignment), mTiM and mGene (inference of new transcripts). * '''Salmon''' ''[https://github.com/kingsfordgroup/sailfish/tree/develop Salmon]'' is an software tool for computing transcript abundance from RNA-seq data using either an alignment-free (based directly on the raw reads) or an alignment-based (based on pre-computed alignments) approach. It uses an online stochastic optimization approach to maximize the likelihood of the transcript abundances under the observed data. The software itself is capable of making use of many threads to produce accurate quantification estimates quickly. It is part of the ''[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~ckingsf/software/sailfish/ Sailfish]'' suite of software, and is the successor to the Sailfish tool. * '''SAJR''' ''[http://storage.bioinf.fbb.msu.ru/~mazin/ SAJR]'' is a java-written read counter and R-package for differential splicing analysis. It uses junction reads to estimate exon exclusion and reads mapped within exon to estimate its inclusion. SAJR models it by GLM with quasibinomial distribution and uses log likelihood test to assess significance. * '''Scotty''' ''[http://euler.bc.edu/marthlab/scotty/scotty.php/ Scotty]'' Performs power analysis to estimate the number of replicates and depth of sequencing required to call differential expression. * '''Seal''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/ Seal]'' Ultrafast, alignment-free algorithm to quantify sequence expression by matching kmers between raw reads and a reference transcriptome. Handles paired reads and alternate isoforms, and uses little memory. Accepts all common read formats, and outputs read counts, coverage, and FPKM values per reference sequence. Open-source, written in pure Java; supports all platforms with no recompilation and no other dependencies. Distributed with BBMap.
