(Seal - Sequence Expression AnaLyzer - is unrelated to the SEAL distributed short-read aligner.) *'''semisup''' ''[https://doi.org/doi:10.18129/B9.bioc.semisup semisup]''.<ref name=Rauschenberger2018>{{cite arXiv | vauthors= Rauschenberger A, Menezes RX, van de Wiel MA, van Schoor NM, Jonker MA | title= Detecting SNPs with interactive effects on a quantitative trait | eprint=1805.09175| class= stat.ME | year= 2018 }}</ref> Semi-supervised mixture model: detecting SNPs with interactive effects on a quantitative trait * '''Sleuth''' ''[https://pachterlab.github.io/sleuth/ Sleuth]'' is a program for analysis of RNA-Seq experiments for which transcript abundances have been quantified with kallisto. * '''SplicingCompass''' ''[http://www.ichip.de/software/SplicingCompass.html SplicingCompass]''. SplicingCompass: differential splicing detection using RNA-Seq data. * '''sSeq''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/sSeq.html sSeq]''. The purpose of this R package is to discover the genes that are differentially expressed between two conditions in RNA-seq experiments. * '''StringTie''' ''[http://ccb.jhu.edu/software/stringtie/ StringTie]'' is a fast and highly efficient assembler of RNA-Seq alignments into potential transcripts. It uses a novel network flow algorithm as well as an optional de novo assembly step to assemble and quantitate full-length transcripts representing multiple splice variants for each gene locus. It was designed as a successor to Cufflinks (its developers include some of the Cufflinks developers) and has many of the same features, but runs far faster and in far less memory. *'''TIGAR''' ''[https://github.com/nariai/tigar TIGAR]'' Transcript isoform abundance estimation method with gapped alignment of RNA-Seq data by variational Bayesian inference. *'''TimeSeq''' ''[http://rpackages.ianhowson.com/cran/timeSeq/ TimeSeq]'' - Detecting Differentially Expressed Genes in Time Course RNA-Seq Data. * '''WemIQ''' ''[http://www-rcf.usc.edu/~liangche/software.html WemIQ]''is a software tool to quantify isoform expression and exon splicing ratios from RNA-seq data accurately and robustly.
===Evaluation of quantification and differential expression=== * '''CompcodeR''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/compcodeR.html CompcodeR]''— RNAseq data simulation, differential expression analysis and performance comparison of differential expression methods. * '''DEAR-O''' ''[http://cnsgenomics.com/software/dear-o/ DEAR-O]'' : Differential Expression Analysis based on RNA-seq data – Online. * '''PROPER''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/PROPER.html PROPER]'': comprehensive power evaluation for differential expression using RNA-seq. *'''RNAontheBENCH''' ''[https://github.com/plger/RNAontheBENCH RNAontheBENCH]'': computational and empirical resources for benchmarking RNAseq quantification and differential expression methods. * '''rnaseqcomp''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/3.3/bioc/html/rnaseqcomp.html rnaseqcomp]''. Several quantitative and visualized benchmarks for RNA-seq quantification pipelines. Two-condition quantifications for genes, transcripts, junctions or exons by each pipeline with nessasery meta information should be organizd into numeric matrices in order to proceed the evaluation. * '''http://www.clipz.unibas.ch/benchmarking'''. Comparative assessment of methods for the computational inference of transcript isoform abundance from RNA-seq data.
===Multi-tool solutions=== *'''DEB''' ''[http://www.bioinformation.net/007/97320630007044.htm DEB]'' is a web-interface/pipeline that permits to compare results of significantly expressed genes from different tools. Currently are available three algorithms: edgeR, DESeq and bayseq. *'''SARTools''' ''[https://github.com/PF2-pasteur-fr/SARTools SARTools]'': A DESeq2- and EdgeR-Based R Pipeline for Comprehensive Differential Analysis of RNA-Seq Data.
==Workbench (analysis pipeline / integrated solutions)== ===Commercial solutions=== * '''ActiveSite by Cofactor Genomics ''' ''[http://cofactorgenomics.com/activesite/ ActiveSite]'' * '''Avadis NGS (currently Strand NGS) ''' ''[http://www.strand-ngs.com/ Strand NGS]''. * '''BaseSpace by Illumina ''' ''[http://basespace.illumina.com/ BaseSpace]'' * '''Biowardrobe''' ''[https://biowardrobe.com/ Biowardrobe]'' an integrated platform for analysis of epigenomics and transcriptomics data. * '''CLC Genomics Workbench ''' ''[http://www.clcbio.com/ CLC Genomics Workbench]'' * '''[[DNASTAR]] ''' ''[http://www.dnastar.com/t-sub-nextgen-genome-solutions-rnaseq.aspx DNASTAR]'' * '''ERGO ''' ''[http://www.igenbio.com ERGO]'' * '''[[Genedata]] ''' * '''GeneSpring GX ''' ''[http://www.genomics.agilent.com/CollectionSubpage.aspx?PageType=Product&SubPageType=ProductDetail&PageID=1675 GeneSpring GX]'' * '''Genevestigator by Nebion''' ''[http://www.genevestigator.com/ Genevestigator]'' A userfriendly platform for transcriptomic meta-analysis of public data. * '''geospiza''' ''[http://www.geospiza.com/ geospiza]'' * '''Golden Helix''' ''[http://www.goldenhelix.com/ Golden Helix]'' * '''Maverix Biomics''' ''[http://www.maverixbio.com/ Maverix Biomics]'' * '''NextGENe''' ''[http://www.softgenetics.com/NextGENe.html NextGENe]'' * '''OmicsOffice''' ''[http://www.omicsoffice.com/ OmicsOffice]'' * '''[[Qlucore]]'''. Easy to use for analysis and visualization. One button import of BAM files.
===Open (free) source solutions=== *'''ArrayExpressHTS''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/2.11/bioc/html/ArrayExpressHTS.html ArrayExpressHTS]'' (and ''[http://www.ebi.ac.uk/Tools/rwiki/Wiki.jsp?page=ArrayExpressHTS%20Main%20Page ebi_ArrayExpressHTS]'') is a BioConductor package that allows preprocessing, quality assessment and estimation of expression of RNA-Seq datasets. It can be run remotely at the European Bioinformatics Institute cloud or locally. The package makes use of several tools: ShortRead (quality control), Bowtie, TopHat or BWA (alignment to a reference genome), SAMtools format, Cufflinks or MMSEQ (expression estimation). *'''BioJupies''' ''[http://biojupies.cloud BioJupies]'' is a web-based platform that provides complete RNA-seq analysis solution from free alignment service to a complete data analysis report delivered as an interactive Jupyter Notebook. *'''BioQueue''' ''[http://www.bioqueue.org BioQueue]'' is a web-based queue engine designed preferentially to improve the efficiency and robustness of job execution in bioinformatics research by estimating the system resources required by a certain job. At the same time, BioQueue also aims to promote the accessibility and reproducibility of data analysis in biomedical research. Implemented by Python 2.7, BioQueue can work in both POSIX compatible systems (Linux, Solaris, OS X, etc.) and Windows. See also.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Yao L, Wang H, Song Y, Sui G | year = 2017 | title = BioQueue: a novel pipeline framework to accelerate bioinformatics analysis | url = http://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/33/20/3286/3870464/BioQueue-a-novel-pipeline-framework-to-accelerate | journal = Bioinformatics | volume = 33 | issue = 20| pages = 3286–3288 | doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btx403| pmid = 28633441 }}</ref> *'''BioWardrobe''' ''[http://biowardrobe.com BioWardrobe]'' is an integrated package that for analysis of ChIP-Seq and RNA-Seq datasets using a web-based user-friendly GUI. For RNA-Seq Biowardrobe performs mapping, quality control, RPKM estimation and differential expression analysis between samples (groups of samples). Results of differential expression analysis can be integrated with ChIP-Seq data to build average tag density profiles and heat maps. The package makes use of several tools open source tools including STAR and DESeq. See also.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kartashov AV, Barski A | year = 2015 | title = BioWardrobe: an integrated platform for analysis of epigenomics and transcriptomics data | url = http://www.genomebiology.com/2015/16/1/158 | journal = Genome Biology | volume = 16 | issue = 1| page = 158 | doi=10.1186/s13059-015-0720-3| pmid = 26248465 | pmc = 4531538 }}</ref> *'''Chipster''' ''[http://chipster.csc.fi/ Chipster]''. Chipster is a user-friendly analysis software for high-throughput data. It contains over 350 analysis tools for next generation sequencing (NGS), microarray, proteomics and sequence data. Users can save and share automatic analysis workflows, and visualize data interactively using a built-in genome browser and many other visualizations. *'''DEWE''' ''[http://www.sing-group.org/dewe DEWE]''. DEWE (Differential Expression Workflow Executor) is an open source desktop application that provides a user-friendly GUI for easily executing Differential Expression analyses in RNA-Seq data. Currently, DEWE provides two differential expression analysis workflows: HISAT2, StringTie and Ballgown and Bowtie2, StringTie and R libraries (Ballgown and edgeR). It runs in Linux, Windows and Mac OS X. *'''easyRNASeq''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.11/bioc/html/easyRNASeq.html easyRNASeq]''. Calculates the coverage of high-throughput short-reads against a genome of reference and summarizes it per feature of interest (e.g. exon, gene, transcript). The data can be normalized as 'RPKM' or by the 'DESeq' or 'edgeR' package. *'''ExpressionPlot''' ''[http://blog.expressionplot.com/ ExpressionPlot]''. *'''FX''' ''[http://fx.gmi.ac.kr/ FX]''. FX is a user-Frendly RNA-Seq gene eXpression analysis tool, empowered by the concept of cloud-computing. With FX, you can simply upload your RNA-Seq raw FASTQ data on the cloud, and let the computing infra to do the heavy analysis. *'''[[Galaxy (computational biology)|Galaxy]]''': Galaxy is a general purpose workbench platform for computational biology. There are several [http://wiki.galaxyproject.org/PublicGalaxyServers publicly accessible Galaxy servers] that support RNA-Seq tools and workflows, including [[Netherlands Bioinformatics Centre|NBIC's]] [http://galaxy.nbic.nl/ Andromeda], the [http://galaxy.cbiit.cuhk.edu.hk/ CBIIT-Giga] server, the [[Galaxy (computational biology)|Galaxy Project's]] [http://usegalaxy.org/ public server], the [[GeneNetwork]] [http://galaxy.genenetwork.org/ Galaxy server], the [[University of Oslo]]'s [http://hyperbrowser.uio.no/hb/ Genomic Hyperbrowser], [[URGI]]'s [http://urgi.versailles.inra.fr/galaxy server] (which supports S-MART), and many others. *'''GENE-Counter''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/genecounter/ GENE-Counter]'' is a Perl pipeline for RNA-Seq differential gene expression analyses. Gene-counter performs alignments with CASHX, Bowtie, BWA or other SAM output aligner. Differential gene expression is run with three optional packages (NBPSeq, edgeR and DESeq) using negative binomial distribution methods. Results are stored in a [[MySQL]] database to make possible additional analyses. *'''GenePattern''' ''[http://www.broadinstitute.org/cancer/software/genepattern/modules/RNA-seq/ GenePattern]'' offers integrated solutions to RNA-Seq analysis ([[Broad Institute]]). *'''GeneProf''' [http://www.geneprof.org GeneProf]: Freely accessible, easy to use analysis pipelines for RNA-seq and ChIP-seq experiments. *'''GREIN''' ''[https://shiny.ilincs.org/grein/ GREIN]'' is an interactive web platform for re-processing and re-analyzing GEO RNA-seq data. GREIN is powered by the back-end computational pipeline for uniform processing of RNA-seq data and the large number (>5,800) of already processed data sets. The front-end user friendly interfaces provide a wealth of user-analytics options including sub-setting and downloading processed data, interactive visualization, statistical power analyses, construction of differential gene expression signatures and their comprehensive functional characterization, connectivity analysis with LINCS L1000 data, etc. *'''GT-FAR''' ''[http://genomics.isi.edu/gtfar GT-FAR]'' is an RNA seq pipeline that performs RNA-seq QC, alignment, reference free quantification, and splice variant calling. It filters, trims, and sequentially aligns reads to gene models and predicts and validates new splice junctions after which it quantifies expression for each gene, exon, and known/novel splice junction, and Variant Calling. *'''MultiExperiment Viewer (MeV)''' ''[http://www.tm4.org/mev/?q=about MeV]'' is suitable to perform analysis, data mining and visualization of large-scale genomic data. The MeV modules include a variety of algorithms to execute tasks like Clustering and Classification, [[Student's t-test]], [http://www.broadinstitute.org/gsea/index.jsp Gene Set Enrichment Analysis] or Significance Analysis. MeV runs on [[Java (software platform)|Java]]. See also ''[http://seqanswers.com/wiki/MeV seqanswers/MeV]''. *'''NGSUtils''' ''[http://ngsutils.org/ NGSUtils]''. NGSUtils is a suite of software tools for working with next-generation sequencing datasets. *'''Rail-RNA''' ''[https://github.com/nellore/rail Rail-Rna]''. Scalable analysis of RNA-seq splicing and coverage. *'''RAP''' - RNA-Seq Analysis Pipeline, a new cloud-based NGS web application. *'''RSEQtools''' ''[http://archive.gersteinlab.org/proj/rnaseq/rseqtools/ RSEQtools]''. "RSEQtools consists of a set of modules that perform common tasks such as calculating gene expression values, generating signal tracks of mapped reads, and segmenting that signal into actively transcribed regions. In addition to the anonymization afforded by this format it also facilitates the decoupling of the alignment of reads from downstream analyses." *'''RobiNA''' ''[http://mapman.gabipd.org/web/guest/robin RobiNA]'' provides a user graphical interface to deal with R/BioConductor packages. RobiNA provides a package that automatically installs all required external tools (R/Bioconductor frameworks and [[Bowtie]]). This tool offers a diversity of quality control methods and the possibility to produce many tables and plots supplying detailed results for differential expression. Furthermore, the results can be visualized and manipulated with ''[http://mapman.gabipd.org/web/guest/mapman MapMan]'' and ''[http://mapman.gabipd.org/web/guest/pageman PageMan]''. RobiNA runs on [[Java (software platform)|Java]] version 6. *'''RseqFlow''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/rseqflow RseqFlow]'' is an RNA-Seq analysis pipeline which offers an express implementation of analysis steps for RNA sequencing datasets. It can perform pre and post mapping quality control (QC) for sequencing data, calculate expression levels for uniquely mapped reads, identify differentially expressed genes, and convert file formats for ease of visualization. *'''S-MART''' ''[http://urgi.versailles.inra.fr/Tools/S-Mart S-MART]'' handles mapped RNA-Seq data, and performs essentially data manipulation (selection/exclusion of reads, clustering and differential expression analysis) and visualization (read information, distribution, comparison with epigenomic ChIP-Seq data). It can be run on any laptop by a person without computer background. A friendly graphical user interface makes easy the operation of the tools. *'''[[Taverna workbench|Taverna]]''' ''[http://www.taverna.org.uk/ Taverna]''. Taverna is an open source and domain-independent Workflow Management System – a suite of tools used to design and execute scientific workflows and aid in silico experimentation. *'''TCW''' ''[http://www.agcol.arizona.edu/software/tcw/ TCW]''. TCW is a Transcriptome Computational Workbench. * '''TRAPLINE''' ''[https://www.sbi.uni-rostock.de/RNAseqTRAPLINE TRAPLINE]'': a standardized and automated pipeline for RNA sequencing data analysis, evaluation and annotation. *'''ViennaNGS''' ''[https://github.com/mtw/Bio-ViennaNGS ViennaNGS]''. A toolbox for building efficient next- generation sequencing analysis pipelines. *'''wapRNA''' ''[http://waprna.big.ac.cn/ wapRNA]''. This is a free web-based application for the processing of high-throughput RNA-Seq data (wapRNA) from next generation sequencing (NGS) platforms, such as Genome Analyzer of Illumina Inc. (Solexa) and SOLiD of Applied Biosystems (SOLiD). wapRNA provides an integrated tool for RNA sequence, refers to the use of High-throughput sequencing technologies to sequence cDNAs in order to get information about a sample's RNA content.
==Alternative splicing analysis== ===General tools=== *'''Alternative Splicing Analysis Tool Package(ASATP)''' ''[https://github.com/Z-G-L/ASATP ASATP]''. Alternative splicing analysis tool package (ASATP) includes a series of toolkits to analyze alternative splicing events, which could be used to detect and visualized alternative splicing events, check ORF changes, assess regulations of alternative splicing and do statistical analysis. *'''Asprofile''' ''[http://ccb.jhu.edu/software/ASprofile/ asprofile]''. ASprofile is a suite of programs for extracting, quantifying and comparing alternative splicing (AS) events from RNA-seq data. *'''AStalavista''' ''[http://genome.crg.es/astalavista/ AStalavista]''. The AStalavista web server extracts and displays alternative splicing (AS) events from a given genomic annotation of exon-intron gene coordinates. By comparing all given transcripts, AStalavista detects the variations in their splicing structure and identify all AS events (like exon skipping, alternate donor, etc.) by assigning to each of them an AS code. *'''CLASS2''' ''[https://sourceforge.net/p/splicebox/wiki/Home/ Class]'': accurate and efficient splice variant annotation from RNA-seq reads. *'''Cufflinks/Cuffdiff''' ''[http://cufflinks.cbcb.umd.edu/ Cufflinks]''. *'''DEXseq''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/DEXSeq.html DEXseq]''. Inference of differential exon usage in RNA-Seq. *'''Diceseq''' ''[http://diceseq.sf.net Diceseq]'' - Statistical modeling of isoform splicing dynamics from RNA-seq time series data. *'''EBChangepoint''' ''[http://ebchangepoint.sourceforge.net/ EBChangepoint]'' An empirical Bayes change-point model for identifying 3′ and 5′ alternative splicing by RNA-Seq. *'''Eoulsan''' ''[http://outils.genomique.biologie.ens.fr/eoulsan2/ Eoulsan]'' A versatile framework dedicated to high throughput sequencing data analysis. Allows automated analysis (mapping, counting and differencial analysis with DESeq2). *'''GESS''' ''[http://motif.bmi.ohio-state.edu/GESS_Web/ GESS]'' – for de novo detection of exon-skipping event sites from raw RNA-seq reads. *'''LeafCutter''' ''[https://github.com/davidaknowles/leafcutter LeaffCutter]'', a suite of novel methods that allow identification and quantication of novel and existing alternative splicing events by focusing on intron excisions. *'''LEMONS''' <ref name=Evin2015>{{cite journal|journal=PLoS ONE |volume=10| year=2015|vauthors=evin L, Bar-Yaacov D, Bouskila A, Chorev M, Carmel L, Mishmar D | pmid=26606265| title= LEMONS – A Tool for the Identification of Splice Junctions in Transcriptomes of Organisms Lacking Reference Genomes.|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0143329 | issue=11| pages=e0143329 | pmc=4659627|bibcode=2015PLoSO..1043329L}}</ref> A Tool for the Identification of Splice Junctions in Transcriptomes of Organisms Lacking Reference Genomes. *'''MAJIQ''' ''[http://majiq.biociphers.org/ MAJIQ]''. Modeling Alternative Junction Inclusion Quantification. *'''MATS''' ''[http://rnaseq-mats.sourceforge.net/ MATS]''. Multivariate Analysis of Transcript Splicing (MATS). *'''MISO''' ''[http://genes.mit.edu/burgelab/miso/ MISO]'' quantifies the expression level of splice variants from RNA-Seq data and is able to recognize differentially regulated exons/isoforms across different samples. MISO uses a probabilistic method (Bayesian inference) to calculate the probability of the reads origin. *'''Rail-RNA''' ''[https://github.com/nellore/rail Rail-Rna]''. Scalable analysis of RNA-seq splicing and coverage. *'''RPASuite''' <ref name=Pundhir2015>{{cite journal|journal=Scientific Reports | year=2015|vauthors=Pundhir S, Gorodkin J | title= Differential and coherent processing patterns from small RNAs.|pmid= 26166713 |doi=10.1038/srep12062 | volume=5| pages=12062 | pmc=4499813|bibcode=2015NatSR...512062P}}</ref> ''[http://rth.dk/resources/rpa/ RPASuite]''. RPASuite (RNA Processing Analysis Suite) is a computational pipeline to identify differentially and coherently processed transcripts using RNA-seq data obtained from multiple tissue or cell lines. *'''RSVP''' ''[https://ohlerlab.mdc-berlin.de/software/RNA-seq_Variant_Prediction_61/RSVP RSVP]''. RSVP is a software package for prediction of alternative isoforms of protein-coding genes, based on both genomic DNA evidence and aligned RNA-seq reads. The method is based on the use of ORF graphs, which are more general than the splice graphs used in traditional transcript assembly. *'''SAJR''' ''[http://storage.bioinf.fbb.msu.ru/~mazin/ SAJR]'' calculates the number of the reads that confirms segment (part of gene between two nearest splice sites) inclusion or exclusion and then model these counts by GLM with quasibinomial distribution to account for biological variability. *'''SGSeq''' ''[https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/SGSeq.html SGSeq]'' A R package to de novo prediction of splicing events. *'''SplAdder''' ''[https://github.com/ratschlab/spladder SplAdder]'' Identification, quantification and testing of alternative splicing events from RNA-Seq data. *'''SpliceGrapher''' ''[http://splicegrapher.sourceforge.net/ SpliceGrapher]'' Prediction of novel alternative splicing events from RNA-Seq data.<ref>http://genomebiology.com/content/pdf/gb-2012-13-1-r4.pdf</ref> *'''SpliceJumper''' ''[https://github.com/Reedwarbler/SpliceJumper SpliceJumper]'': a classification-based approach for calling splicing junctions from RNA-seq data. *'''SplicePie''' ''[https://github.com/pulyakhina/splicing_analysis_pipeline SplicePie]''is a pipeline to analyze non-sequential and multi-step splicing. SplicePie contains three major analysis steps: analyzing the order of splicing per sample, looking for recursive splicing events per sample and summarizing predicted recursive splicing events for all analyzed sample (it is recommended to use more samples for higher reliability). The first two steps are performed individually on each sample and the last step looks at the overlap in all samples. However, the analysis can be run on one sample as well. *'''SplicePlot''' ''[http://montgomerylab.stanford.edu/spliceplot/ SplicePlot]''. SplicePlot is a tool for visualizing alternative splicing and the effects of splicing quantitative trait loci (sQTLs) from RNA-seq data. It provides a simple command line interface for drawing sashimi plots, hive plots, and structure plots of alternative splicing events from .bam, .gtf, and .vcf files. *'''SpliceR''' ''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/2.13/bioc/html/spliceR.html SpliceR]''. An R package for classification of alternative splicing and prediction of coding potential from RNA-seq data. *'''SpliceSEQ''' ''[http://bioinformatics.mdanderson.org/main/SpliceSeq:Overview SpliceSeq]''. SpliceViewer is a Java application that allows researchers to investigate alternative mRNA splicing patterns in data from high-throughput mRNA sequencing studies. Sequence reads are mapped to splice graphs that unambiguously quantify the inclusion level of each exon and splice junction. The graphs are then traversed to predict the protein isoforms that are likely to result from the observed exon and splice junction reads. UniProt annotations are mapped to each protein isoform to identify potential functional impacts of alternative splicing. *'''SpliceTrap'''<ref name=JieWu2011>{{cite journal|journal= Bioinformatics |volume=27| year=2011| author=Wu, J. et al| pmid=21896509| title= SpliceTrap: a method to quantify alternative splicing under single cellular conditions |url= https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/27/21/3010/217325/SpliceTrap-a-method-to-quantify-alternative |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btr508| issue=21| pages=3010–3016|pmc=3198574}}</ref> ''[http://rulai.cshl.edu/splicetrap/ SpliceTrap]'' is a statistical tool for the quantification of exon inclusion ratios from RNA-seq data. *'''Splicing Express''' – a software suite for alternative splicing analysis using next-generation sequencing data. *'''SUPPA''' ''[https://bitbucket.org/regulatorygenomicsupf/suppa Suppa]''. This tool generates different Alternative Splicing (AS) events and calculates the PSI ("Percentage Spliced In") value for each event exploiting the fast quantification of transcript abundances from multiple samples. *'''SwitchSeq''' ''[https://github.com/mgonzalezporta/SwitchSeq SwitchSeq]'' identifies extreme changes in splicing (switch events). *'''Portcullis''' ''[https://github.com/maplesond/portcullis Portcullis]'' - identification of genuine splice junctions. *'''TrueSight''' ''[http://bioen-compbio.bioen.illinois.edu/TrueSight/ TrueSight]'' A Self-training Algorithm for Splice Junction Detection using RNA-seq. *'''Vast-tools''' ''[https://github.com/vastgroup/vast-tools vast-tools]''A toolset for profiling alternative splicing events in RNA-Seq data.
===Intron retention analysis=== *'''IRcall / IRclassifier''' ''[http://mlg.hit.edu.cn/ybai/IR/IRcallAndIRclass.html IRcall / IRclassifier]''. IRcall is a computational tool for IR event detection from RNA-Seq data. IRclassifier is a supervised machine learning-based approach for IR event detection from RNA-Seq data.
=== Differential isoform/transcript usage === * '''IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR''' [http://bioconductor.org/packages/IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR/ ''IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR'']. IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR is an R package that enables statistical identification of isoform switches with predicted functional consequences where the consequences of interest can be chosen from a long list but includes gain/loss of protein domains, signal peptides changes in NMD sensitivity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vitting-Seerup|first=Kristoffer|last2=Sandelin|first2=Albin|date=2017-01-01|title=The Landscape of Isoform Switches in Human Cancers|url=http://mcr.aacrjournals.org/content/early/2017/06/02/1541-7786.MCR-16-0459|journal=Molecular Cancer Research|volume=15|issue=9|language=en|pages=1206–1220|doi=10.1158/1541-7786.mcr-16-0459|issn=1541-7786|pmid=28584021}}</ref> IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR is made for post analysis of data from any full length isoform/transcript quantification tool but directly support [https://cole-trapnell-lab.github.io/cufflinks/ Cufflinks/Cuffdiff], [https://deweylab.github.io/RSEM/ RSEM] [https://pachterlab.github.io/kallisto/about.html Kallisto] and [https://github.com/kingsfordgroup/sailfish/tree/develop Salmon]. * '''DRIMSeq''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/DRIMSeq/ DRIMSeq].'' An R package that utilizes [[generalized linear model]]ing (GLM) to identify isoform switches from estimated isoform count data.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nowicka|first=Malgorzata|last2=Robinson|first2=Mark D.|date=2016-12-06|title=DRIMSeq: a Dirichlet-multinomial framework for multivariate count outcomes in genomics|url=https://f1000research.com/articles/5-1356/v2|journal=F1000Research|volume=5|doi=10.12688/f1000research.8900.2|pmc=5200948|pmid=28105305|page=1356}}</ref> * '''BayesDRIMSeq''' [https://github.com/mqbssppe/BayesDRIMSeq BayesDRIMSeq]. An R package conatining a [[Bayesian statistics|Bayesian]] implementation of DRIMSeq.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Papastamoulis|first=Panagiotis|last2=Rattray|first2=Magnus|date=2017-01-11|title=Bayesian estimation of Differential Transcript Usage from RNA-seq data|journal=Statistical Applications in Genetics and Molecular Biology|volume=16|issue=5–6|pages=367–386|arxiv=1701.03095|doi=10.1515/sagmb-2017-0005|pmid=29091583}}</ref> * '''Cufflinks/Cuffdiff''' [https://cole-trapnell-lab.github.io/cufflinks/ Cufflinks/Cuffdiff]. Full length isoform/transcript quantification and differential analysis tool which amongst other test for changes in usage for isoform belonging to the same primary transcript (sharing a TSS) via a one-sided t-test based on the asymptotic of the Jensen-Shannon metric.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Trapnell|first=Cole|last2=Williams|first2=Brian A.|last3=Pertea|first3=Geo|last4=Mortazavi|first4=Ali|last5=Kwan|first5=Gordon|last6=van Baren|first6=Marijke J.|last7=Salzberg|first7=Steven L.|last8=Wold|first8=Barbara J.|last9=Pachter|first9=Lior|date=May 2010|title=Transcript assembly and quantification by RNA-Seq reveals unannotated transcripts and isoform switching during cell differentiation|journal=Nature Biotechnology|volume=28|issue=5|pages=511–515|doi=10.1038/nbt.1621|issn=1546-1696|pmc=3146043|pmid=20436464}}</ref> * '''rSeqNP''' [http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jianghui/rseqnp/ rSeqNP]. An R package that implements a non-parametric approach to test for differential expression and splicing from RNA-Seq data.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shi|first=Yang|last2=Chinnaiyan|first2=Arul M.|last3=Jiang|first3=Hui|date=2015-07-01|title=rSeqNP: a non-parametric approach for detecting differential expression and splicing from RNA-Seq data|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=31|issue=13|pages=2222–2224|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btv119|issn=1367-4811|pmc=4481847|pmid=25717189}}</ref> * '''Isolator''' [https://github.com/dcjones/isolator Isolator]. Full length isoform/transcript quantification and differential analysis tool which analyses all samples in an experiment in unison using a simple Bayesian hierarchical model. Can identify differential isoform usage by testing for probability of monotonic splicing.<ref>{{cite biorxiv|last=Jones|first=Daniel C.|last2=Kuppusamy|first2=Kavitha T.|last3=Palpant|first3=Nathan J.|last4=Peng|first4=Xinxia|last5=Murry|first5=Charles E.|last6=Ruohola-Baker|first6=Hannele|last7=Ruzzo|first7=Walter L.|date=2016-11-20|title=Isolator: accurate and stable analysis of isoform-level expression in RNA-Seq experiments|biorxiv=088765}}</ref>
==Fusion genes/chimeras/translocation finders/structural variations== Genome arrangements result of diseases like cancer can produce aberrant genetic modifications like fusions or translocations. Identification of these modifications play important role in carcinogenesis studies.<ref name=Kumar2016>{{cite journal|journal= Scientific Reports |volume=6| year=2016|author1=Shailesh Kumar |author2=Angie Duy Vo |author3=Fujun Qin |author4=Hui Li | pmid=26862001| title= Comparative assessment of methods for the fusion transcripts detection from RNA-Seq data|url= http://www.nature.com/articles/srep21597 |doi= 10.1038/srep21597 | issue=21587| pages=21597 | pmc=4748267|bibcode=2016NatSR...621597K}}</ref> * '''Arriba''' ''[https://github.com/suhrig/arriba/ Arriba]'' is an ultrafast fusion detection algorithm based on the STAR<ref name="dobin2013"/> RNA-Seq aligner. The post-alignment runtime typically takes just two minutes. In terms of accuracy, Arriba is the best-performing algorithm in the ongoing DREAM Challenge<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.synapse.org/SMC_RNA | title=Synapse | Sage Bionetworks}}</ref> about fusion detection (as of the 4th round). Apart from gene fusions, Arriba can detect other structural rearrangements, such as exon duplications or truncations of genes (i.e., breakpoints in introns and intergenic regions). * '''Bellerophontes''' * '''BreakDancer''' ''[http://breakdancer.sourceforge.net/ BreakDancer]''. * '''BreakFusion''' * '''ChimeraScan''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/chimerascan/ ChimeraScan]''. * '''DeFuse''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/apps/mediawiki/defuse/index.php?title=DeFuse DeFuse]''. DeFuse is a software package for gene fusion discovery using RNA-Seq data. * '''EBARDenovo''' ''[http://ebardenovo.sourceforge.net/ EBARDenovo]''. * '''EricScript''' *'''FusionAnalyser''' ''[http://www.ilte-cml.org/FusionAnalyser/ FusionAnalyser]''. FusionAnalyser uses paired reads mapping to different genes (Bridge reads), generated through high-throughput whole transcriptome sequencing, to build a first dataset of candidate fusion events. Subsequently, a second dataset, built upon those reads where only one of the two sequences in a pair is successfully mapped to the reference genome (‘Half-mapped Anchor reads’), is generated. The mapped reads in the latter dataset are used as an anchor to tie each Half-mapped event to the corresponding Bridge region. * '''FusionCatcher''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/fusioncatcher/ FusionCatcher]''. FusionCatcher searches for novel/known somatic fusion genes, translocations, and chimeras in RNA-seq data (stranded/unstranded paired-end reads from Illumina NGS platforms like Solexa/HiSeq/NextSeq/MiSeq) from diseased samples. * '''FusionHunter''' ''[http://bioen-compbio.bioen.illinois.edu/FusionHunter/ FusionHunter]'' identifies fusion transcripts without depending on already known annotations. It uses Bowtie as a first aligner and paired-end reads. * '''FusionMap''' ''[http://www.omicsoft.com/fusionmap FusionMap]''. FusionMap is an efficient fusion aligner which aligns reads spanning fusion junctions directly to the genome without prior knowledge of potential fusion regions. It detects and characterizes fusion junctions at base-pair resolution. FusionMap can be applied to detect fusion junctions in both single- and paired-end dataset from either gDNA-Seq or RNA-Seq studies. * '''FusionSeq''' ''[http://archive.gersteinlab.org/proj/rnaseq/fusionseq/ FusionSeq]''. * '''JAFFA''' ''[https://github.com/Oshlack/JAFFA/wiki JAFFA]'' is based on the idea of comparing a transcriptome against a reference transcriptome rather than a genome-centric approach like other fusion finders''. * '''MapSplice'''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=K|last2=Singh|first2=D|last3=Zeng|first3=Z|last4=Coleman|first4=SJ|last5=Huang|first5=Y|last6=Savich|first6=GL|last7=He|first7=X|last8=Mieczkowski|first8=P|last9=Grimm|first9=SA|last10=Perou|first10=CM|last11=MacLeod|first11=JN|last12=Chiang|first12=DY|last13=Prins|first13=JF|last14=Liu|first14=J|title=MapSplice: accurate mapping of RNA-seq reads for splice junction discovery.|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=October 2010|volume=38|issue=18|pages=e178|doi=10.1093/nar/gkq622|pmid=20802226|pmc=2952873}}</ref> * '''nFuse''' * '''Oncomine''' ''[http://www.thermofisher.com/uk/en/home/life-science/cancer-research/cancer-genomics/cancer-genomics-data-analysis-compendia-bioscience/oncomine-cancer-genomics-data-analysis-tools/oncomine-ngs-power-tools.html?CID=fl-we112680 Oncomine]'' - NGS RNA-Seq Gene Expression Browser. * '''PRADA''' ''[http://bioinformatics.mdanderson.org/main/PRADA:Overview prada]''. * '''SOAPFuse''' ''[http://soap.genomics.org.cn/soapfuse.html SOAPFuse]'' detects fusion transcripts from human paired-end RNA-Seq data. It outperforms other five similar tools in both computation and fusion detection performance using both real and simulated data.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jia|first1=W|last2=Qiu|first2=K|last3=He|first3=M|last4=Song|first4=P|last5=Zhou|first5=Q|last6=Zhou|first6=F|last7=Yu|first7=Y|last8=Zhu|first8=D|last9=Nickerson|first9=ML|last10=Wan|first10=S|last11=Liao|first11=X|last12=Zhu|first12=X|last13=Peng|first13=S|last14=Li|first14=Y|last15=Wang|first15=J|last16=Guo|first16=G|title=SOAPfuse: an algorithm for identifying fusion transcripts from paired-end RNA-Seq data|journal=Genome Biology|date=2013|volume=14|issue=2|page=R12|doi=10.1186/gb-2013-14-2-r12|pmid=23409703|url=http://genomebiology.com/2013/14/2/R12|pmc=4054009}}</ref> * '''SOAPfusion''' [http://soap.genomics.org.cn/SOAPfusion.html Soapf''usion'']''.'' * '''TopHat-Fusion''' ''[http://tophat.cbcb.umd.edu/fusion_index.html TopHat-Fusion]'' is based on TopHat version and was developed to handle reads resulting from fusion genes. It does not require previous data about known genes and uses Bowtie to align continuous reads. * '''ViralFusionSeq''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/viralfusionseq/ ViralFusionSeq]'' is high-throughput sequencing (HTS) tool for discovering viral integration events and reconstruct fusion transcripts at single-base resolution. See also ''[http://www.hkbic.cuhk.edu.hk/software/viralfusionseq hkbic/VFS]''. * '''ViReMa''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/virema/ ViReMa]'' (Viral Recombination Mapper) detects and reports recombination or fusion events in and between virus and host genomes using deep sequencing datasets.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Routh|first1=A|last2=Johnson|first2=JE|title=Discovery of functional genomic motifs in viruses with ViReMa-a Virus Recombination Mapper-for analysis of next-generation sequencing data.|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=January 2014|volume=42|issue=2|pages=e11|doi=10.1093/nar/gkt916|pmid=24137010|pmc=3902915}}</ref>
==Copy number variation identification== * '''CNVseq''' ''[http://tiger.dbs.nus.edu.sg/CNV-seq/ CNVseq]'' detects [[copy number variations]] supported on a statistical model derived from [[array-comparative genomic hybridization]]. Sequences alignment are performed by BLAT, calculations are executed by R modules and is fully automated using Perl.
==Single cell RNA-Seq== [[Single cell sequencing]]. The traditional RNA-Seq methodology is commonly known as "bulk RNA-Seq", in this case RNA is extracted from a group of cells or tissues, not from the individual cell like it happens in single cell methods. Some tools available to bulk RNA-Seq are also applied to single cell analysis, however to face the specificity of this technique new algorithms were developed. Comparative analysis of single-cell RNA-sequencing methods.<ref name=Christop2016>{{cite biorxiv | year=2016|author1=Christoph Ziegenhain |author2=Swati Parekh |author3=Beate Vieth |author4=Martha Smets |author5=Heinrich Leonhardt |author6=Ines Hellmann |author7=Wolfgang Enard |title= Comparative analysis of single-cell RNA-sequencing methods |biorxiv=035758}}</ref> A list of Single Cell tools can be found at ''[https://github.com/seandavi/awesome-single-cell Awesome Single Cell].
* '''CEL-Seq''' ''[http://yanailab.technion.ac.il/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=84&FID=722&PID=1444 CEL-Seq]'':<ref name=Tamar2012>{{cite journal|journal=Cell Reports |volume=2| year=2012|author1=Tamar Hashimshony |author2=Florian Wagner |author3=Noa Sher |author4=Itai Yanai | pmid=22939981| title= CEL-Seq: Single-Cell RNA-Seq by Multiplexed Linear Amplification |url= http://www.cell.com/cell-reports/abstract/S2211-1247(12)00228-8 |doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2012.08.003| issue=3| pages=666–673}}</ref> single-cell RNA-Seq by multiplexed linear amplification. *'''Drop-Seq''' ''[http://mccarrolllab.com/dropseq/ Drop-Seq]'':<ref name=Evan2015>{{cite journal|journal= Cell|volume=161| year=2015|author1=Evan Z. |doi=10.1016/j.cell.2015.05.002 | issue=5| pages=1202–1214 | pmc=4481139}}</ref> Highly Parallel Genome-wide Expression Profiling of Individual Cells Using Nanoliter Droplets. *'''FISSEQ''' FP |author4=Proserpio V |author5=Scialdone A |author6=Theis FJ |author7=Teichmann SA |author8=Marioni JC |author9=Stegle O | pmid=25599176| title = Computational analysis of cell-to-cell heterogeneity in single-cell RNA-Sequencing data reveals hidden subpopulation of cells |url= http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v33/n2/full/nbt.3102.html |doi=10.1038/nbt.3102| issue=2| pages=155–160}}</ref> scLVM name=Monzoorul2010>{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics |volume=27| year=2011 |author1=Monzoorul Haque M |author2=Tarini Shankar Ghosh |author3=Nitin Kumar Singh |author4=Sharmila S Mande | binning process. SPHINX can analyze sequences in metagenomic data sets as rapidly as composition based approaches, but nevertheless has the accuracy and specificity of similarity based algorithms. *'''TraCeR''' [https://github.com/Teichlab/tracer TraCeR]:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stubbington|first=Michael JT|last2=Lönnberg|first2=Tapio|last3=Proserpio|first3=Valentina|last4=Clare|first4=Simon|last5=Speak|first5=Anneliese O|last6=Dougan|first6=Gordon|last7=Teichmann|first7=Sarah A|title=T cell fate and clonality inference from single-cell transcriptomes|url=http://www.nature.com/nmeth/journal/v13/n4/nmeth.3800|journal=Nature Methods|doi=10.1038/nmeth.3800|volume=13|issue=4|pages=329–332|pmid=26950746|pmc=4835021|year=2016}}</ref> Paired T-cell receptor reconstruction from single-cell RNA-Seq reads. *'''VDJPuzzle''' [https://github.com/Simo-88/VDJPuzzle VDJPuzzle]:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eltahla|first=Auda A|last2=Rizzetto|first2=Simone|last3=Pirozyan|first3=Mehdi R|last4=Betz-Stablein|first4=Brigid D|last5=Venturi|first5=Vanessa|last6=Kedzierska|first6=Katherine|last7=Lloyd|first7=Andrew R|last8=Bull|first8=Rowena A|last9=Luciani|first9=Fabio|title=Linking the T cell receptor to the single cell transcriptome in antigen-specific human T cells|journal=Immunology and Cell Biology|volume=94|issue=6|pages=604–11|doi=10.1038/icb.2016.16|pmid=26860370|year=2016}}</ref> T-cell receptor reconstruction from single-cell RNA-Seq reads and link the clonotype with the functional phenotype and transcriptome of individual cells.

===Quality Control and Gene Filtering=== *'''Celloline''' ''[https://github.com/Teichlab/celloline Celloline]'' A pipeline for mapping and quality assessment single cell RNA-seq data. *'''OEFinder''' ''[https://github.com/lengning/OEFinder OEFinder]. A user interface to identify and visualize ordering effects in single-cell RNA-seq data. *'''SinQC''' ''[http://www.morgridge.net/SinQC.html SinQC]'' A Method and Tool to Control Single-cell RNA-seq Data Quality.
===Normalization=== *'''BASICS''' ''[https://github.com/catavallejos/BASiCS BASICS]''. Understanding changes in gene expression at the single-cell level. *'''GRM''' ''[http://wanglab.ucsd.edu/star/GRM/ GRM]'' - Normalization and noise reduction for single cell RNA-seq experiments.
