===Differential Expression=== *'''BPSC''' ''[https://github.com/nghiavtr/BPSC BPSC]'' An R package BPSC for model fitting and differential expression analyses of single-cell RNA-seq. *'''MAST''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/help/course-materials/2016/BioC2016/ConcurrentWorkshops2/McDavid/MAITAnalysis.html MAST]'' : a flexible statistical framework for assessing transcriptional changes and characterizing heterogeneity in single-cell RNA sequencing data. *'''SCDE''' ''[http://pklab.med.harvard.edu/scde/ SCDE]''. Characterizing transcriptional heterogeneity through pathway and gene set overdispersion analysis.
===Clustering=== ===Pseudo-time Construction=== ===Visualization=== * '''eXpose'''
==RNA-Seq simulators== These Simulators generate ''in silico'' reads and are useful tools to compare and test the efficiency of algorithms developed to handle RNA-Seq data. Moreover, some of them make possible to analyse and model RNA-Seq protocols.See also ''[https://popmodels.cancercontrol.cancer.gov/gsr/packages/ Genetic Simulation Resources]'' and some discussion about simulation at ''[https://www.biostars.org/p/4143/ Biostars]''.
* '''BEERS Simulator''' ''[http://www.cbil.upenn.edu/BEERS/ BEERS]'' is formatted to mouse or human data, and paired-end reads sequenced on Illumina platform. Beers generates reads starting from a pool of gene models coming from different published annotation origins. Some genes are chosen randomly and afterwards are introduced deliberately errors (like indels, base changes and low quality tails), followed by construction of novel splice junctions. *'''compcodeR''' ''[https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/compcodeR.html compcodeR]'' RNAseq data simulation, differential expression analysis and performance comparison of differential expression methods. *'''CuReSim''' ''[http://www.pegase-biosciences.com/curesim-a-customized-read-simulator/ Curesim]'': a customized read simulator. *'''Flux simulator''' ''[http://sammeth.net/confluence/display/SIM/Home Flux Simulator]'' implements a computer pipeline simulation to mimic a RNA-Seq experiment. All component steps that influence RNA-Seq are taken into account (reverse transcription, fragmentation, adapter ligation, PCR amplification, gel segregation and sequencing) in the simulation. These steps present experimental attributes that can be measured, and the approximate experimental biases are captured. Flux Simulator allows joining each of these steps as modules to analyse different type of protocols. *'''PBSIM''' ''[https://code.google.com/archive/p/pbsim/ PBSIM]'' - PacBio reads simulator - toward accurate genome assembly. * '''Polyester''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/polyester.html Polyester]''. This bioconductor package can be used to simulate RNA-seq reads from differential expression experiments with replicates. The reads can then be aligned and used to perform comparisons of methods for differential expression. * '''RandomReads''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/bbmap/ RandomReads]'' Generates synthetic reads from a genome with an Illumina or PacBio error model. The reads may be paired or unpaired, with arbitrary length and insert size, output in fasta or fastq, RandomReads has a wide selection of options for mutation rates, with individual settings for substitution, deletion, insertion, and N rates and length distributions, annotating reads with their original, unmutated genomic start and stop location. RandomReads is does not vary expression levels and thus is not designed to simulate RNA-seq experiments, but to test the sensitivity and specificity of RNA-seq aligners with de-novo introns. Includes a tool for grading and generating ROC curves from resultant sam files. Open-source, written in pure Java; supports all platforms with no recompilation and no other dependencies. Distributed with BBMap. * '''rlsim''' ''[https://github.com/sbotond/rlsim rlsim]'' is a software package for simulating RNA-seq library preparation with parameter estimation. *'''rnaseqbenchmark''' ''[http://rafalab.rc.fas.harvard.edu/rnaseqbenchmark rnaseqbenchmark]'' A Benchmark for RNA-seq Quantification Pipelines. *'''rnaseqcomp''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/rnaseqcomp.html rnaseqcomp]'' Benchmarks for RNA-seq Quantification Pipelines. * '''RSEM Read Simulator''' ''[http://deweylab.biostat.wisc.edu/rsem/ rsem-simulate-reads]''. RSEM provides users the ‘rsem-simulate-reads’ program to simulate RNA-Seq data based on parameters learned from real data sets. * '''RNASeqReadSimulator''' ''[http://alumni.cs.ucr.edu/~liw/rnaseqreadsimulator.html RNASeqReadSimulator]'' contains a set of simple Python scripts, command line driven. It generates random expression levels of transcripts (single or paired-end), equally simulates reads with a specific positional bias pattern and generates random errors from sequencing platforms. *'''RNA Seq Simulator''' ''[http://popmodels.cancercontrol.cancer.gov/gsr/packages/rna-seq-simulator/ RNA Seq Simulator]'' . RSS takes SAM alignment files from RNA-Seq data and simulates over dispersed, multiple replica, differential, non-stranded RNA-Seq datasets. *'''SimSeq''' ''[https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/SimSeq/index.html SimSeq]'': A Nonparametric Approach to Simulation of RNA-Sequence Datasets. * '''WGsim''' ''[https://github.com/lh3/wgsim wgsim]''. Wgsim is a small tool for simulating sequence reads from a reference genome. It is able to simulate diploid genomes with SNPs and insertion/deletion (INDEL) polymorphisms, and simulate reads with uniform substitution sequencing errors. It does not generate INDEL sequencing errors, but this can be partly compensated by simulating INDEL polymorphisms.
==Transcriptome assemblers== The [[transcriptome]] is the total population of RNAs expressed in one cell or group of cells, including non-coding and protein-coding RNAs. There are two types of approaches to assemble transcriptomes. Genome-guided methods use a reference [[genome]] (if possible a finished and high quality genome) as a template to align and assembling reads into transcripts. Genome-independent methods does not require a reference genome and are normally used when a genome is not available. In this case reads are assembled directly in transcripts. Some important comparative studies <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hayer|first1=Katharina E.|last2=Pizarro|first2=Angel|last3=Lahens|first3=Nicholas F.|last4=Hogenesch|first4=John B.|last5=Grant|first5=Gregory R.|title=Benchmark analysis of algorithms for determining and quantifying full-length mRNA splice forms from RNA-seq data|journal=Bioinformatics|date=3 September 2015|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btv488|pages=3938–45|pmid=26338770|pmc=4673975|volume=31|issue=24}}</ref><ref name=Steijger2013>{{cite journal|journal= Nat Methods |volume=10| year=2013 | author= Steijger T, Abril JF, Engström PG, Kokocinski F, Hubbard TJ, Guigó R, Harrow J, Bertone P; RGASP Consortium.| pmid=24185837| title = Assessment of transcript reconstruction methods for RNA-seq |doi=10.1038/nmeth.2714 | issue=12| pages=1177–84 | pmc=3851240}}</ref> were already published.
===Genome-guided assemblers=== *'''Bayesembler''' ''[https://github.com/bioinformatics-centre/bayesembler Baysembler]'' Bayesian transcriptome assembly. * '''CIDANE''' ''[http://ccb.jhu.edu/software/cidane/ Cidane]'' a comprehensive isoform discovery and abundance estimation. * '''CLASS''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/p/splicebox/wiki/CLASS/ CLASS]''. CLASS is a program for assembling transcripts from RNA-seq reads aligned to a genome. CLASS produces a set of transcripts in three stages. Stage 1 uses linear programming to determine a set of exons for each gene. Stage 2 builds a splice graph representation of a gene, by connecting the exons (vertices) via introns (edges) extracted from spliced read alignments. Stage 3 selects a subset of the candidate transcripts encoded in the graph that can explain all the reads, using either a parsimonius (SET_COVER) or a dynamic programming optimization approach. This stage takes into account constraints derived from mate pairs and spliced alignments and, optionally, knowledge about gene structure extracted from known annotation or alignments of cDNA sequences. * '''Cufflinks''' ''[http://cufflinks.cbcb.umd.edu/ Cufflinks]''. Cufflinks assembles transcripts, estimates their abundances, and tests for differential expression and regulation in RNA-Seq samples. It accepts aligned RNA-Seq reads and assembles the alignments into a parsimonious set of transcripts. Cufflinks then estimates the relative abundances of these transcripts based on how many reads support each one, taking into account biases in library preparation protocols. * '''iReckon''' ''[http://compbio.cs.toronto.edu/ireckon/ iReckon]''. iReckon is an algorithm for the simultaneous isoform reconstruction and abundance estimation. In addition to modelling novel isoforms, multi-mapped reads and read duplicates, this method takes into account the possible presence of unspliced pre-mRNA and intron retention. iReckon only requires a set of transcription start and end sites, but can use known full isoforms to improve sensitivity. Starting from the set of nearly all possible isoforms, iReckon uses a regularized EM algorithm to determine those actually present in the sequenced sample, together with their abundances. iReckon is multi-threaded to increase efficiency in all its time consuming steps. * '''IsoInfer''' ''[http://www.cs.ucr.edu/~jianxing/IsoInfer.html IsoInfer]''. IsoInfer is a C/C++ program to infer isoforms based on short RNA-Seq (single-end and paired-end) reads, exon-intron boundary and TSS/PAS information. * '''IsoLasso''' ''[http://alumni.cs.ucr.edu/~liw/isolasso.html IsoLasso]''. IsoLasso is an algorithm to assemble transcripts and estimate their expression levels from RNA-Seq reads. * '''Flipflop''' ''[http://cbio.ensmp.fr/flipflop/ flipflop]''. FlipFlop implements a fast method for de novo transcript discovery and abundance estimation from RNA-Seq data. It differs from Cufflinks by simultaneously performing the identification and quantitation tasks using a convex penalized maximum likelihood approach, which leads to improved precision/recall. * '''GIIRA''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/giira/ GIIRA]''. GIIRA is a gene prediction method that identifies potential coding regions exclusively based on the mapping of reads from an RNA-Seq experiment. It was foremost designed for prokaryotic gene prediction and is able to resolve genes within the expressed region of an operon. However, it is also applicable to eukaryotes and predicts exon intron structures as well as alternative isoforms. * '''MITIE''' ''[http://bioweb.me/mitie MITIE]''. Simultaneous RNA-Seq-based Transcript Identification and Quantification in Multiple Samples. * '''RNAeXpress''' ''[http://www.rnaexpress.org/ RNAeXpress]''. RNA-eXpress was designed as a user friendly solution to extract and annotate biologically important transcripts from next generation RNA sequencing data. This approach complements existing gene annotation databases by ensuring all transcripts present in the sample are considered for further analysis. * '''Scripture''' ''[http://www.broadinstitute.org/software/scripture/ Scripture]''. Scripture is a method for transcriptome reconstruction that relies solely on RNA-Seq reads and an assembled genome to build a transcriptome ab initio. The statistical methods to estimate read coverage significance are also applicable to other sequencing data. Scripture also has modules for ChIP-Seq peak calling. * '''SLIDE''' ''[https://sites.google.com/site/jingyijli/ SLIDE]'' - Sparse Linear modeling of RNA-Seq data for Isoform Discovery and abundance Estimation. *'''Strawberry''' ''[https://github.com/ruolin/Strawberry Strawberry]''- A program for fast and accurate genome-guided transcripts reconstruction and quantification from paired-end RNA-seq. *'''StringTie''' ''[http://www.ccb.jhu.edu/software/stringtie/ StringTie]''. StringTie is a fast and highly efficient assembler of RNA-Seq alignments into potential transcripts. It uses a novel network flow algorithm as well as an optional de novo assembly step to assemble and quantitate full-length transcripts representing multiple splice variants for each gene locus. Its input can include not only the alignments of raw reads used by other transcript assemblers, but also alignments longer sequences that have been assembled from those reads.To identify differentially expressed genes between experiments, StringTie's output can be processed either by the Cuffdiff or Ballgown programs. *'''TransComb''' ''[https://sourceforge.net/projects/transcriptomeassembly/files/ TransComb]'' a genome-guided transcriptome assembly via combing junctions in splicing graphs. *'''Traph''' ''[https://www.cs.helsinki.fi/en/gsa/traph/ Traph]'' A tool for transcript identification and quantification with RNA-Seq. *'''Tiling Assembly''' for Annotation-independent Novel Gene Discovery.
===Genome-independent (''de novo'') assemblers=== * '''Bridger''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/rnaseqassembly/ Bridger]''<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Bridger: a new framework for de novo transcriptome assembly using RNA-seq data|url = http://genomebiology.com/2015/16/1/30/abstract|journal = Genome Biology|date = 2015-02-11|issn = 1465-6906|pmc = 4342890|pmid = 25723335|pages = 30|volume = 16|issue = 1|doi = 10.1186/s13059-015-0596-2|first = Zheng|last = Chang|first2 = Guojun|last2 = Li|first3 = Juntao|last3 = Liu|first4 = Yu|last4 = Zhang|first5 = Cody|last5 = Ashby|first6 = Deli|last6 = Liu|first7 = Carole L.|last7 = Cramer|first8 = Xiuzhen|last8 = Huang}}</ref> was developed at Shandong University, takes advantage of techniques employed in Cufflinks to overcome limitations of the existing de novo assemblers. * '''CLC''' ''[http://resources.qiagenbioinformatics.com/manuals/clcgenomicsworkbench/852/index.php?manual=De_novo_assembly.html CLC]'' de novo assembly algorithm of CLC Genomics Workbench. * '''KISSPLICE''' ''[http://kissplice.prabi.fr/ KISSPLICE]'' is a software that enables to analyse RNA-seq data with or without a reference genome. It is an exact local transcriptome assembler that allows to identify SNPs, indels and alternative splicing events. It can deal with an arbitrary number of biological conditions, and will quantify each variant in each condition. * '''Oases''' ''[http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~zerbino/oases/ Oases]''. De novo transcriptome assembler for very short reads. * '''rnaSPAdes''' ''[http://cab.spbu.ru/software/rnaspades/ rnaSPAdes]'' * '''Rnnotator''' ''[https://sites.google.com/a/lbl.gov/rnnotator/ Rnnotator]: an automated de novo transcriptome assembly pipeline from stranded RNA-Seq reads. * '''SAT-Assembler''' ''[http://sat-assembler.sourceforge.net/ SAT-Assembler]'' * '''SOAPdenovo-Trans''' ''[http://sourceforge.net/projects/soapdenovotrans/ SOAPdenovo-trans]''. *'''Scaffolding Translation Mapping''' ''[http://www.surget-groba.ch/soft.php STM]''. * '''Trans-ABySS''' ''[http://www.bcgsc.ca/platform/bioinfo/software/trans-abyss Trans-AByss]''. * '''T-IDBA''' ''[http://i.cs.hku.hk/~alse/hkubrg/projects/tidba/ T-IDBA]''. * '''Trinity''' ''[https://github.com/trinityrnaseq/trinityrnaseq/wiki Trinity]'' was developed at the Broad Institute and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, represents a novel method for the efficient and robust de novo reconstruction of transcriptomes from RNA-seq data. Trinity combines three independent software modules: Inchworm, Chrysalis, and Butterfly, applied sequentially to process large volumes of RNA-seq reads. * '''Velvet''' [[Velvet (algorithm)]].<ref name=zerbino2008>{{cite journal | journal=Genome Research | volume=18 | issue=5 | pages=821–829 | year=2008 |vauthors=Zerbino DR, Birney E | title=Velvet: Algorithms for de novo short read assembly using de Bruijn graphs | url=http://genome.cshlp.org/content/18/5/821.full | pmid=18349386 | doi= 10.1101/gr.074492.107 | pmc=2336801 }}</ref> ''[http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~zerbino/velvet/ Velvet(EMBL-EBI)]''.
===Assembly evaluation tools=== * '''Busco''' ''[http://busco.ezlab.org/ Busco]'' provides quantitative measures for the assessment of genome assembly, gene set, and transcriptome completeness, based on evolutionarily-informed expectations of gene content from near-universal single-copy orthologs selected from OrthoDB tool. * '''Detonate''' ''[http://deweylab.biostat.wisc.edu/detonate/ Detonate]''. DETONATE (DE novo TranscriptOme rNa-seq Assembly with or without the Truth Evaluation) consists of two component packages, RSEM-EVAL and REF-EVAL. Both packages are mainly intended to be used to evaluate de novo transcriptome assemblies, although REF-EVAL can be used to compare sets of any kinds of genomic sequences. * '''rnaQUAST''' ''[http://bioinf.spbau.ru/en/rnaquast rnaquast]'': Quality Assessment Tool for Transcriptome Assemblies. * '''TransRate''' ''[http://hibberdlab.com/transrate TransRate]''. Transrate is software for de-novo transcriptome assembly quality analysis. It examines your assembly in detail and compares it to experimental evidence such as the sequencing reads, reporting quality scores for contigs and assemblies. This allows you to choose between assemblers and parameters, filter out the bad contigs from an assembly, and help decide when to stop trying to improve the assembly.
==Co-expression networks== * '''GeneNetWeaver''' ''[http://gnw.sourceforge.net/genenetweaver.html GeneNetWeaver]'' is an open-source tool for in silico benchmark generation and performance profiling of network inference methods. * '''WGCNA''' ''[http://labs.genetics.ucla.edu/horvath/CoexpressionNetwork/Rpackages/WGCNA/ Weighted Gene Coexpression Network Analysis]'' is an R package for weighted correlation network analysis. * '''Pigengene''' ''[http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/Pigengene.html/ Pigengene]'' is an R package that infers biological information from gene expression profiles. Based on a coexpression network, it computes eigengenes and effectively uses them as features to fit decision trees and Bayesian networks that are useful in diagnosis and prognosis.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Foroushani|first1=Amir|last2=Agrahari|first2=Rupesh|last3=Docking|first3=Roderick|last4=Chang|first4=Linda|last5=Duns|first5=Gerben|last6=Hudoba|first6=Monika|last7=Karsan|first7=Aly|last8=Zare|first8=Habil|title=Large-scale gene network analysis reveals the significance of extracellular matrix pathway and homeobox genes in acute myeloid leukemia: an introduction to the Pigengene package and its applications|journal=BMC Medical Genomics|date=16 March 2017|volume=10|issue=1|pages=16|doi=10.1186/s12920-017-0253-6|pmid=28298217|pmc=5353782}}</ref>
==miRNA prediction and analysis== * '''iSRAP''' – <ref name=Camelia2015>{{cite journal|journal= Journal of Extracellular Vesicles |volume=4| year=2015|author1=Camelia Quek |author2=Chol-hee Jung |author3=Shayne A. Bellingham |author4=Andrew Lonie |author5=Andrew F. Hill | pmid=26561006|pmc=4641893| title= iSRAP - a one-touch research tool for rapid profiling of small RNA-seq data|doi=10.3402/jev.v4.29454| issue=| pages=29454}}</ref> a one-touch research tool for rapid profiling of small RNA-seq data. * '''SPAR''' – <ref name=Kuksa2018spar>{{cite journal|journal= Nucleic Acids Research |volume=Web Server issue| year=2018|author1=Pavel P. Kuksa |author2=Alexandre Amlie-Wolf |author3=Zivadin Katanic |author4=Li-San Wang |author5=Yuk Yee Leung | pmid=29733404|pmc=6030839| title=SPAR: small RNA-seq portal for analysis of sequencing experiments |doi=10.1093/nar/gky330| issue=W1| pages=W36–W42}}</ref> small RNA-seq, short total RNA-seq, miRNA-seq, single-cell small RNA-seq data processing, analysis, annotation, visualization, and comparison against reference [[ENCODE]] and [http://lisanwanglab.org/DASHR DASHR] datasets. ''[https://www.lisanwanglab.org/SPAR SPAR]'' * '''miRDeep2''' ''[https://www.mdc-berlin.de/8551903/en/ miRDeep2]''. * '''MIReNA''' ''[http://www.lgm.upmc.fr/mirena/index.html MIReNA]''. * '''miRExpress''' ''[http://mirexpress.mbc.nctu.edu.tw/ miRExpress]''. * '''miR-PREFeR''' ''[https://github.com/hangelwen/miR-PREFeR miR-PREFeR]''. * '''miRDeep-P''' For plants. ''[http://faculty.virginia.edu/lilab/miRDP/ miRDeep-P]''. * '''miRDeep*''' [[sourceforge:projects/mirdeepstar/|mirdeepstar]] * '''miRPlant''' [[sourceforge:projects/mirplant/|mirplant]] * '''MiRdup''' ''[http://cs.mcgill.ca/~blanchem/mirdup/ MiRdup]''
==Visualization tools== * '''ABrowse''' ''[http://www.abrowse.org/ ABrowse]'' - a customizable next-generation genome browser framework. * '''Artemis''' ''[http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/software/artemis/ Artemis]''. Artemis is a free genome browser and annotation tool that allows visualisation of sequence features, next generation data and the results of analyses within the context of the sequence, and also its six-frame translation. * '''Apollo''' ''[http://apollo.berkeleybop.org/current/index.html Apollo]''. Apollo is designed to support geographically dispersed researchers, and the work of a distributed community is coordinated through automatic synchronization: all edits in one client are instantly pushed to all other clients, allowing users to see annotation updates from collaborators in real-time during the editing process. * '''BamView''' ''[http://bamview.sourceforge.net BamView]''. BamView is a free interactive display of read alignments in BAM data files. It has been developed by the Pathogen Group at the Sanger Institute. * '''BrowserGenome''' ''[http://www.browsergenome.org/ BrowserGenome.org]'':<ref name="Schmid-Burgk2015">{{cite journal|journal= Nat Methods|volume=12| year=2015|vauthors=Schmid-Burgk JL, Hornung V | pmid=26513548| title = BrowserGenome.org: web-based RNA-seq data analysis and visualization |url= http://www.nature.com/nmeth/journal/v12/n11/full/nmeth.3615.html |doi= 10.1038/nmeth.3615 | issue=11| pages=1001}}</ref> web-based RNA-seq data analysis and visualization. * '''Degust''' ''[https://victorian-bioinformatics-consortium.github.io/degust/ Degust]''. An interactive web tool for visualising Differential Gene Expression data. * '''DensityMap''' ''[https://github.com/sguizard/DensityMap DensityMap]'' is a perl tool for the visualization of features density along chromosomes. * '''EagleView''' ''[http://bioinformatics.bc.edu/marthlab/wiki/index.php/EagleView EagleView]''. EagleView is an information-rich genome assembler viewer with data integration capability. EagleView can display a dozen different types of information including base qualities, machine specific trace signals, and genome feature annotations. * '''expvip-web''' ''[https://github.com/homonecloco/expvip-web expvip-web]'' a customisable RNA-seq data analysis and visualisation platform. * '''GBrowse''' ''[http://gmod.org/wiki/GBrowse GBrowse]''. * '''Integrated Genome Browser''' ''[http://www.affymetrix.com/partners_programs/programs/developer/tools/igbsource_terms.affx IGB]''. * '''Integrative Genomics Viewer (IGV)''' ''[http://www.broadinstitute.org/igv/ IGV]''. * '''GenomeView''' ''[http://genomeview.org/ genomeview]''. * '''MapView''' ''[http://evolution.sysu.edu.cn/mapview/ MapView]''. * '''MicroScope''' ''[https://github.com/Bohdan-Khomtchouk/Microscope Microscope]'': comprehensive genome analysis software suite for gene expression heatmaps. * '''ReadXplorer''' ''[https://www.uni-giessen.de/fbz/fb08/Inst/bioinformatik/software/ReadXplorer ReadXplorer]''. ReadXplorer is a freely available comprehensive exploration and evaluation tool for NGS data. It extracts and adds quantity and quality measures to each alignment in order to classify the mapped reads. This classification is then taken into account for the different data views and all supported automatic analysis functions. * '''RNASeqExpressionBrowser''' ''[http://pgsb.helmholtz-muenchen.de/plant/RNASeqExpressionBrowser/index.jsp RNASeqExpressionBrowser]'' is a web-based tool which provides means for the search and visualization of RNA-seq expression data (e.g. based on sequence-information or domain annotations). It can generate detailed reports for selected genes including expression data and associated annotations. If needed, links to (publicly available) databases can be easily integrated. The RNASeqExpressionBrowser allows password protection and thereby access restriction to authorized users only. * '''Savant''' ''[http://www.genomesavant.com/p/savant/index Savant]''. Savant is a next-generation genome browser designed for the latest generation of genome data. * '''Samscope''' ''[http://samscope.dna.bio.keio.ac.jp/wiki/index.php/Samscope Samscope]''. * '''SeqMonk''' ''[http://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/seqmonk/ SeqMonk]''. * '''Tablet''' <ref name=Tablet2013>{{cite journal|journal= Briefings in Bioinformatics |volume=14| year=2013 |vauthors=Milne I, Stephen G, Bayer M, Cock PJ, Pritchard L, Cardle L, Shaw PD, Marshall D | pmid=22445902| title=Using Tablet for visual exploration of second-generation sequencing data|doi=10.1093/bib/bbs012| issue=2| pages=193–202}}</ref> ''[http://bioinf.scri.ac.uk/tablet/ Tablet]''. Tablet is a lightweight, high-performance graphical viewer for next generation sequence assemblies and alignments. * '''Tbrowse- HTML5 Transcriptome Browser''' ''[https://code.google.com/p/tbrowse/ Tbrowse]''. * '''TBro ''' ''[https://github.com/TBroTeam/TBro TBro]'' – a transcriptome browser for de novo RNA-sequencing experiments. * '''Vespa''' ''[https://www.biopilot.org/docs/Software/Vespa.php Vespa]''.
==Functional, network and pathway analysis tools== * '''BioCyc''' ''[http://www.biocyc.org BioCyc]'': Visualize RNA-seq data onto individual pathway diagrams, multi-pathway diagrams called pathway collages, and zoomable organism-specific metabolic map diagrams. Computes pathway enrichment. Also provides a tool called the [https://biocyc.org/dashboard/dashboard-intro.shtml Omics Dashboard] for visualizing RNA-seq data within a hierarchy of cellular systems. * '''BRANE Clust''' ''[http://www-syscom.univ-mlv.fr/~pirayre/Codes-GRN-BRANE-clust.html BRANE Clust]'': Biologically-Related Apriori Network Enhancement for Gene Regulatory Network Inference combined with clustering.<ref name=BraneClust2017>{{cite journal|journal= IEEE/ACM Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics |volume=PP|issue=3|pages=850–860| year=2017|author1=Aurelie Pirayre |author2=Camille Couprie |author3=Laurent Duval |author4=Jean-Christophe Pesquet | title= BRANE Clust: Cluster-Assisted Gene Regulatory Network Inference Refinement |pmid=28368827|doi= 10.1109/TCBB.2017.2688355 |url=https://hal-ifp.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01330638/file/Pirayre_A_2016_j-ieee-tcbb_BRANEClust-HAL.pdf|type=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> * '''BRANE Cut''' ''[http://www-syscom.univ-mlv.fr/~pirayre/Codes-GRN-BRANE-cut.html BRANE Cut]'': Biologically-Related Apriori Network Enhancement with Graph cuts for Gene Regulatory Network Inference.<ref name=BraneCut2015>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=16| year=2015|author1=Aurelie Pirayre |author2=Camille Couprie |author3=Frédérique Bidard |author4=Laurent Duval |author5=Jean-Christophe Pesquet | title= BRANE Cut: biologically-related a priori network enhancement with graph cuts for gene regulatory network inference |pmid=26537179|doi= 10.1186/s12859-015-0754-2 |pmc=4634801 |page=368}}</ref> * '''[http://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/Enrichr/ Enrichr]''' ''[http://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/Enrichr/ Enrichr]'': a comprehensive gene set enrichment analysis web server. * '''FunRich''' ''[http://www.funrich.org/ Funrich]'': Functional Enrichment analysis tool. * '''[http://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/gage.html GAGE]''' is applicable independent of sample sizes, experimental design, assay platforms, and other types of heterogeneity.<ref name=GAGE2009>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=10| year=2009 |author1=Weijun Luo |author2=Michael S Friedman |author3=Kerby Shedden |author4=Kurt D Hankenson |author5=Peter J Woolf | pmid=19473525| title= GAGE: generally applicable gene set enrichment for pathway analysis |url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/10/161|doi=10.1186/1471-2105-10-161| issue=161| pages=17 | pmc=2696452}}</ref> This Biocondutor package also provides functions and data for pathway, GO and gene set analysis in general. Tutorials describe both [http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/vignettes/gage/inst/doc/RNA-seqWorkflow.pdf RNA-Seq pathway analysis workflows] and [http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/vignettes/gage/inst/doc/gage.pdf microarray analysis workflows]. The RNA-Seq workflows cover from preparation, reads counting, data preprocessing, gene set test, to pathway visualization in about 40 lines of codes. * '''Gene Set Association Analysis for RNA-Seq''' ''([http://gsaa.unc.edu GSAASeq])'': GSAASeq are computational methods that assess the differential expression of a pathway/gene set between two biological states based on sequence count data. *'''GeneSCF''' ''[http://genescf.kandurilab.org/ GeneSCF]'': a real-time based functional enrichment tool with support for multiple organisms.<ref name=GeneSCF2016>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Bioinformatics |volume=17| year=2016 |author1=Santhilal Subhash |author2=Chandrasekhar Kanduri| pmid=27618934| title= GeneSCF: a real-time based functional enrichment tool with support for multiple organisms |doi=10.1186/s12859-016-1250-z| issue=1| pages=365 | pmc=5020511}}</ref> Complete tutorial for GeneSCF is available on [https://www.biostars.org/p/108669 BioStar] and documentation on [http://genescf.kandurilab.org/ftp/GeneSCF-Documentation_v1.1.pdf GeneSCF project home page]. Advantages of using GeneSCF: real-time analysis, users do not have to depend on enrichment tools to get updated, easy for computational biologists to integrate GeneSCF with their NGS pipeline, it supports multiple organisms, enrichment analysis for multiple gene list using multiple source database in single run, retrieve or download complete GO terms/Pathways/Functions with associated genes as simple table format in a plain text file. *'''GOexpress''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/GOexpress.html GOexpress]''.<ref name=Rue2014>{{cite journal|journal= |volume=| year=2014| author = Rue-Albrecht K | pmid=| title = Visualise microarray and RNAseq data using gene ontology annotations. R package version 1.4.1|url= https://github.com/kevinrue/GOexpress|doi=| issue=| pages=}}</ref> Visualise microarray and RNAseq data using gene ontology annotations. * '''GOSeq''' ''[https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/goseq.html GOSeq]''.<ref name=Young2010>{{cite journal|journal= Genome Biology |volume=11| year=2010 |vauthors=Young MD, Wakefield MJ, Smyth GK, Oshlack A | pmid=20132535| title= Gene ontology analysis for RNA-seq: accounting for selection bias.|url= http://www.genomebiology.com/2010/11/2/R14 |doi= 10.1186/gb-2010-11-2-r14| issue=2| pages=12 | pmc=2872874}}</ref> Gene Ontology analyser for RNA-seq and other length biased data. * '''GSAASEQSP''' ''[http://gsaa.unc.edu/login/ GSAASeqSP]'':<ref name=Qing2014>{{cite journal|journal= Scientific Reports |volume=4| year=2014|author1=Qing Xiong, Sayan Mukherjee |author2=Terrence S. Furey |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=25213199|pmc=4161965| title = GSAASeqSP: A Toolset for Gene Set Association Analysis of RNA-Seq Data |url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep06347|doi=10.1038/srep06347| issue=6347| pages=6347|bibcode=2014NatSR...4E6347X}}</ref> A Toolset for Gene Set Association Analysis of RNA-Seq Data. * '''GSVA''' ''[https://www.webcitation.org/query.php?url=http://www.bioconductor.org&refdoi=10.1186/1471-2105-14-7 GSVA]'' <ref name=Sonja2013>{{cite journal|journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=14| year=2013|author1=Sonja Hänzelmann, Robert Castelo |author2=Justin Guinney |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=23323831| title= GSVA: gene set variation analysis for microarray and RNA-Seq data. |url= http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/14/7/|doi= 10.1186/1471-2105-14-7| issue=17| pages=7 | pmc=3618321}}</ref> gene set variation analysis for microarray and RNA-Seq data. * '''Heat*Seq''' ''[https://github.com/gdevailly/HeatStarSeq_gh Heat*Seq]'': an interactive web tool for high-throughput sequencing experiment comparison with public data. * '''Ingenuity Systems (commercial)''' ''[http://www.ingenuity.com/products/rna-seq-expression-analysis iReport & IPA]'': Ingenuity’s IPA and iReport applications enable you to upload, analyze, and visualize RNA-Seq datasets, eliminating the obstacles between data and biological insight. Both IPA and iReport support identification, analysis and interpretation of differentially expressed isoforms between condition and control samples, and support interpretation and assessment of expression changes in the context of biological processes, disease and cellular phenotypes, and molecular interactions. Ingenuity iReport supports the upload of native Cuffdiff file format as well as gene expression lists. IPA supports the upload of gene expression lists. * '''PathwaySeq''' <ref name=Yi2015>{{cite journal|journal=Biometrics |volume=72| year=2015| author =Yi-Hui Zhou| pmid=26259845|pmc=4992401| title= Pathway analysis for RNA-Seq data using a score-based approach|doi=10.1111/biom.12372| issue=1| pages=165–74}}</ref> Pathway analysis for RNA-Seq data using a score-based approach. * '''petal''' ''[https://github.com/julipetal/petalNet petalNet]'' – Co-expression network modelling in R. * '''ToPASeq''':<ref name=Ivana2015>{{cite journal|journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=16| year=2015|author1=Ivana Ihnatova |author2=Eva Budinska |lastauthoramp=yes| pmid=26514335| title= ToPASeq: an R package for topology-based pathway analysis of microarray and RNA-Seq data|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/16/350|doi=10.1186/s12859-015-0763-1| issue=350| pages= 350| pmc=4625615}}</ref> an R package for topology-based pathway analysis of microarray and RNA-Seq data. *'''RNA-Enrich''' ''[http://lrpath.ncibi.org/ RNA-Enrich]'': A cut-off free functional enrichment testing method for RNA-seq with improved detection power. * '''TRAPID''' ''[http://bioinformatics.psb.ugent.be/webtools/trapid/ TRAPID]''.<ref name=Michiel2013>{{cite journal|journal= Genome Biol.|volume=14| year=2013|vauthors=Van Bel M, Proost S, Van Neste C, Deforce D, Van de Peer Y, Vandepoele K | pmid=24330842| title = TRAPID, an efficient online tool for the functional and comparative analysis of de novo RNA-Seq transcriptomes |doi=10.1186/gb-2013-14-12-r134| issue=12| pages=R134| pmc=4053847}}</ref> Rapid Analysis of Transcriptome Data. * '''T-REx''' ''[http://server.molgenrug.nl/index.php/rnaseq-expression-analysis T-REx]''.<ref name=Anne2015>{{cite journal|journal= BMC Genomics |volume=16| year=2015|author1=Anne de Jong |author2=Sjoerd van der Meulen |author3=Oscar P. Kuipers |author4=Jan Kok | pmid=26335208| title=T-REx: Transcriptome analysis webserver for RNA-seq Expression data|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2164/16/663|doi=10.1186/s12864-015-1834-4| issue=663|pages= 663| pmc=4558784}}</ref> RNA-seq expression analysis.
==Further annotation tools for RNA-Seq data== *'''Frama''' ''[https://github.com/gengit/FRAMA Frama]'': From RNA-seq data to annotated mRNA assemblies. *'''HLAminer''' ''[http://www.bcgsc.ca/platform/bioinfo/software/hlaminer HLAminer]'' is a computational method for identifying HLA alleles directly from whole genome, exome and transcriptome shotgun sequence datasets. HLA allele predictions are derived by targeted assembly of shotgun sequence data and comparison to a database of reference allele sequences. This tool is developed in [[perl]] and it is available as console tool. *'''pasa''' ''[https://pasapipeline.github.io/ pasa]''. PASA, acronym for Program to Assemble Spliced Alignments, is a eukaryotic genome annotation tool that exploits spliced alignments of expressed transcript sequences to automatically model gene structures, and to maintain gene structure annotation consistent with the most recently available experimental sequence data. PASA also identifies and classifies all splicing variations supported by the transcript alignments. *'''seq2HLA''' ''[http://tron-mainz.de/tron-facilities/computational-medicine/seq2hla seq2HLA]'' is an annotation tool for obtaining an individual's HLA class I and II type and expression using standard NGS RNA-Seq data in [[fastq]] format. It comprises mapping RNA-Seq reads against a reference database of HLA alleles using [[bowtie]], determining and reporting HLA type, confidence score and locus-specific expression level. This tool is developed in [[Python (programming language)|Python]] and [[R (programming language)|R]]. It is available as console tool or [[Galaxy]] module.
==RNA-Seq databases== * '''ARCHS4''' ''[http://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/ARCHS4 ARCHS4]''. Uniformly processed RNA-seq data from GEO/SRA (>300,000 samples) with metadata search to locate subsets of published samples. * '''ENA''' ''[http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/search?query=rnaseq ENA]''. The European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) provides a comprehensive record of the world's nucleotide sequencing information, covering raw sequencing data, sequence assembly information and functional annotation. * '''ENCODE''' ''[http://genome-preview.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgFileUi?db=hg19&g=wgEncodeCshlLongRnaSeq ENCODE]''. *'''queryable-rna-seq-database ''' ''[https://github.com/fatPerlHacker/queryable-rna-seq-database queryable-rna-seq-database]''. Formally known as the Queryable RNA-Seq Database, this system is designed to simplify the process of RNA-seq analysis by providing the ability upload the result data from RNA-Seq analysis into a database, store it, and query it in many different ways. *'''CIRCpedia v2''' ''[http://www.picb.ac.cn/rnomics/circpedia/ CIRCpedia]'' is an updated comprehensive database containing circRNA annotations from over 180 RNA-seq datasets across six different species. This atlas allows users to search, browse and download circRNAs with expression characteristics/features in various cell types/tissues, including disease samples. In addition, the updated database incorporates conservation analysis of circRNAs between humans and mice.
===Human related=== * '''Brain RNA-Seq''' ''[http://web.stanford.edu/group/barres_lab/brain_rnaseq.html Brain RNA-Seq]''.<ref name=YeZhang2014>{{cite journal|journal= Journal of Neuroscience|volume=34| year=2014|author1=Ye Zhang |author2=Kenian Chen |author3=Steven A Sloan |author4=Mariko L Bennett |author5=Anja R Scholze |author6=Sean O'Keefe |author7=Hemali P Phatnani |author8=Paolo Guarnieri |author9=Christine Caneda |author10=Nadine Ruderisch |author11=Shuyun Deng |author12=Shane A Liddelow |author13=Chaolin Zhang |author14=Richard Daneman |author15=Tom Maniatis |author16=Ben A Barres |author17=Jia Qian Wu | pmid=25186741|pmc=4152602| title= An RNA-Seq transcriptome and splicing database of glia, neurons, and vascular cells of the cerebral cortex.|url= http://www.jneurosci.org/content/34/36/11929.short|doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.1860-14.2014| issue=36| pages=11929–11947}}</ref> An RNA-Seq transcriptome and splicing database of glia, neurons, and vascular cells of the cerebral cortex. * '''FusionCancer''' <ref name=Wang2015>{{cite journal|journal=Diagnostic Pathology |volume=10| year=2015 | author=Wang, Y., Wu, N., Liu, J., Wu, Z., & Dong, D.| pmid=26215638| title=FusionCancer: a database of cancer fusion genes derived from RNA-seq data|doi=10.1186/s13000-015-0310-4| issue=131| pages=39| pmc=4517624}}</ref> ''[http://donglab.ecnu.edu.cn/databases/FusionCancer/ FusionCancer]'': a database of cancer fusion genes derived from RNA-seq data. *'''Hipposeq''' ''[http://hipposeq.janelia.org/ Hipposeq]'' a comprehensive RNA-seq database of gene expression in [[hippocampal]] principal neurons. *'''Mitranscriptome''' ''[http://mitranscriptome.org/ Mitranscriptome]'' is a systematic list of long poly-adenylated Human RNA transcripts based on RNA-Seq data from more than 6,500 samples associated with a variety of cancer and tissue types. The database contains detailed gene expression analysis of over 91,000 genes, most are uncharacterized long RNAs. *'''RNA-Seq Atlas'''<ref name=Atlas2012>{{cite journal|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=28| year=2012 |author1=Krupp M |author2=Marquardt JU |author3=Sahin U |author4=Galle PR |author5=Castle J |author6=Teufel A. | pmid=22345621| title=RNA-Seq Atlas--a reference database for gene expression profiling in normal tissue by next-generation sequencing|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts084| issue=8| pages=1184–1185}}</ref>''[http://medicalgenomics.org/rna_seq_atlas RNA-Seq Atlas]'' a reference database for gene expression profiling in normal tissue by next-generation sequencing. *'''SRA''' ''[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra SRA]''. The Sequence Read Archive (SRA) stores raw sequence data from "next-generation" sequencing technologies including 454, IonTorrent, Illumina, SOLiD, Helicos and Complete Genomics. In addition to raw sequence data, SRA now stores alignment information in the form of read placements on a reference sequence. *'''DASHR''' ''[http://lisanwanglab.org/DASHR DASHR]''. A database of human small RNA genes and mature products derived from small RNA-seq data.
===Single species' RNA-Seq databases=== *'''Aedes-albopictus''' ''[https://www.vectorbase.org/organisms/aedes-albopictus Aedes albopictus]'' [[Aedes albopictus]] database. *'''Arabidopsis thaliana''' ''[http://travadb.org/ TraVa]'' the database of gene expression profiles in [[Arabidopsis thaliana]] based on RNA-seq analysis. *'''Barley''' ''[https://ics.hutton.ac.uk/morexGenes/ morexGenes]''- [[Barley]] RNA-seq Database. *'''Chickpea ''' ''[http://www.nipgr.res.in/ctdb.html Chickpea transcriptome database]'' (CTDB) has been developed with the view to provide most comprehensive information about the [[chickpea]] transcriptome, the most relevant part of the genome". *'''Chilo suppressalis''' ''[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4082153/ ChiloDB ]'': a genomic and transcriptome database for an important rice insect pest [[Chilo suppressalis]]. *'''Echinoderm''' ''[http://echinotol.org EchinoDB]'' – a repository of orthologous transcripts from [[echinoderms]]. *'''[[Equine]]''' transcriptome ([http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/phr/ University of California, Davis]). The data can be found at: ''[https://github.com/dib-lab/horse_trans https://github.com/dib-lab/horse_trans]''. *'''Escherichia coli''' ''[http://prokaryomics.com Ecomics]'' – an omics normalized database for [[Escherichia coli]]. *'''[[Fish]]''' ''[http://phylofish.sigenae.org/index.html Phylofish]''. *'''[[Ginger]]''' ''[http://220.227.138.213/GTDB/ Ginger]'' Ginger transcriptome database. *'''[[Lygodium japonicum]]''' ''[http://bioinf.mind.meiji.ac.jp/kanikusa/index.php Lygodium japonicum]'' Transcriptome Database. *'''[[Mammals]]''' ''[http://mtd.cbi.ac.cn/index.php Mammalian Transcriptomic Database]''. *''' Oyster (Pacific)''' ''[http://gigaton.sigenae.org/ GigaTon]'': an extensive publicly searchable database providing a new reference transcriptome in the [[pacific oyster]] Crassostrea gigas. *'''Mouse and Human''' ''[https://panglaodb.se/ PanglaoDB]'': A gene expression database for exploration and meta-analysis of single cell sequencing data. *'''[[Mangrove]]''' ''[http://mangrove.illinois.edu/transcriptome Mangrove]'' Transcriptome Database. *'''Krill (Antarctic)''' ''[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/362526 KrillDB]'': a de novo Transcriptome Database for the Antarctic [[Krill]]. *'''Mouse''' ''[http://rnaseqmetadb.ece.tamu.edu/ RNASeqMetaDB]: a database and web server for navigating metadata of publicly available [[mouse]] RNA-Seq data sets. *'''Rubus''' ''[https://www.rosaceae.org/organism/Rubus/spp/reftrans/v1 Rubus GDR RefTrans V1]'' - GDR Rubus RefTrans combines published RNA-Seq and EST data sets to create a reference transcriptome (RefTrans) for [[rubus]] and provides putative gene function identified by homology to known proteins. *'''Sorghum''' ''[http://sorghum.riken.jp/morokoshi/Home.html MOROKOSHI]'' Sorghum transcriptome database. RIKEN full-length cDNA clone and RNA-Seq data in [[Sorghum bicolor]]. *'''S. purpuratus''' ''[http://www.spbase.org/SpBase/rnaseq/ S. purpuratus]'' Developmental Transcriptomes of S. purpuratus *'''[[S. cerevisiae]]''' ''[http://yeastmine.yeastgenome.org/yeastmine/begin.do YeastMine]'' transcriptome database. *'''Wheat''' ''[http://wheat.pw.usda.gov/WheatExp/ WheatExp]'' – an RNA-seq expression database for polyploid [[wheat]].
== External links ==
===Webinars and presentations=== * ''[http://www.rna-seqblog.com/category/presentations/ RNASeq-Blog Presentations]'' * ''[http://training.bioinformatics.ucdavis.edu/docs/2012/05/RNA/index.html# RNA-Seq Workshop Documentation (UC Davis University)]'' * ''[https://sites.google.com/site/princetonhtseq/tutorials/rna-seq Princeton Workshop]'' * ''[https://www.youtube.com/results?q=rna-seq YouTube/RNA-Seq]'' * ''[http://www.rna-seqblog.com/rna-seq-presentations-from-gsk-university-of-torino-and-university-of-bath/ RNA-Seq Presentations from GSK, University of Torino and University of Bath]''.
== References == {{Reflist|35em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}
[[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Lists of software|RNA-Seq Bioinformatic]]

revision.comment: /* Physiological context */ ce
revision.text:
This is a list of antioxidants naturally occurring in food. [[Vitamin C]] and [[vitamin E]] – which are ubiquitous among raw [[plant food]]s – are confirmed as dietary antioxidants, whereas [[vitamin A]] becomes an antioxidant following [[metabolism]] of [[provitamin A]] [[beta-carotene]] and [[cryptoxanthin]]. Most food compounds listed as antioxidants – such as [[polyphenol]]s common in colorful, edible plants – have antioxidant activity only [[in vitro]], as their fate [[in vivo]] is to be rapidly metabolized and [[excretion|excreted]], and the in vivo properties of their [[metabolite]]s remain poorly understood. For antioxidants added to food to preserve them, see [[butylated hydroxyanisole]] and [[butylated hydroxytoluene]].
==Regulatory guidance== In the following discussion, the term "antioxidant" refers mainly to non-nutrient compounds in foods, such as polyphenols, which have ''antioxidant capacity'' [[in vitro]] and so provide an artificial index of antioxidant strength – the ORAC measurement. Other than for dietary antioxidant vitamins – [[vitamin A]], [[vitamin C]] and [[vitamin E]] – no food compounds have been proved with antioxidant efficacy [[in vivo]]. Accordingly, regulatory agencies like the [[Food and Drug Administration]] of the United States and the [[European Food Safety Authority]] (EFSA) have published guidance disallowing food product labels to claim an inferred antioxidant benefit when no such physiological evidence exists.<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/OHRMS/DOCKETS/98fr/FDA-1995-N-0400-GDL.pdf Guidance for Industry, Food Labeling; Nutrient Content Claims; Definition for "High Potency" and Definition for "Antioxidant" for Use in Nutrient Content Claims for Dietary Supplements and Conventional Foods] U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Food and Drug Administration, Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, June 2008</ref><ref name=efsa>{{cite journal |author= EFSA Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies |year=2010 |title=Scientific Opinion on the substantiation of health claims related to various food(s)/food constituent(s) and protection of cells from premature aging, antioxidant activity, antioxidant content and antioxidant properties, and protection of DNA, proteins and lipids from oxidative damage pursuant to Article 13(1) of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 |journal=EFSA Journal |volume=8 |issue=2 |page=1489 |doi=10.2903/j.efsa.2010.1489}}</ref>
==Physiological context== Despite the above discussion implying that ORAC-rich foods with polyphenols may provide antioxidant benefits when in the diet, there remains no physiological evidence that any polyphenols have such actions or that ORAC has any relevance in the human body.
On the contrary, research indicates that although polyphenols are [[antioxidant]]s [[in vitro]], antioxidant effects [[in vivo]] are probably negligible or absent.<ref name="Williams RJ, Spencer JP, Rice-Evans C 2004 838–49">{{cite journal |last1=Williams |first1=Robert J |last2=Spencer |first2=Jeremy P.E | authorlink2 = Jeremy P. E. Spencer |last3=Rice-Evans |first3=Catherine |title=Flavonoids: antioxidants or signalling molecules?☆ |journal=Free Radical Biology and Medicine |volume=36 |issue=7 |pages=838–49 |year=2004 |pmid=15019969 |doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2004.01.001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nutraceuticalsworld.com/issues/2009-03/view_features/new-roles-for-polyphenols/ |title=New Roles for Polyphenols. A 3-Part report on Current Regulations & the State of Science |last1=Gross |first1=P |last2= |first2= |date=2009 |work=Nutraceuticals World |publisher=Rodman Media |accessdate=April 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name=USDA2>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dr-jonny-bowden/orac-_b_1594115.html|title=ORAC no more! |author= Jonny Bowden, PhD, C.N.S.|date=16 Dec 2012 |work= |publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate=12 Dec 2012}}</ref> By non-antioxidant mechanisms still undefined, polyphenols may affect mechanisms of cardiovascular disease or cancer.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Arts |first1=IC |last2=Hollman |first2=PC |title=Polyphenols and disease risk in epidemiologic studies |journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition |volume=81 |issue=1 Suppl |pages=317S–325S |year=2005 |pmid=15640497}}</ref>
The increase in antioxidant capacity of blood seen after the consumption of polyphenol-rich (ORAC-rich) foods is not caused directly by the polyphenols, but most likely results from increased [[uric acid]] levels derived from metabolism of [[flavonoids]].<ref name = Lotito/><ref name="LPI"/> According to Frei, "we can now follow the activity of flavonoids in the body, and one thing that is clear is that the body sees them as foreign compounds and is trying to get rid of them."<ref name="LPI"/> Another mechanism may be the increase in activities of [[paraoxonase]]s by dietary antioxidants which can reduce [[oxidative stress]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/01.mol.0000174398.84185.0f |last1=Aviram |first1=M |last2=Rosenblat |first2=M |title=Paraoxonases and cardiovascular diseases: pharmacological and nutritional influences |journal=Current Opinion in Lipidology |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=393–9 |year=2005 |pmid=15990587}}</ref>
== Vitamins == * [[Vitamin A]] (retinol), also [[Biosynthesis|synthesized]] by the body from [[beta-carotene]], protects dark green, yellow and orange vegetables and fruits from [[solar radiation]] damage, and is thought to play a similar role in the human body. [[Carrot]]s, [[squash (fruit)|squash]], [[broccoli]], [[sweet potato]]es, [[tomato]]es (which gain their color from the compound [[lycopene]]), [[kale]], [[mango]]es, [[orange (fruit)|oranges]], [[seabuckthorn]] berries, [[wolfberries]] (goji), [[collards]], [[cantaloupe]], [[peach]]es and [[apricot]]s are particularly rich sources of [[beta-carotene]], the major [[provitamin A]] [[carotenoid]]. * [[Vitamin C]] (ascorbic acid) is a water-[[soluble]] compound that fulfills several roles in living systems. Sources include [[citrus]] fruits (such as [[orange (fruit)|oranges]], [[sweet lime]], etc.), [[Bell pepper|green peppers]], [[broccoli]], [[green leafy vegetable]]s, [[black currants]], [[strawberries]], [[blueberries]], [[seabuckthorn]], raw [[cabbage]] and [[tomato]]es. * [[Vitamin E]], including [[tocotrienol]] and [[tocopherol]], is fat soluble and protects [[lipid]]s. Sources include [[wheat germ]], [[seabuckthorn]], [[nut (fruit)|nuts]], [[seed]]s, [[whole grain]]s, [[green leafy vegetables]], [[kiwifruit]], [[vegetable oil]], and [[Cod liver oil|fish-liver oil]]. Alpha-tocopherol is the main form in which vitamin E is consumed. Recent studies showed that some tocotrienol isomers have significant anti-oxidant properties.
==Vitamin cofactors and minerals== * [[Coenzyme Q]]10 * [[Manganese]], particularly when in its +2 valence state as part of the enzyme called [[superoxide dismutase]] (SOD). * [[Iodide]]
== Hormones == * [[Melatonin]]
== Carotenoid terpenoids == :{{main|Carotenoid}} * [[Alpha-carotene]] - found in carrots, winter squash, tomatoes, green beans, cilantro, Swiss chard * [[Astaxanthin]] - found naturally in [[red algae]] and animals higher in the marine food chain. It is a red pigment familiarly recognized in crustacean shells and salmon flesh/roe. * [[Beta-carotene]] - found in high concentrations in butternut squash, carrots, orange bell peppers, pumpkins, kale, peaches, apricots, mango, turnip greens, broccoli, spinach, and sweet potatoes. * [[Canthaxanthin]] * [[Cryptoxanthin]] - present in [[papaya]], egg yolk, butter, apples * [[Lutein]] - found in high concentration in spinach, kale, Swiss chard, collard greens, beet and mustard greens, endive, red pepper and okra * [[Lycopene]] - found in high concentration in cooked red tomato products like canned tomatoes, tomato sauce, tomato juice and garden cocktails, guava and watermelons. * [[Zeaxanthin]] - best sources are kale, collard greens, spinach, turnip greens, Swiss chard, mustard and beet greens, corn, and broccoli
== Natural phenols == {{Main|Polyphenol}} Natural phenols are a class of molecules found in abundance in plants.
=== Flavonoids === [[Flavonoid]]s, a subset of [[polyphenol antioxidant]]s, are present in many [[berry|berries]], as well as in [[coffee]] and [[tea]]. * [[Flavones]]: ** [[Apigenin]] ** [[Luteolin]] ** [[Tangeritin]] * [[Flavonols]]: ** [[Isorhamnetin]] ** [[Kaempferol]] ** [[Myricetin]] - [[walnut]]s are a rich source ** [[Proanthocyanidin]]s, or [[condensed tannin]]s ** [[Quercetin]] and related, such as [[rutin]] * Flavanones: ** [[Eriodictyol]] ** [[Hesperetin]] (metabolizes to [[hesperidin]]) ** [[Naringenin]] (metabolized from [[naringin]]) * Flavanols and their polymers: ** [[Catechin]], [[gallocatechin]] and their corresponding [[gallic acid|gallate]] esters ** [[Epicatechin]], [[epigallocatechin]] and their corresponding gallate esters ** [[Theaflavin]] its gallate esters ** [[Thearubigin]]s * [[Isoflavone]] [[phytoestrogens]] - found primarily in soy, peanuts, and other members of the Fabaceae family ** [[Daidzein]] ** [[Genistein]] ** [[Glycitein]] * [[Stilbenoids]]: ** [[Resveratrol]] - found in the skins of dark-colored grapes, and concentrated in red wine. ** [[Pterostilbene]] - methoxylated analogue of resveratrol, abundant in ''[[Vaccinium]]'' berries * [[Anthocyanins]] ** [[Cyanidin]] ** [[Delphinidin]] ** [[Malvidin]] ** [[Pelargonidin]] ** [[Peonidin]] ** [[Petunidin]]
=== Phenolic acids and their esters === :{{main|polyphenol antioxidant}} * [[Chicoric acid]] - another caffeic acid derivative, is found in chicory and Echinacea. * [[Chlorogenic acid]] - found in high concentration in coffee (more concentrated in robusta than arabica beans), blueberries and tomatoes. Produced from esterification of caffeic acid. * [[Cinnamic acid]] and its derivatives, such as [[ferulic acid]] - found in seeds of plants such as in brown rice, whole wheat and oats, as well as in coffee, apple, artichoke, peanut, orange and pineapple. * [[Ellagic acid]] - found in high concentration in [[raspberry]] and [[strawberry]], and in ester form in red wine tannins. * [[Ellagitannin]]s - hydrolyzable tannin polymer formed when ellagic acid, a polyphenol monomer, esterifies and binds with the hydroxyl group of a polyol carbohydrate such as glucose. * [[Gallic acid]] - found in gallnuts, sumac, witch hazel, tea leaves, oak bark, and many other plants. * [[Gallotannin]]s - hydrolyzable tannin polymer formed when gallic acid, a polyphenol monomer, esterifies and binds with the hydroxyl group of a polyol carbohydrate such as glucose. * [[Rosmarinic acid]] - found in high concentration in [[rosemary]], [[oregano]], [[lemon balm]], [[Common sage|sage]], and [[marjoram]]. * [[Salicylic acid]] - found in most vegetables, fruits, and herbs; but most abundantly in the bark of willow trees, from where it was extracted for use in the early manufacture of [[aspirin]].
=== Other nonflavonoid phenolics === * [[Curcumin]] - Curcumin has low bioavailability, because, much of it is excreted through [[glucuronidation]]. However, bioavailability is substantially enhanced by solubilization in a lipid (oil or lecithin), heat,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kurien |first1=Biji T. |last2=Singh |first2=Anil |last3=Matsumoto |first3=Hiroyuki |last4=Scofield |first4=R. Hal |title=Improving the Solubility and Pharmacological Efficacy of Curcumin by Heat Treatment |journal=ASSAY and Drug Development Technologies |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=567–76 |year=2007 |pmid=17767425 |doi=10.1089/adt.2007.064}}</ref> addition of [[piperine]], or through nanoparticularization. * Flavonolignans - e.g. [[silymarin]] - a mixture of flavonolignans extracted from [[milk thistle]]. * [[Xanthone]]s - [[mangosteen]] is purported to contain a large variety of xanthones,<ref>[http://www.choice.com.au/viewArticleAsOnePage.aspx?id=105902 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804162147/http://www.choice.com.au/viewArticleAsOnePage.aspx?id=105902 |date=August 4, 2008 }}</ref> but some of the xanthones like [[mangostin]] might be present only in the [[Xanthone#Xanthone derivatives|inedible shell]]. * [[Eugenol]]
==Polyphenols in foods== Many common foods contain rich sources of [[polyphenols]] which have antioxidant properties only in test tube studies. As interpreted by the [[Linus Pauling Institute]], dietary polyphenols have little or no direct antioxidant food value following digestion.<ref name = Lotito>{{cite journal |last1=Lotito |first1=S |last2=Frei |first2=B |title=Consumption of flavonoid-rich foods and increased plasma antioxidant capacity in humans: Cause, consequence, or epiphenomenon? |journal=Free Radical Biology and Medicine |volume=41 |issue=12 |pages=1727–46 |year=2006 |pmid=17157175 |doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2006.04.033}}</ref> Not like controlled test tube conditions, the fate of flavones or polyphenols [[in vivo]] shows they are poorly absorbed and poorly conserved (less than 5%), so that most of what is absorbed exists as metabolites modified during digestion, destined for rapid excretion.<ref name="LPI">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2007-03/osu-sfn030507.php|title=Studies force new view on biology of flavonoids|author=David Stauth|publisher=EurekAlert!; Adapted from a news release issued by Oregon State University|date=5 March 2007}}</ref>
Spices, herbs, and [[essential oil]]s are rich in polyphenols in the plant itself and shown with antioxidant potential [[in vitro]]. Typical spices high in polyphenols (confirmed in vitro) are [[clove]], [[cinnamon]], [[oregano]], [[turmeric]], [[cumin]], [[parsley]], [[basil]], [[curry powder]], [[mustard seed]], [[ginger]], [[Black pepper|pepper]], [[chili powder]], [[paprika]], [[garlic]], [[coriander]], [[onion]] and [[cardamom]]. Typical herbs are [[Salvia officinalis|sage]], [[thyme]], [[marjoram]], [[tarragon]], [[peppermint]], [[oregano]], [[Summer savory|savory]], [[basil]] and [[dill weed]].
Dried fruits are a good source of polyphenols by weight/serving size as the water has been removed making the ratio of polyphenols higher. Typical dried fruits are pears, apples, plums, peaches, raisins, figs and dates. Dried raisins are high in polyphenol count. Red wine is high in total polyphenol count which supplies antioxidant quality which is unlikely to be conserved following digestion (see section below).
Deeply pigmented fruits like cranberries, blueberries, plums, blackberries, raspberries, strawberries, blackcurrants, figs, cherries, guava, oranges, mango, grape juice and pomegranate juice also have significant polyphenol content.
Typical cooked vegetables rich in antioxidants are [[artichoke]]s, [[cabbage]], [[broccoli]], [[asparagus]], [[avocado]]s, [[beetroot]] and [[spinach]].
Nuts are a moderate source of polyphenol antioxidants. Typical nuts are [[pecan]]s, [[walnut]]s, [[hazelnut]]s, [[pistachio]], [[almond]]s, [[cashew nut]]s, [[macadamia nut]]s and [[peanut butter]].
Sorghum bran, [[Cocoa solids|cocoa]] powder, and [[cinnamon]] are rich sources of procyanidins, which are large [[molecular weight]] compounds found in many fruits and some vegetables. Partly due to the large molecular weight (size) of these compounds, their amount actually absorbed in the body is low, an effect also resulting from the action of stomach acids, enzymes and bacteria in the gastrointestinal tract where smaller derivatives are metabolized and prepared for rapid excretion.<ref name = Lotito/><ref name="LPI"/>
== Other compounds == * [[Capsaicin]], the active component of chili peppers * [[Bilirubin]], a breakdown product of blood, has been identified as a possible antioxidant.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Stocker |first1=R |last2=Yamamoto |first2=Y |last3=McDonagh |first3=A. |last4=Glazer |first4=A. |last5=Ames |first5=B. |title=Bilirubin is an antioxidant of possible physiological importance |journal=Science |volume=235 |issue=4792 |pages=1043–6 |year=1987 |pmid=3029864 |doi=10.1126/science.3029864|bibcode = 1987Sci...235.1043S }}</ref> * [[Citric acid]], [[oxalic acid]], and [[phytic acid]] * N-[[Acetylcysteine]], water-soluble * R-α-[[Lipoic acid]], fat- and water-soluble <!--* [[Uric acid]], in humans, accounts for roughly half the antioxidant capacity of plasma.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} [[Fructose]], which is found abundantly in fruits, significantly elevates uric acid levels in humans,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zawiasa |first1=A. |last2=Szklarek-Kubicka |first2=M. |last3=Fijałkowska-Morawska |first3=J. |last4=Nowak |first4=D. |last5=Rysz |first5=J. |last6=Mamełka |first6=B. |last7=Nowicki |first7=M. |title=Effect of Oral Fructose Load on Serum Uric Acid and Lipids in Kidney Transplant Recipients Treated with Cyclosporine or Tacrolimus |journal=Transplantation Proceedings |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=188–91 |year=2009 |pmid=19249511 |doi=10.1016/j.transproceed.2008.10.038}}</ref> and thus indirectly increases antioxidant capacity. High levels of uric acid may be a protective factor against Parkinson's disease<ref>{{cite journal |last1=De Vera |first1=Mary |last2=Rahman |first2=M. Mushfiqur |last3=Rankin |first3=James |last4=Kopec |first4=Jacek |last5=Gao |first5=Xiang |last6=Choi |first6=Hyon |title=Gout and the risk of parkinson's disease: A cohort study |journal=Arthritis & Rheumatism |volume=59 |issue=11 |pages=1549–54 |year=2008 |doi=10.1002/art.24193 |pmid=18975349}}</ref> and possibly other diseases related to [[oxidative stress]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}-->
==See also== * [[Antioxidant]] * [[Colour retention agent]] * [[Nutrition]] * [[Polyphenol antioxidant]] * [[Free radical]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2841576 The total antioxidant content of more than 3100 foods, beverages, spices, herbs and supplements used worldwide] Nutr J. 2010

page.title: List of centers and institutes at the Perelman School of Medicine

revision.comment: /* References */
revision.text:
This list contains the names of the centers and institutes at the [[Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania]] in alphabetical order with their external links.<ref>{{cite web|title=Centers and Institutes|url=http://www.med.upenn.edu/centers.shtml|work=Perelman School of Medicine|publisher=University of Pennsylvania|accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref>
* Abramson [[Cancer]] Center – http://penncancer.org/ * Brain Behavior Lab (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/bbl/ * Center for [[Bioethics]] – http://bioethics.upenn.edu/ * Center for Bio[[medical Image Computing]] and Analytics – http://www.cbica.upenn.edu/ * Center for [[Brain Injury]] and Repair (Department of [[Neurosurgery]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cbir/ * Center for [[Cancer]] Pharmacology (Department of Pharmacology) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/ccp/ * Center for [[Clinical Epidemiology]] and [[Biostatistics]] – http://www.cceb.upenn.edu/ * Center for [[Cognitive Therapy]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cct/ * Center for Community-Based Research and [[Health equity|Health Disparities]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – https://web.archive.org/web/20120308173351/http://www.med.upenn.edu/ccrhd/ * Center for [[Gastroenterology|Digestive]], [[Hepatology|Liver]], and [[Hepatology|Pancreatic Medicine]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/jointcenterfordighealth/ * Center for [[Evidence-Based Practice]] – http://www.uphs.upenn.edu/cep/ * Center for [[Functional Neuroimaging]] (Department of [[Radiology]] and [[Neurology]]) – http://www.cfn.upenn.edu/ * Center for [[Genetics]] and [[Complex Trait]]s (Center for [[Clinical Epidemiology]] and [[Biostatistics]]) – http://www.cceb.upenn.edu/pages/cgact/ * Center for Healthcare Improvement & [[Patient Safety]] (Department of Medicine) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/chips * Center for Health Incentives and [[Behavioral Economics]] at the Leonard Davis Institute – http://chibe.upenn.edu/ * Center for Interdisciplinary Research on [[Nicotine Addiction]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cirna/ * Center for [[Mental Health]] Policy and Services Research (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cmhpsr/ * Center for Molecular Studies in [[Digestive disease|Digestive]] and [[Liver Disease]] (Department of Medicine) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/molecular/ * Center for [[Neurobiology]] and Behavior (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cnb/ * Center for [[Neurodegenerative Disease]] Research (Department of [[Pathology]] and [[Laboratory Medicine]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cndr/ * Center for Preventive [[Ophthalmology]] and [[Biostatistics]] (Department of Ophthalmology) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cpob/ * Center for [[Psychopathology]] Research (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) * Center for [[Psychotherapy]] Research (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/cpr/ * Center for [[Public Health]] Initiatives – http://www.cphi.upenn.edu/ * Center for Research on [[Reproduction]] and [[Women's Health]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/crrwh/ * Center for [[Resuscitation]] Science (Department of Emergency Medicine) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/resuscitation/ * Center for [[Sleep medicine|Sleep and Circadian Neurobiology]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/sleepctr/ * Center for Studies of [[Addiction]]s (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/csa/ * Center for the Prevention of [[Suicide]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/suicide/ * Center for the Treatment and Study of [[Anxiety]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/ctsa/ * Center for [[Translational Research]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) * Center for Weight and [[Eating Disorder]]s (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/weight/research.shtml * Center of Excellence in [[Environmental Toxicology]] (Department of [[Pharmacology]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/ceet/ * Center on the [[Continuum of Care]] (Department of [[Psychiatry]]) – http://www.med.upenn.edu/ccc/index.html * [[Clinical research|Clinical]] and [[Translational Research]] Center (Institute for [[Translational Medicine]] and [[Therapeutics]]) – http://www.itmat.upenn.edu/ctsa/ * [[Eldridge Reeves Johnson]] Foundation (Department of [[Biochemistry]] and [[Biophysics]]) – http://www.uphs.upenn.edu/biocbiop/jf/jf.html * Institute for [[Diabetes]], [[Obesity]] and [[Metabolism]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/idom/ * Institute for [[Environmental Medicine]] – https://web.archive.org/web/20120120233850/http://health.upenn.edu/ifem/ * Institute for [[Immunology]] – http://www.med.upenn.edu/ifi/ * Institute for Medicine and Engineering – http://www.uphs.upenn.edu/ime/ * Institute for [[Regenerative Medicine]] – http://www.irm.upenn.edu/ * Institute for Strategic This is a '''list of lakes of Minnesota'''. Although promoted as the "Land of 10,000 Lakes," Minnesota has 11,842 lakes of 10 acres or more.{{cite web |title=Lakes, rivers, and wetlands facts |url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/faq/mnfacts/water.html |publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources |date=2016 |accessdate=19 November 2016}} The 1968 state survey found 15,291 lake basins, of which 3,257 were dry.{{cite book |title=Bulletin No. 25 - An Inventory of Minnesota Lakes |url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/waters/watermgmt_section/pwi/bulletin25.html |publisher=Minnesota Conservation Department - Division of Waters, Soils, and Minerals |date=1968 |page=6}} If all basins over 2.5 acres were counted, Minnesota would have 21,871 lakes.{{cite web |title=The Ten Largest Lakes in Minnesota |url=http://www.minnesotafunfacts.com/minnesota-geography/the-ten-largest-lakes-in-minnesota/ |publisher=Minnesota Fun Facts |accessdate=19 November 2016}} The prevalence of lakes has generated many repeat names. For example, there are more than 200 Mud Lakes, 150 Long Lakes, and 120 Rice Lakes.{{cite web|url=http://www.minnesotafunfacts.com/trivia/geography/|title=Geography |publisher=Minnesota Fun Facts |accessdate=28 April 2015}} All but four [[List of counties in Minnesota|Minnesota counties]] ([[Mower County, Minnesota|Mower]], [[Olmsted County, Minnesota|Olmsted]], [[Pipestone County, Minnesota|Pipestone]] and [[Rock County, Minnesota|Rock]]) contain at least one natural lake. Minnesota's lakes provide 44,926 miles of shoreline, more than the combined lake (~32,000 mi) and coastal (3,427 mi) shorelines of [[California]].{{citation|title=Frequently Asked Questions: Travel and Leisure |url=http://www.state.mn.us/portal/mn/jsp/content.do?action=faq&category=Travel+and+Leisure&agency=NorthStar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205035251/http://www.state.mn.us/portal/mn/jsp/content.do?action=faq&category=Travel%2Band%2BLeisure&agency=NorthStar |archivedate=5 February 2012 |publisher=Minnesota North Star |accessdate=2013-04-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{citation|url=http://www.chrisfinke.com/2013/12/30/does-minnesota-really-have-more-shoreline-than-california/|title=Does Minnesota really have more shoreline than California?|accessdate=2013-12-30 }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Mammals by population sidebar}} This is a list of [[primate]] species by estimated global population. This list is not comprehensive, as not all primates have had their numbers quantified. {{Clear}} {{Expand list|date=November 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width="15%"|Common name ! width="15%"|[[Binomial nomenclature|Binomial name]] ! data-sort-type="number" width="15%"|[[Population biology|Population]] ! width="5%"|[[Conservation status|Status]] ! width="5%"|Trend ! class="unsortable"|Notes ! class="unsortable"|Image |-
| '''[[Hainan black crested gibbon]]''' ||''Nomascus hainanus'' || '''20'''<ref name='Nomascus hainanus IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41643/0 | title = Nomascus hainanus | accessdate = 2012-11-10 |author1=Geissmann, T. |author2=Bleisch, W. |lastauthoramp=yes| year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}</ref>|| align=center style="background:#F08080"|[[Critically endangered species|CR]]<ref name='Nomascus hainanus IUCN'/> || align=center|{{steady}}<ref name='Nomascus hainanus IUCN'/> || Population was estimated at over 2,000 in the late 1950s.<ref name='Nomascus hainanus IUCN'/> || [[Image:Nomascus nasutus hainanus.jpg|175px]] |- | '''[[Eastern black crested gibbon]]''' ||''Nomascus nasutus'' || '''35–37'''<ref name='Nomascus nasutus IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/41642/0 | title = Nomascus nasutus | accessdate = 2012-11-10 |author1=Geissmann, T. |author2=Bleisch, W. |lastauthoramp=yes| year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}</ref>|| align=center style="background:#F08080"|[[Critically endangered species|CR]]<ref name='Nomascus nasutus IUCN'/> || align=center|{{decrease}}<ref name='Nomascus nasutus IUCN'/> || Previously thought to be possibly extinct. Numbers may be higher.<ref name='Nomascus nasutus IUCN'/> || |- | '''[[Blond capuchin]]''' ||''Cebus flavius'' || '''180'''<ref name='Cebus flavius IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/136253/0 | title = Cebus flavius | accessdate = 2012-11-10 | author = de Oliveira, M.M., Boubli, J.-P. & Kierulff, M.C.M. | year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}</ref>|| align=center style="background:#F08080"|[[Critically endangered species|CR]]<ref name='Cebus flavius IUCN'/> || align=center|{{decrease}}<ref name='Cebus flavius IUCN'/> || Estimate is for mature individuals only.<ref name='Cebus flavius IUCN'/> ||[[Image:S. flavius SP Zoo 3.jpg|175px]] |- | '''[[Sarawak surili]]''' ||''Presbytis chrysomelas'' || '''200–500'''<ref name='Presbytis chrysomelas IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/39803/0 | title = Presbytis chrysomelas | accessdate = 2012-11-10 | author = Nijman, V., Hon, J. & Richardson, M. | year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}</ref>|| align=center style="background:#F08080"|[[Critically endangered species|CR]]<ref name='Presbytis chrysomelas IUCN'/> || align=center|{{decrease}}<ref name='Presbytis chrysomelas IUCN'/> || || |- | '''[[Perrier's sifaka]]''' ||''Propithecus perrieri'' || '''230'''<ref name='Propithecus perrieri IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/18361/0 | title = Propithecus perrieri | accessdate = 2012-11-10 | author = Andrainarivo, C., Andriaholinirina, V.N., Feistner, A., Felix, T., Ganzhorn, J., Garbutt, N., Golden, C., Konstant, B., Louis Jr., E., Meyers, D., Mittermeier, R.A., Perieras, A., Princee, F., Rabarivola, J.C., Rakotosamimanana, B., Rasamimanana, H., Ratsimbazafy, J., Raveloarinoro, G., Razafimanantsoa, A., Rumpler, Y., Schwitzer, C., Thalmann, U., Wilmé, L. & Wright, P. | year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}</ref>|| align=center style="background:#F08080"|[[Critically endangered species|CR]]<ref name='Propithecus perrieri IUCN'/> || align=center|{{decrease}}<ref name='Propithecus perrieri IUCN'/> || One of the 25 most endangered primates.<ref name='Propithecus perrieri IUCN'/> || [[Image:Propithecus perrieri 001.jpg|175px]] |- | '''[[Silky sifaka]]''' ||''Propithecus candidus'' || '''250'''<ref name='Propithecus candidus IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/18360/0 | title = Propithecus candidus | accessdate = 2012-11-10 | author = Andrainarivo, C., Andriaholinirina, V.N., Feistner, A., Felix, T., Ganzhorn, J., Garbutt, N., Golden, C., Konstant, B., Louis Jr., E., Meyers, D., Mittermeier, R.A., Patel, E., Perieras, A., Princee, F., Rabarivola, J.C., Rakotosamimanana, B., Rasamimanana, H., Ratsimbazafy, J., Raveloarinoro, G., Razafimanantsoa, A., Rumpler, Y., Schwitzer, C., Thalmann, U., Wilmé, L. & Wright, P. | year = 2008 | work = IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
